def:
\label{kappa} If $C$ is an Euler system of a 4-regular multigraph $F$ and
$v\in V(F)$ then the $\kappa$\emph{-transform} $C\ast v$ is the Euler system
obtained by reversing one of the two $v$-to-$v$ trails within the circuit of
$C$ incident at $v$.
plain_text_def:
If C is an Euler system of a 4-regular multigraph F and
v∈ V(F) then the κ-transform C∗ v is the Euler system
obtained by reversing one of the two v-to-v trails within the circuit of
C incident at v.
masked_plain_text_def:
If C is an Euler system of a 4-regular multigraph F and
v∈ V(F) then the κB_MATH_TERM C∗ v is the Euler system
obtained by reversing one of the two v-to-v trails within the circuit of
C incident at v.

def:
Let $F$ be a 4-regular multigraph with an Euler system $C$, and suppose
$W\subseteq V(F)$ has the property that an Euler system is obtained from $C$
by using the $\psi$ transition at every vertex in $W$, and the $\chi$
transition at every vertex not in $W$. Then this Euler system is the $\iota
$\emph{-transform} of $C$ with respect to $W$; we denote it $C\#W$.
plain_text_def:
Let F be a 4-regular multigraph with an Euler system C, and suppose
W⊆ V(F) has the property that an Euler system is obtained from C
by using the ψ transition at every vertex in W, and the χ
transition at every vertex not in W. Then this Euler system is the ι-transform of C with respect to W; we denote it C#W.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let F be a 4-regular multigraph with an Euler system C, and suppose
W⊆ V(F) has the property that an Euler system is obtained from C
by using the ψ transition at every vertex in W, and the χ
transition at every vertex not in W. Then this Euler system is the ιB_MATH_TERM of C with respect to W; we denote it C#W.

def: Let $G=G(\Phi)$ be the Weyl group associated to $\Phi$ acting on $\R^n$. Fix a point  $x\in \R^n$ which is not on any of the hyperplanes in $\Sigma(\Phi)$. The convex hull of the orbit of $x$ under $G$, $$P_G(x)= \text{conv}(\{g.x~:~g\in G \})$$ is called a $\Phi$-\emph{Permutahedron} .
plain_text_def:
Let G=G(Φ) be the Weyl group associated to Φ acting on ^n. Fix a point  x∈^n which is not on any of the hyperplanes in Σ(Φ). The convex hull of the orbit of x under G, 
    P_G(x)= conv({g.x : g∈ G })
 is called a Φ-Permutahedron .
masked_plain_text_def:
Let G=G(Φ) be the Weyl group associated to Φ acting on ^n. Fix a point  x∈^n which is not on any of the hyperplanes in Σ(Φ). The convex hull of the orbit of x under G, 
    P_G(x)= conv({g.x : g∈ G })
 is called a Φ-B_MATH_TERM .

def:
\label{def:trans}
Let $f:[1,N]\rightarrow\R$ be an arbitrary function.
\begin{enumerate}
\item The function $f$ is said to be $\eta$-\textit{pseudorandom} if
$|\hat{f}(r/N)-\delta_{r,0}N|\leq\eta N$ for each $r\in\Z/N\Z$,
where $\delta_{r,0}$ is the Kronecker delta.
\item The function $f$ is said to satisfy the $L^q$ extension
estimate if $\|\hat{f}\|_q\ll_q N^{1-1/q}$, where the implied
constant depends only on $q$.
\item The function $f$ is said to be $(\beta,\kappa)$-regular if
\[ \sum_{(u,v)\in M}f(u)f(v)\geq\kappa N^2, \]
where
\[ M=\{(u,v):u\leq\beta N,v\geq (1-\beta)N,(v-u,P(\beta^{-1}))=1\}. \]
\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
Let f:[1,N]→ be an arbitrary function.


  * The function f is said to be η-pseudorandom if
|f̂(r/N)-δ_r,0N|≤η N for each r∈/N,
where δ_r,0 is the Kronecker delta.

  * The function f is said to satisfy the L^q extension
estimate if f̂_q≪_q N^1-1/q, where the implied
constant depends only on q.

  * The function f is said to be (β,κ)-regular if

    ∑_(u,v)∈ Mf(u)f(v)≥κ N^2,

where

    M={(u,v):u≤β N,v≥ (1-β)N,(v-u,P(β^-1))=1}.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let f:[1,N]→ be an arbitrary function.


  * The function f is said to be η-B_MATH_TERM if
|f̂(r/N)-δ_r,0N|≤η N for each r∈/N,
where δ_r,0 is the Kronecker delta.

  * The function f is said to satisfy the L^q extension
estimate if f̂_q≪_q N^1-1/q, where the implied
constant depends only on q.

  * The function f is said to be (β,κ)-regular if

    ∑_(u,v)∈ Mf(u)f(v)≥κ N^2,

where

    M={(u,v):u≤β N,v≥ (1-β)N,(v-u,P(β^-1))=1}.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
Let p=p(n) be a sequence of densities, i.e., 0≤ p≤ 1, and let β=β(n).
An n-vertex graph Γ is called (p,β)-jumbled if 

    |e_Γ(X,Y)-p(X,Y)| ≤β(X,Y)^1/2,

for all X,Y ⊆ V(Γ).
masked_plain_text_def:
Let p=p(n) be a sequence of densities, i.e., 0≤ p≤ 1, and let β=β(n).
An n-vertex graph Γ is called (p,β)-B_MATH_TERM if 

    |e_Γ(X,Y)-p(X,Y)| ≤β(X,Y)^1/2,

for all X,Y ⊆ V(Γ).
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
[$c$-ordinary triangle]
Let $c$ be a natural number and  let $P$ be a point set in the plane. 
A $c$-\textit{ordinary triangle} in $P$ is 
a subset of $P$ consisting of three non-collinear points such that each of the 
three lines determined by the three points contains at most $c$ points of $P$.
plain_text_def:
[c-ordinary triangle]
Let c be a natural number and  let P be a point set in the plane. 
A c-ordinary triangle in P is 
a subset of P consisting of three non-collinear points such that each of the 
three lines determined by the three points contains at most c points of P.
masked_plain_text_def:
[c-ordinary triangle]
Let c be a natural number and  let P be a point set in the plane. 
A c-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM in P is 
a subset of P consisting of three non-collinear points such that each of the 
three lines determined by the three points contains at most c points of P.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
Let $\mathbf{V}=(V_n)_{n \in \N}$ be an ssee. Let $N_1$,~$N_2 \leq n$.  An \emph{$i$-intersecting embedding} of~$(V_{N_1}, V_{N_2})$ into $V_n$ is a function $\phi: \ V_{N_1}\sqcup V_{N_2}\rightarrow V_n$ such that:
	\begin{enumerate}[(i)]
		\item the restriction of $\phi$ to  $V_{N_1}$ lies in $\binom{V_n}{V_{N_1}}$, and the restriction of $\phi$ to $V_{N_2}$ lies in $\binom{V_n}{V_{N_2}}$;
		\item $\vert \phi(V_{N_1})\cap \phi(V_{N_2})\vert=i$.
	\end{enumerate}
	We denote by $I_i\bigl( (V_{N_1}, V_{N_2}), V_n\bigr)$ the number of $i$-intersecting embeddings of $(V_{N_1}, V_{N_2})$ into $V_n$, and set
	\[I(N, n):=\sum_{1<i<\vert V_N\vert} I_i\bigl( (V_{N}, V_{N}), V_n\bigr).\]
plain_text_def:
Let 𝐕=(V_n)_n ∈ be an ssee. Let N_1, N_2 ≤ n.  An i-intersecting embedding of (V_N_1, V_N_2) into V_n is a function ϕ:  V_N_1⊔ V_N_2→ V_n such that:
	
		
  * the restriction of ϕ to  V_N_1 lies in V_nV_N_1, and the restriction of ϕ to V_N_2 lies in V_nV_N_2;
		
  * |ϕ(V_N_1)∩ϕ(V_N_2)|=i.
	
	We denote by I_i( (V_N_1, V_N_2), V_n) the number of i-intersecting embeddings of (V_N_1, V_N_2) into V_n, and set
	
    I(N, n):=∑_1<i<| V_N| I_i( (V_N, V_N), V_n).
masked_plain_text_def:
Let 𝐕=(V_n)_n ∈ be an ssee. Let N_1, N_2 ≤ n.  An i-intersecting embedding of (V_N_1, V_N_2) into V_n is a function ϕ:  V_N_1⊔ V_N_2→ V_n such that:
	
		
  * the restriction of ϕ to  V_N_1 lies in V_nV_N_1, and the restriction of ϕ to V_N_2 lies in V_nV_N_2;
		
  * |ϕ(V_N_1)∩ϕ(V_N_2)|=i.
	
	We denote by I_i( (V_N_1, V_N_2), V_n) the number of i-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM of (V_N_1, V_N_2) into V_n, and set
	
    I(N, n):=∑_1<i<| V_N| I_i( (V_N, V_N), V_n).

def: For $F$ an edge-coloring of $K_n$ and $S \subseteq R$ a set of colors, we write that a set $Z$ of vertices is $S$-\emph{subchromatic} in $F$ if every edge internal to $Z$ takes colors (under $F$) only from $S$.
plain_text_def: For F an edge-coloring of K_n and S ⊆ R a set of colors, we write that a set Z of vertices is S-subchromatic in F if every edge internal to Z takes colors (under F) only from S.
masked_plain_text_def: For F an edge-coloring of K_n and S ⊆ R a set of colors, we write that a set Z of vertices is S-B_MATH_TERM in F if every edge internal to Z takes colors (under F) only from S.

def:
\label{31} Fix $\I, \J$ $L'$-structures and a sublanguage $L^\ast \subseteq L'$.  Fix a set of parameters $\In := (a_i : i \in I)$. 
\begin{enumerate}
\item We say the $J$-indexed set $(b_i : i \in J)$ 
is \emph{$L^\ast$-locally based on the $a_i$ ($L^\ast$-locally based on $\In$)} if for any finite set of $L$-formulas, $\Delta$, and for any finite tuple $(t_1, \ldots, t_n)$ from $J$, there exists a tuple $(s_1, \ldots, s_n)$ from $I$ such that 

$\qt^{L^\ast}(\ov{t};\J)=\qt^{L^\ast}(\ov{s};\I)$, 

\nin and

$\textrm{tp}^{\Delta}(\ov{b}_{\ov{t}}; \Mm) = \textrm{tp}^{\Delta}(\ov{a}_{\ov{s}}; \Mm)$.

\vspace{.1in}

\noindent We abbreviate this condition by ``the $b_i$ are $L^\ast$-locally based on the $a_i$.''

\item If the $J$-indexed set $(b_i : i \in J)$ is $L'$-locally based on the $a_i$, we omit mention of $L'$. 
\end{enumerate}

is L^∗-locally based on the a_i (L^∗-locally based on ) if for any finite set of L-formulas, Δ, and for any finite tuple (t_1, …, t_n) from J, there exists a tuple (s_1, …, s_n) from I such that 

^L^∗(t;)=^L^∗(s;), 

and

tp^Δ(b_t; ) = tp^Δ(a_s; ).




We abbreviate this condition by “the b_i are L^∗-locally based on the a_i.”


  * If the J-indexed set (b_i : i ∈ J) is L'-locally based on the a_i, we omit mention of L'.
masked_plain_text_def:
Fix , L'-structures and a sublanguage L^∗⊆ L'.  Fix a set of parameters := (a_i : i ∈ I). 


  * We say the J-indexed set (b_i : i ∈ J) 
is L^∗-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM the a_i (L^∗-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM ) if for any finite set of L-formulas, Δ, and for any finite tuple (t_1, …, t_n) from J, there exists a tuple (s_1, …, s_n) from I such that

and

tp^Δ(b_t; ) = tp^Δ(a_s; ).




We abbreviate this condition by “the b_i are L^∗-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM the a_i.”

plain_text_def:
If G is a graph, W is a reducible set of vertices in G, and W_1,W_2 ⊂ V \ W are two sets of vertices in Γ_W(G), then

    rank_Γ_W(G)(W_1,W_2) = rank_G(W ∪ W_1, W ∪ W_2) - rank_G(W).

def: If $G$ is a graph, and $W_1,W_2 \subset V$ are two subsets of the vertices of $G$, then $\emph{rank}_G(W_1,W_2)$ denotes the rank of the submatrix of the adjacency matrix with rows $W_1$ and columns $W_2$. More intrinsically, this is the rank of the map $\langle W_1 \rangle \rightarrow \langle W_2 \rangle^\ast$ induced by $\cE$, where $\langle W_2 \rangle^*$ is the dual vector space of $\langle W_2 \rangle$.

More intrinsically, this is the rank of the map ⟨ W_1 ⟩→⟨ W_2 ⟩^∗ induced by , where ⟨ W_2 ⟩^* is the dual vector space of ⟨ W_2 ⟩.

More intrinsically, this is the rank of the map ⟨ W_1 ⟩→⟨ W_2 ⟩^∗ induced by , where ⟨ W_2 ⟩^* is the dual vector space of ⟨ W_2 ⟩.

plain_text_def:
Let A and B be finite subsets of abelian groups (not necessarily equal). We say that A and B are m-Freiman isomorphic if there exists a bijection f:A→ B such that 

    f(a_1)+f(a_2)…+f(a_m)   =    f(a_1')+f(a_2')…+f(a_m')
       ⇕   
    
    a_1+…+a_m   =   a_1'+…+a_m'.

Let A and B be finite subsets of abelian groups (not necessarily equal). We say that A and B are m-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM if there exists a bijection f:A→ B such that 

    f(a_1)+f(a_2)…+f(a_m)   =    f(a_1')+f(a_2')…+f(a_m')
       ⇕   
    
    a_1+…+a_m   =   a_1'+…+a_m'.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
Let $T_1$ be an unordered increasing tree with root vertex $a_1$, and let $v$ be any vertex in $T$ ($v$ can be equal to $a_1$). Suppose that the unique maximal
chain from $a_1$ to $v$ is given by $a_1<a_2<\cd <a_k=v$, $k\geq 1$. Now remove the edges on the chain in $T$ from $a_1$ to $a_k$. There are $k$ components in the resulting graph, each of which is an unordered increasing tree, whose root vertex is on the chain from $a_1$ to $a_k$. Let $T^{(a_i)}$ be the component among these that is rooted at vertex $a_i$, $i=1,\ldots ,k$. Then the $v$-\emph{decomposition} of $T$ is the ordered list $T^{(a_1)},\ldots ,T^{(a_k)}$.
plain_text_def:
Let T_1 be an unordered increasing tree with root vertex a_1, and let v be any vertex in T (v can be equal to a_1). Suppose that the unique maximal
chain from a_1 to v is given by a_1<a_2< <a_k=v, k≥ 1. Now remove the edges on the chain in T from a_1 to a_k. There are k components in the resulting graph, each of which is an unordered increasing tree, whose root vertex is on the chain from a_1 to a_k. Let T^(a_i) be the component among these that is rooted at vertex a_i, i=1,… ,k. Then the v-decomposition of T is the ordered list T^(a_1),… ,T^(a_k).
masked_plain_text_def:
Let T_1 be an unordered increasing tree with root vertex a_1, and let v be any vertex in T (v can be equal to a_1). Suppose that the unique maximal
chain from a_1 to v is given by a_1<a_2< <a_k=v, k≥ 1. Now remove the edges on the chain in T from a_1 to a_k. There are k components in the resulting graph, each of which is an unordered increasing tree, whose root vertex is on the chain from a_1 to a_k. Let T^(a_i) be the component among these that is rooted at vertex a_i, i=1,… ,k. Then the v-B_MATH_TERM of T is the ordered list T^(a_1),… ,T^(a_k).

plain_text_def:
Consider a π-increasing tree T, with (π-compatible) vertex-set =∪_i ∈ Iπ_i. For a vertex v in T, suppose that the v-decomposition of T is given by

    T^(a_1), ,T^(a_ℓ),

where a_ℓ=v. Then the v-dependence graph of T, denoted by vT, is a directed graph with the following vertices and directed edges:

    
  * the vertex-set of G_v(T) is {π_i, i∈ I};
    
  * for the directed edges of G_v(T), consider, if any, a maximum element μ_i, i∈ I, which is not contained in the
        chain a_1,⋯,a_ℓ of T. 
       This vertex belongs (as a nonroot vertex) to T^(a_j) for some j=1,… ,ℓ.
        Then there is a directed edge from π_i to π^a_j, for each such i∈ I.
masked_plain_text_def:
Consider a π-increasing tree T, with (π-compatible) vertex-set =∪_i ∈ Iπ_i. For a vertex v in T, suppose that the v-decomposition of T is given by

    T^(a_1), ,T^(a_ℓ),

where a_ℓ=v. Then the v-B_MATH_TERM graph of T, denoted by vT, is a directed graph with the following vertices and directed edges:

    
  * the vertex-set of G_v(T) is {π_i, i∈ I};
    
  * for the directed edges of G_v(T), consider, if any, a maximum element μ_i, i∈ I, which is not contained in the
        chain a_1,⋯,a_ℓ of T. 
       This vertex belongs (as a nonroot vertex) to T^(a_j) for some j=1,… ,ℓ.
        Then there is a directed edge from π_i to π^a_j, for each such i∈ I.

def:
%Let $G$ be a finite connected simple graph, and let $Z$ be a nonempty subset of $V(G)$.
A \emph{$Z$-oriented spanning forest} of $G$ is an oriented subgraph $F$ of $G$ such that
\begin{enumerate}
\item Every vertex in $Z$ has outdegree $0$ in $F$;
\item Every vertex in $G \setminus Z$ has outdegree 1 in $F$; and
\item $F$ contains no directed cycles. \qedhere
\end{enumerate}
%
%
%for any vertex $x$ not in $Z$, there exists a unique directed path in the  subgraph 
%that starts at $x$ and ends at $Z$.
plain_text_def:
A Z-oriented spanning forest of G is an oriented subgraph F of G such that


  * Every vertex in Z has outdegree 0 in F;

  * Every vertex in G ∖ Z has outdegree 1 in F; and

  * F contains no directed cycles.
masked_plain_text_def:
A Z-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM of G is an oriented subgraph F of G such that


  * Every vertex in Z has outdegree 0 in F;

  * Every vertex in G ∖ Z has outdegree 1 in F; and

  * F contains no directed cycles.

plain_text_def: The Z-oriented uniform spanning forest , denoted by (G,Z), is the uniform probability distribution on Z-oriented spanning forests of G.
masked_plain_text_def: The Z-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM , denoted by (G,Z), is the uniform probability distribution on Z-oriented spanning forests of G.

def:
The random tree $\mathcal{T}_n'$ described in  previous paragraph
will be called a $p$\emph{-biased recursive tree ($p$-BRT)} . When
$p$ is the uniform distribution over $[a]$, $a\geq 2$, we call
$\mathcal{T}_n'$ an $a$\emph{-recursive tree} ($a$-RT).
plain_text_def:
The random tree 𝒯_n' described in  previous paragraph
will be called a p-biased recursive tree (p-BRT) . When
p is the uniform distribution over [a], a≥ 2, we call
𝒯_n' an a-recursive tree (a-RT).

will be called a pB_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM . When
p is the uniform distribution over [a], a≥ 2, we call
𝒯_n' an aB_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM (a-RT).

def:
[Jumbledness for graphs]
 We say that $\Gamma=(V,E_\Gamma)$ is a $(p,\beta)$\emph{-jumbled graph} if, for all subsets $X$, 
$Y\subset V$, we have 
$\big|e_{\Gamma}(X,Y) - p|X||Y|\big|\leq 
\beta\sqrt{|X||Y|}$.
Furthermore, a bipartite graph $\Gamma_B=(U,V;E)$ is called  
$(p,\beta)$\emph{-jumbled} if, for all $X\subset U$ and 
$Y\subset V$, we have $|e_{\Gamma}(X,Y) - p|X||Y|\big|\leq \beta\sqrt{|X||Y|}$.
plain_text_def:
[Jumbledness for graphs]
 We say that Γ=(V,E_Γ) is a (p,β)-jumbled graph if, for all subsets X, 
Y⊂ V, we have 
|e_Γ(X,Y) - p|X||Y||≤β√(|X||Y|).
Furthermore, a bipartite graph Γ_B=(U,V;E) is called  
(p,β)-jumbled if, for all X⊂ U and 
Y⊂ V, we have |e_Γ(X,Y) - p|X||Y||≤β√(|X||Y|).
masked_plain_text_def:
[Jumbledness for graphs]
 We say that Γ=(V,E_Γ) is a (p,β)B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM if, for all subsets X, 
Y⊂ V, we have 
|e_Γ(X,Y) - p|X||Y||≤β√(|X||Y|).
Furthermore, a bipartite graph Γ_B=(U,V;E) is called  
(p,β)B_MATH_TERM if, for all X⊂ U and 
Y⊂ V, we have |e_Γ(X,Y) - p|X||Y||≤β√(|X||Y|).
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def: An $a$-\emph{core} is a partition that has no hook lengths of size $a$. An $(a,b)$-\emph{core} is a partition that is simultaneously an $a$-core and a $b$-core.  We use $\mathcal{C}_{a,b}$ to denote the set of $(a,b)$-cores.
plain_text_def: An a-core is a partition that has no hook lengths of size a. An (a,b)-core is a partition that is simultaneously an a-core and a b-core.  We use 𝒞_a,b to denote the set of (a,b)-cores.
masked_plain_text_def: An a-B_MATH_TERM is a partition that has no hook lengths of size a. An (a,b)-B_MATH_TERM is a partition that is simultaneously an a-core and a b-core.  We use 𝒞_a,b to denote the set of (a,b)-cores.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
[k-metric antidimension and k-antiresolving basis]
The k-metric antidimension of a simple connected graph G = (V, E) is the
minimum cardinality amongst the k-antiresolving sets in G and is denoted by _k(G). A k-antiresolving set of cardinality _k(G) is called a k-antiresolving basis for G.
masked_plain_text_def:
[k-metric antidimension and k-antiresolving basis]
The k-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM of a simple connected graph G = (V, E) is the
minimum cardinality amongst the k-antiresolving sets in G and is denoted by _k(G). A k-antiresolving set of cardinality _k(G) is called a k-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM for G.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O

def:
[$(k, \ell)$-anonymity]\label{def_graph_anonymity}
A graph $G$ meets $(k, \ell)$-\emph{anonymity} with respect
to active attacks if $k$ is the smallest positive integer such that the
$k$-metric antidimension of $G$ is lower than or equal to $\ell$.
plain_text_def:
[(k, ℓ)-anonymity]
A graph G meets (k, ℓ)-anonymity with respect
to active attacks if k is the smallest positive integer such that the
k-metric antidimension of G is lower than or equal to ℓ.
masked_plain_text_def:
[(k, ℓ)-anonymity]
A graph G meets (k, ℓ)-B_MATH_TERM with respect
to active attacks if k is the smallest positive integer such that the
k-metric antidimension of G is lower than or equal to ℓ.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
[$k$-metric antidimensional graph]
A simple connected graph $G = (V, E)$ is $k$-\emph{metric antidimensional} , if
$k$ is the largest integer such that $G$ contains a $k$-antiresolving set.
plain_text_def:
[k-metric antidimensional graph]
A simple connected graph G = (V, E) is k-metric antidimensional , if
k is the largest integer such that G contains a k-antiresolving set.
masked_plain_text_def:
[k-metric antidimensional graph]
A simple connected graph G = (V, E) is k-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM , if
k is the largest integer such that G contains a k-antiresolving set.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{main}
Let $n, k,$ be positive integers and $\vec{s}=(s_1, \ldots, s_k)$ be an integer vector where $k\geq 2$, $n\geq\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}s_i+2$, $s_i\geq2$ for $i\neq k$ and $s_k\in\{1,2\}$. Then, the neighborhood complex of $KG(n, k)_{\vec{s}-\textit{stab}}$ is homotopy equivalent to the $\left(n-\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}s_i-2\right)$-sphere.
plain_text_def: Let n, k, be positive integers and s⃗=(s_1, …, s_k) be an integer vector where k≥ 2, n≥∑_i=1^k-1s_i+2, s_i≥2 for i≠ k and s_k∈{1,2}. Then, the neighborhood complex of KG(n, k)_s⃗-stab is homotopy equivalent to the (n-∑_i=1^k-1s_i-2)-sphere.
masked_plain_text_def: Let n, k, be positive integers and s⃗=(s_1, …, s_k) be an integer vector where k≥ 2, n≥∑_i=1^k-1s_i+2, s_i≥2 for i≠ k and s_k∈{1,2}. Then, the neighborhood complex of KG(n, k)_s⃗-B_MATH_TERM is homotopy equivalent to the (n-∑_i=1^k-1s_i-2)-sphere.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{chromaticnumber}
Let $n, k,$ be positive integers and $\vec{s}=(s_1, \ldots, s_k)$ be an integer vector where $k\geq 2$, $n\geq\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}s_i+2$, $s_i\geq2$ for $i\neq k$ and $s_k\in\{1,2\}$. Then
	\[
	\chi\left({KG(n, k)}_{\vec{s}-\textit{stab}}\right)= n-\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}s_i.
	\]
plain_text_def:
Let n, k, be positive integers and s⃗=(s_1, …, s_k) be an integer vector where k≥ 2, n≥∑_i=1^k-1s_i+2, s_i≥2 for i≠ k and s_k∈{1,2}. Then
	
    χ(KG(n, k)_s⃗-stab)= n-∑_i=1^k-1s_i.

    χ(KG(n, k)_s⃗-B_MATH_TERM)= n-∑_i=1^k-1s_i.

plain_text_def:
[polylogarithmic bilinear Bogolyubov]

For any δ, if P_h≥δ q^2k+2,
then there exist _p-subspaces W_1,W_2 of the _p-vector space G_k+1 of codimension
r_1,r_2 and
_p-bilinear forms Q_1,…,Q_r on W_1× W_2
such that
P_2^9h={(a,b)∈ G_k+1^2|rk M_a,b≤ 2^9 h} contains the set

    {(x,y)∈ W_1× W_2| Q_1(x,y)=⋯=Q_r(x,y)=0}

and
max(r,r_1,r_2)≤ O(log^80δ^-1).

def:
The \emph{L{\'e}vy concentration function} of $S$ is defined as
	$$
	\mathcal{L}(S, \eps) := \sup_{v \in \R} \P(|S-v| \leq \eps ) .
	$$
plain_text_def:
The Lévy concentration function of S is defined as
	
    ℒ(S, ) := sup_v ∈(|S-v| ≤ ) .

def:
For $\delta>0$, we call a path $P=v_1,v_2,\dots,v_m$ in $G$ a $\delta$-\emph{exploding path}
if $v_m\in \core(G)$ and $t_{v_{i+1}}\geq (1+\delta)t_{v_i}$ for $1\leq i\leq m-2$.
plain_text_def:
For δ>0, we call a path P=v_1,v_2,…,v_m in G a δ-exploding path
if v_m∈(G) and t_v_i+1≥ (1+δ)t_v_i for 1≤ i≤ m-2.
masked_plain_text_def:
For δ>0, we call a path P=v_1,v_2,…,v_m in G a δ-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM
if v_m∈(G) and t_v_i+1≥ (1+δ)t_v_i for 1≤ i≤ m-2.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

def:
Let $r$ and $\ell$ be non-negative integers. A code
$C\subseteq \F^n$ is said to be $(r,\le \ell)$-\emph{identifying}
if for all $X,Y\subseteq \F^n$ such that $|X|\le \ell$, $|Y|\le
\ell$ and $X\ne Y$ we have
$$I_r(C;X)\ne I_r(C;Y).$$
plain_text_def:
Let r and ℓ be non-negative integers. A code
C⊆^n is said to be (r,≤ℓ)-identifying
if for all X,Y⊆^n such that |X|≤ℓ, |Y|≤ℓ and X Y we have

    I_r(C;X) I_r(C;Y).
masked_plain_text_def:
Let r and ℓ be non-negative integers. A code
C⊆^n is said to be (r,≤ℓ)-B_MATH_TERM
if for all X,Y⊆^n such that |X|≤ℓ, |Y|≤ℓ and X Y we have

    I_r(C;X) I_r(C;Y).
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\cite{erdossim1975}\label{antiramsey for Kp}
For any $p\geq2$ and all sufficiently large $n$, $n\geq n_0(p)$, we have
$$
\emph{AR}(n,K_{p+2})=t(n,p)+1,
$$
and any coloring achieving this bound is obtained by taking a rainbow $T(n,p)$ and coloring all edges in its complement with the same (extra) color.
plain_text_def:
<cit.>
For any p≥2 and all sufficiently large n, n≥ n_0(p), we have

    AR(n,K_p+2)=t(n,p)+1,

and any coloring achieving this bound is obtained by taking a rainbow T(n,p) and coloring all edges in its complement with the same (extra) color.

def:
\label{main1}
Let $\mathcal{F}$ be a family of graphs with $\mathcal{F}^{-}=\{H-e:H\in \mathcal{F}, e\in E(H)\}$ and $p(\mathcal{F}^{-})=p\geq 2$. Let $\mathcal{M}_0(\mathcal{F}),\ldots,\mathcal{M}_p(\mathcal{F})$ be the decomposition family sequence of $\mathcal{F}$.\\
(\romannumeral1) If $\mathcal{M}_0(\mathcal{F})=\{M_{2k}\}$ ($k\geq2$), then $$\emph{AR}(n,\mathcal{F})=h^\prime(n,p,k-1)+q$$
provided $n$ is sufficiently large, where $q$ is the maximum number of colors such that the coloring of $K_n$, obtained by taking a rainbow $H^\prime(n,p,k-1)$, and coloring all edges in its complement with $q$ (extra) colors so that in each partite set of $T(n-k+2,p)$ we color all edges with the same color, is an $\mathcal{F}$-free coloring.\\
(\romannumeral2) If $\mathcal{M}_0(\mathcal{F})=\{M_2\}$, $\mathcal{M}_1(\mathcal{F})=\{M_{2k-2}\}$ ($k\geq2$), then $$\emph{AR}(n,\mathcal{F})=h(n,p,k-1)+1$$
provided $n$ is sufficiently large.
Moreover, any coloring achieving this bound is obtained by taking a rainbow $H(n,p,k-1)$, and coloring all edges in its complement with one (extra) color.
plain_text_def:
Let ℱ be a family of graphs with ℱ^-={H-e:H∈ℱ, e∈ E(H)} and p(ℱ^-)=p≥ 2. Let ℳ_0(ℱ),…,ℳ_p(ℱ) be the decomposition family sequence of ℱ.

(1) If ℳ_0(ℱ)={M_2k} (k≥2), then 
    AR(n,ℱ)=h^'(n,p,k-1)+q

provided n is sufficiently large, where q is the maximum number of colors such that the coloring of K_n, obtained by taking a rainbow H^'(n,p,k-1), and coloring all edges in its complement with q (extra) colors so that in each partite set of T(n-k+2,p) we color all edges with the same color, is an ℱ-free coloring.

(2) If ℳ_0(ℱ)={M_2}, ℳ_1(ℱ)={M_2k-2} (k≥2), then 
    AR(n,ℱ)=h(n,p,k-1)+1

provided n is sufficiently large.
Moreover, any coloring achieving this bound is obtained by taking a rainbow H(n,p,k-1), and coloring all edges in its complement with one (extra) color.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let ℱ be a family of graphs with ℱ^-={H-e:H∈ℱ, e∈ E(H)} and p(ℱ^-)=p≥ 2. Let ℳ_0(ℱ),…,ℳ_p(ℱ) be the decomposition family sequence of ℱ.

(1) If ℳ_0(ℱ)={M_2k} (k≥2), then 
    B_MATH_TERM(n,ℱ)=h^'(n,p,k-1)+q

provided n is sufficiently large, where q is the maximum number of colors such that the coloring of K_n, obtained by taking a rainbow H^'(n,p,k-1), and coloring all edges in its complement with q (extra) colors so that in each partite set of T(n-k+2,p) we color all edges with the same color, is an ℱ-free coloring.

(2) If ℳ_0(ℱ)={M_2}, ℳ_1(ℱ)={M_2k-2} (k≥2), then 
    B_MATH_TERM(n,ℱ)=h(n,p,k-1)+1

provided n is sufficiently large.
Moreover, any coloring achieving this bound is obtained by taking a rainbow H(n,p,k-1), and coloring all edges in its complement with one (extra) color.

def:
\label{main2}
Let $\mathcal{F}$ be a family of graphs with $\mathcal{F}^{-}=\{H-e:H\in \mathcal{F}, e\in E(H)\}$ and $p(\mathcal{F}^{-})=p\geq 2$. Let $\mathcal{M}_0(\mathcal{F}),\ldots,\mathcal{M}_p(\mathcal{F})$ be the decomposition family sequence of $\mathcal{F}$.\\
(\romannumeral1) Let $k\geq 2$. If $\mathcal{M}_0(\mathcal{F})=\{S_{k+1}\}$ and any graph in $\mathcal{F}_0$ contains $Q(p,k)$ as a subgraph, then $$\emph{AR}(n,\mathcal{F})=t(n,p)+\left\lfloor\frac{(k-2)\lceil\frac{n}{p}\rceil}{2}\right\rfloor+\ldots+\left\lfloor\frac{(k-2)\lfloor\frac{n}{p}\rfloor}{2}\right\rfloor+p$$
provided $n$ is sufficiently large. Furthermore, the colorings in $\mathcal{C}^\prime(n,k-1,p)$ are extremal colorings, and all extremal colorings are in $\mathcal{C}(n,k-1,p)$.\\
(\romannumeral2) Let $k\geq 3$. If $\mathcal{M}_0(\mathcal{F})=\{M_2\}$, $\mathcal{M}_1(\mathcal{F})=\{S_{k+1}\}$ and any graph in $\mathcal{F}_1$ contains $Q(p,k)$ as a subgraph, then
$$\emph{AR}(n,\mathcal{F})=t(n,p)+\left\lfloor\frac{(k-2)\lceil\frac{n}{p}\rceil}{2}\right\rfloor+\ldots+\left\lfloor\frac{(k-2)\lfloor\frac{n}{p}\rfloor}{2}\right\rfloor+p .$$
provided $n$ is sufficiently large. Furthermore, the coloring in $\mathcal{C}^\prime(n,k-1,p)$ are extremal colorings, and all extremal colorings are in $\mathcal{C}(n,k-1,p)$ and except the extremal colorings which is obtained by taking a rainbow graph from  $T(n,2;\mathcal{U}_{n/2,3})$ and coloring all edges in its complement with one (extra) color, when $k=3$, $p=2$ and $n=2$ mod $4$.
plain_text_def:
Let ℱ be a family of graphs with ℱ^-={H-e:H∈ℱ, e∈ E(H)} and p(ℱ^-)=p≥ 2. Let ℳ_0(ℱ),…,ℳ_p(ℱ) be the decomposition family sequence of ℱ.

(1) Let k≥ 2. If ℳ_0(ℱ)={S_k+1} and any graph in ℱ_0 contains Q(p,k) as a subgraph, then 
    AR(n,ℱ)=t(n,p)+⌊(k-2)⌈n/p⌉/2⌋+…+⌊(k-2)⌊n/p⌋/2⌋+p

provided n is sufficiently large. Furthermore, the colorings in 𝒞^'(n,k-1,p) are extremal colorings, and all extremal colorings are in 𝒞(n,k-1,p).

(2) Let k≥ 3. If ℳ_0(ℱ)={M_2}, ℳ_1(ℱ)={S_k+1} and any graph in ℱ_1 contains Q(p,k) as a subgraph, then

    AR(n,ℱ)=t(n,p)+⌊(k-2)⌈n/p⌉/2⌋+…+⌊(k-2)⌊n/p⌋/2⌋+p .

provided n is sufficiently large. Furthermore, the coloring in 𝒞^'(n,k-1,p) are extremal colorings, and all extremal colorings are in 𝒞(n,k-1,p) and except the extremal colorings which is obtained by taking a rainbow graph from  T(n,2;𝒰_n/2,3) and coloring all edges in its complement with one (extra) color, when k=3, p=2 and n=2 mod 4.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let ℱ be a family of graphs with ℱ^-={H-e:H∈ℱ, e∈ E(H)} and p(ℱ^-)=p≥ 2. Let ℳ_0(ℱ),…,ℳ_p(ℱ) be the decomposition family sequence of ℱ.

(1) Let k≥ 2. If ℳ_0(ℱ)={S_k+1} and any graph in ℱ_0 contains Q(p,k) as a subgraph, then 
    B_MATH_TERM(n,ℱ)=t(n,p)+⌊(k-2)⌈n/p⌉/2⌋+…+⌊(k-2)⌊n/p⌋/2⌋+p

provided n is sufficiently large. Furthermore, the colorings in 𝒞^'(n,k-1,p) are extremal colorings, and all extremal colorings are in 𝒞(n,k-1,p).

(2) Let k≥ 3. If ℳ_0(ℱ)={M_2}, ℳ_1(ℱ)={S_k+1} and any graph in ℱ_1 contains Q(p,k) as a subgraph, then

    B_MATH_TERM(n,ℱ)=t(n,p)+⌊(k-2)⌈n/p⌉/2⌋+…+⌊(k-2)⌊n/p⌋/2⌋+p .

provided n is sufficiently large. Furthermore, the coloring in 𝒞^'(n,k-1,p) are extremal colorings, and all extremal colorings are in 𝒞(n,k-1,p) and except the extremal colorings which is obtained by taking a rainbow graph from  T(n,2;𝒰_n/2,3) and coloring all edges in its complement with one (extra) color, when k=3, p=2 and n=2 mod 4.

def: Let $\mathcal{L}_d = \frac{1}{d} \mathbb{Z} \times \frac{1}{d} \mathbb{Z}$. A triangle $T$ is said to be $d$\emph{-minimal} if $T \cap \mathcal{L}_d$ consists precisely of the vertices of $T$.

def:
\label{qcodegree} Let $P\subset\real^n$ be an $n$-dimensional
lattice polytope. The  $\rat$-\emph{codegree} of $P$ is defined as $$
\textstyle\codeg_\rat(P):=\inf_{\rat}\{ \frac{a}{b}\, |\,
(aP)^{(b)}\neq\emptyset\}.$$

Let P⊂^n be an n-dimensional
lattice polytope. The  -codegree of P is defined as 
    _(P):=inf_{a/b  | 
    (aP)^(b)≠∅}.

Let P⊂^n be an n-dimensional
lattice polytope. The  -B_MATH_TERM of P is defined as 
    _(P):=inf_{a/b  | 
    (aP)^(b)≠∅}.

def:
\label{lem_equiv}
Let $\Delta, \Delta'$ be two-dimensional lattice polygons with
\[ \sharp (\Delta \cap \mathbb{Z}^2) - 1 =
\sharp (\Delta' \cap \mathbb{Z}^2) - 1 = N,\]
and suppose that $\emph{Tor}(\Delta) , \emph{Tor}(\Delta') \subset \mathbb{P}^N$
can be obtained from one another using a projective transformation.
Then $\Delta \cong \Delta'$.
plain_text_def:
Let Δ, Δ' be two-dimensional lattice polygons with

    ♯ (Δ∩ℤ^2) - 1 =
    ♯ (Δ' ∩ℤ^2) - 1 = N,

and suppose that Tor(Δ) , Tor(Δ') ⊂ℙ^N
can be obtained from one another using a projective transformation.
Then Δ≅Δ'.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let Δ, Δ' be two-dimensional lattice polygons with

    ♯ (Δ∩ℤ^2) - 1 =
    ♯ (Δ' ∩ℤ^2) - 1 = N,

and suppose that B_MATH_TERM(Δ) , B_MATH_TERM(Δ') ⊂ℙ^N
can be obtained from one another using a projective transformation.
Then Δ≅Δ'.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{theorem_schreyer}
Let $f \in k[x^{\pm 1}, y^{\pm 1}]$ be non-degenerate with respect to its Newton polygon
$\Delta = \Delta(f)$, and suppose that $C_f$ is tetragonal.
Then its invariants $b_1,b_2$ statisfy $\{b_1,b_2\}=\{B,B^{(1)}\}$.
If moreover $B > B^{(1)}$ then the surface $\mu(Y)$ associated to
the canonical model $C_f^\emph{can}$ from Section~\ref{introsection} equals $\emph{Tor}(\Delta^{(1)})$.
plain_text_def:
Let f ∈ k[x^± 1, y^± 1] be non-degenerate with respect to its Newton polygon
Δ = Δ(f), and suppose that C_f is tetragonal.
Then its invariants b_1,b_2 statisfy {b_1,b_2}={B,B^(1)}.
If moreover B > B^(1) then the surface μ(Y) associated to
the canonical model C_f^can from Section <ref> equals Tor(Δ^(1)).
masked_plain_text_def:
Let f ∈ k[x^± 1, y^± 1] be non-degenerate with respect to its Newton polygon
Δ = Δ(f), and suppose that C_f is tetragonal.
Then its invariants b_1,b_2 statisfy {b_1,b_2}={B,B^(1)}.
If moreover B > B^(1) then the surface μ(Y) associated to
the canonical model C_f^B_MATH_TERM from Section <ref> equals B_MATH_TERM(Δ^(1)).
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{thm_intrinsicness}
Let $\Delta, \Delta'$ be two-dimensional lattice polygons and let there be a curve that is both $\Delta$-non-degenerate
and $\Delta'$-non-degenerate. Suppose that $\emph{lw}(\Delta^{(1)}) = 2$ and define $g = \sharp (\Delta^{(1)} \cap \mathbb{Z}^2) = \sharp (\Delta'^{(1)} \cap \mathbb{Z}^2)$. 
%Assume that $g \geq 4$.
\begin{itemize}
  \item Case $g \equiv 0 \bmod 4$. If $\Delta^{(1)}, \Delta'^{(1)} \not \cong \Gamma_g$ then $\Delta^{(1)} \cong \Delta'^{(1)}$.
  This is automatic if $\sharp (\partial \Delta^{(1)} \cap \mathbb{Z}^2) \geq \sharp (\Delta^{(2)} \cap \mathbb{Z}^2) + 5$.  
  \item Case $g \equiv 1 \bmod 4$. If $\Delta^{(1)}, \Delta'^{(1)} \not \cong \Gamma_g^m$ for all $1 \leq m \leq (g+3)/4$ then
   $\Delta^{(1)} \cong \Delta'^{(1)}$. This is automatic if $\sharp (\partial \Delta^{(1)} \cap \mathbb{Z}^2) \geq \sharp (\Delta^{(2)} \cap \mathbb{Z}^2) + 4$.
  \item Cases $g \equiv 2, 3 \bmod 4$. Here one always has $\Delta^{(1)} \cong \Delta'^{(1)}$.
\end{itemize}
plain_text_def:
Let Δ, Δ' be two-dimensional lattice polygons and let there be a curve that is both Δ-non-degenerate
and Δ'-non-degenerate. Suppose that lw(Δ^(1)) = 2 and define g = ♯ (Δ^(1)∩ℤ^2) = ♯ (Δ'^(1)∩ℤ^2). 


  
  * Case g ≡ 0  4. If Δ^(1), Δ'^(1)≇Γ_g then Δ^(1)≅Δ'^(1).
  This is automatic if ♯ (∂Δ^(1)∩ℤ^2) ≥♯ (Δ^(2)∩ℤ^2) + 5.  
  
  * Case g ≡ 1  4. If Δ^(1), Δ'^(1)≇Γ_g^m for all 1 ≤ m ≤ (g+3)/4 then
   Δ^(1)≅Δ'^(1). This is automatic if ♯ (∂Δ^(1)∩ℤ^2) ≥♯ (Δ^(2)∩ℤ^2) + 4.
  
  * Cases g ≡ 2, 3  4. Here one always has Δ^(1)≅Δ'^(1).
masked_plain_text_def:
Let Δ, Δ' be two-dimensional lattice polygons and let there be a curve that is both Δ-non-degenerate
and Δ'-non-degenerate. Suppose that B_MATH_TERM(Δ^(1)) = 2 and define g = ♯ (Δ^(1)∩ℤ^2) = ♯ (Δ'^(1)∩ℤ^2). 


  
  * Case g ≡ 0  4. If Δ^(1), Δ'^(1)≇Γ_g then Δ^(1)≅Δ'^(1).
  This is automatic if ♯ (∂Δ^(1)∩ℤ^2) ≥♯ (Δ^(2)∩ℤ^2) + 5.  
  
  * Case g ≡ 1  4. If Δ^(1), Δ'^(1)≇Γ_g^m for all 1 ≤ m ≤ (g+3)/4 then
   Δ^(1)≅Δ'^(1). This is automatic if ♯ (∂Δ^(1)∩ℤ^2) ≥♯ (Δ^(2)∩ℤ^2) + 4.
  
  * Cases g ≡ 2, 3  4. Here one always has Δ^(1)≅Δ'^(1).

def:
\label{def:normal}
Let~$F$,~$B$ be graphs and let $\alpha>0$.
We call a family $\Xi_{B,n}\subseteq \Psi_{B,n}$ of embeddings of~$B$ into~$K_n$ $\alpha$-\textit{normal} if the following conditions are satisfied.
\begin{enumerate}[label=\Nlabel]
\item\label{it:normal1} $\vert \Xi_{B,n}\vert \geq \alpha n^2$ and
\item\label{it:normal2} $\vert V(h(B))\cap V(h^\prime(B))\vert \leq 1$ for all $h\neq h^\prime\in \Xi_{B,n}$.
\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
Let F, B be graphs and let α>0.
We call a family Ξ_B,n⊆Ψ_B,n of embeddings of B into K_n α-normal if the following conditions are satisfied.


  *  |Ξ_B,n|≥α n^2 and

  *  | V(h(B))∩ V(h^'(B))|≤ 1 for all h≠ h^'∈Ξ_B,n.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let F, B be graphs and let α>0.
We call a family Ξ_B,n⊆Ψ_B,n of embeddings of B into K_n α-B_MATH_TERM if the following conditions are satisfied.


  *  |Ξ_B,n|≥α n^2 and

  *  | V(h(B))∩ V(h^'(B))|≤ 1 for all h≠ h^'∈Ξ_B,n.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def: Let $K \geq 1$.  A multiplicative set $(A,G)$ is said to be \emph{$K$-controlled} by another multiplicative set $(B,G')$ if $G'$ is a subgroup of $G$, if $|B| \leq K |A|$, and there exists another finite non-empty subset $X$ of $G$ with $|X| \leq K$ such that $A \subset (X \cdot B) \cap (B \cdot X)$.
plain_text_def: Let K ≥ 1.  A multiplicative set (A,G) is said to be K-controlled by another multiplicative set (B,G') if G' is a subgroup of G, if |B| ≤ K |A|, and there exists another finite non-empty subset X of G with |X| ≤ K such that A ⊂ (X · B) ∩ (B · X).
masked_plain_text_def: Let K ≥ 1.  A multiplicative set (A,G) is said to be B_MATH_TERMled by another multiplicative set (B,G') if G' is a subgroup of G, if |B| ≤ K |A|, and there exists another finite non-empty subset X of G with |X| ≤ K such that A ⊂ (X · B) ∩ (B · X).
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{def reversible}
Let $G$ be a group and fix a generating set $X$. Let $w$ be a word in the alphabet $X \cup X^{-1}$.  Denote by $|w|$ the corresponding group element. Define $\overline{w}$ as the word obtained by reversing the word $w$.  We say that a group is $X$-\textit{reversible} iff it satisfies the property 
\[
|\overline{w_1}| = |\overline{w_2}| \Leftrightarrow |w_1| = |w_2|
\] 
for all words $w_1,w_2$.
plain_text_def:
Let G be a group and fix a generating set X. Let w be a word in the alphabet X ∪ X^-1.  Denote by |w| the corresponding group element. Define w as the word obtained by reversing the word w.  We say that a group is X-reversible iff it satisfies the property 

    |w_1| = |w_2| ⇔ |w_1| = |w_2|
 
for all words w_1,w_2.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let G be a group and fix a generating set X. Let w be a word in the alphabet X ∪ X^-1.  Denote by |w| the corresponding group element. Define w as the word obtained by reversing the word w.  We say that a group is X-B_MATH_TERM iff it satisfies the property 

    |w_1| = |w_2| ⇔ |w_1| = |w_2|
 
for all words w_1,w_2.

def:
Let $r$ be a non-negative integer and let $W=(w_j)_{j\in[-r,r]^n}$ be an $n$-dimensional array of integers of size $(2r+1)^{n}$. The \textit{additive cellular automaton} (ACA for short) over $\ZZ{m}$ associated with $W$ is the map $\partial$ which assigns, to every $n$-dimensional infinite array of $\ZZ{m}$, a new array by a linear transformation whose coefficients are those of $W$. More precisely, the map $\partial$ is defined by
$$
\partial\left( (a_i)_{i\in\Z^n} \right) = \left(\sum_{j\in[-r,r]^n}{w_ja_{i+j}}\right)_{i\in\Z^n},
$$
for all arrays $(a_i)_{i\in\Z^n}$ of elements in $\ZZ{m}$. We say that $\partial$ is of \textit{dimension} $n\ge1$ and of \textit{weight} $W$ with \textit{radius} $r\ge0$.
plain_text_def:
Let r be a non-negative integer and let W=(w_j)_j∈[-r,r]^n be an n-dimensional array of integers of size (2r+1)^n. The additive cellular automaton (ACA for short) over m associated with W is the map ∂ which assigns, to every n-dimensional infinite array of m, a new array by a linear transformation whose coefficients are those of W. More precisely, the map ∂ is defined by

    ∂( (a_i)_i∈^n) = (∑_j∈[-r,r]^nw_ja_i+j)_i∈^n,

for all arrays (a_i)_i∈^n of elements in m. We say that ∂ is of dimension n≥1 and of weight W with radius r≥0.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let r be a non-negative integer and let W=(w_j)_j∈[-r,r]^n be an n-dimensional array of integers of size (2r+1)^n. The additive cellular automaton (B_MATH_TERM for short) over m associated with W is the map ∂ which assigns, to every n-dimensional infinite array of m, a new array by a linear transformation whose coefficients are those of W. More precisely, the map ∂ is defined by

    ∂( (a_i)_i∈^n) = (∑_j∈[-r,r]^nw_ja_i+j)_i∈^n,

for all arrays (a_i)_i∈^n of elements in m. We say that ∂ is of dimension n≥1 and of weight W with radius r≥0.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
Let $\mathbf{x}$ be an infinite word. The $k$-binomial complexity function of $\mathbf{x}$ is defined as
$$b_{\mathbf{x},k}:\mathbb{N}\to\mathbb{N},\ n\mapsto \# \left( \Fac_n(\mathbf{x})/\!\sim_k\right)$$
where $\Fac_n(\textbf{x})$ is the set of factors of length $n$ occurring in $\textbf{x}$.
plain_text_def:
Let 𝐱 be an infinite word. The k-binomial complexity function of 𝐱 is defined as

    b_𝐱,k:ℕ→ℕ, n↦#( _n(𝐱)/∼_k)

where _n(x) is the set of factors of length n occurring in x.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let 𝐱 be an infinite word. The k-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM function of 𝐱 is defined as

    b_𝐱,k:ℕ→ℕ, n↦#( _n(𝐱)/∼_k)

where _n(x) is the set of factors of length n occurring in x.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
Let $L$ be a subset of $\N$, $i\in\N$ and $k\in\N\setminus\{0\}$.
The sets
$$
L-i = \{x\in\N \mid x+i\in L\}
\ , \
L\div k = \{x\in\N \mid kx \in L\}
\ , \
\sqrt[k]{L} = \{x\in\N \mid x^k\in L\}
$$
are respectively called the $i$-\emph{decrement} ,
$k$-\emph{quotient} and $k$-\emph{root} of $L$.
Observe that the $i$-decrement is defined as a subset of $\N$,
excluding negative integers.

Let ${\+D}(L)$ denote the family $\{L-i \mid i\in\N\}$
of decrements of $L$.
plain_text_def:
Let L be a subset of , i∈ and k∈∖{0}.
The sets

    L-i = {x∈| x+i∈ L} , L÷ k = {x∈| kx ∈ L} , √(L) = {x∈| x^k∈ L}

are respectively called the i-decrement ,
k-quotient and k-root of L.
Observe that the i-decrement is defined as a subset of ,
excluding negative integers.

Let D(L) denote the family {L-i | i∈}
of decrements of L.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let L be a subset of , i∈ and k∈∖{0}.
The sets

    L-i = {x∈| x+i∈ L} , L÷ k = {x∈| kx ∈ L} , √(L) = {x∈| x^k∈ L}

are respectively called the i-B_MATH_TERM ,
k-B_MATH_TERM and k-B_MATH_TERM of L.
Observe that the i-decrement is defined as a subset of ,
excluding negative integers.

Let D(L) denote the family {L-i | i∈}
of decrements of L.

def:
\label{def:countingthin}
Let $\alpha \geq 0$ and $0 < K < \infty$.  A (possibly finite) set $E \subseteq \Z^d$ is $(K,\alpha)$\emph{-counting bounded} if for all cubes $C \subseteq \R^d$ with $\|C\| \geq 1$, $|E \cap C| \leq K \|C\|^\alpha$.
plain_text_def: Let α≥ 0 and 0 < K < ∞.  A (possibly finite) set E ⊆^d is (K,α)-counting bounded if for all cubes C ⊆^d with C≥ 1, |E ∩ C| ≤ K C^α.
masked_plain_text_def: Let α≥ 0 and 0 < K < ∞.  A (possibly finite) set E ⊆^d is (K,α)B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM if for all cubes C ⊆^d with C≥ 1, |E ∩ C| ≤ K C^α.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{def:massthin}
Let $\alpha \geq 0$ and $0 < K < \infty$.  A (possibly finite) set $E \subseteq \Z^d$ is $(K,\alpha)$-\emph{mass bounded} if for all centered cubes $C \subseteq \R^d$ with $\|C\| \geq 1$, $|E \cap C| \leq K \|C\|^\alpha$.
plain_text_def: Let α≥ 0 and 0 < K < ∞.  A (possibly finite) set E ⊆^d is (K,α)-mass bounded if for all centered cubes C ⊆^d with C≥ 1, |E ∩ C| ≤ K C^α.
masked_plain_text_def: Let α≥ 0 and 0 < K < ∞.  A (possibly finite) set E ⊆^d is (K,α)-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM if for all centered cubes C ⊆^d with C≥ 1, |E ∩ C| ≤ K C^α.

plain_text_def:
[cf. <cit.>]
Let N =(B,E, 𝗉𝗋𝖾,𝗉𝗈𝗌𝗍), N' =(B',E', 𝗉𝗋𝖾',𝗉𝗈𝗌𝗍') be Petri nets. A morphism (β,η):N → N' consists of a relation β⊆ B × B', such that β^op (=opposite to β) is a partial function B' → B, and a partial function η:E → E' such that β (^∙ e) = ^∙η(e), and β(e^∙) = η(e)^∙. On the other hand, the diagrams

    E_* @->[r]^𝗉𝗋𝖾@->[d]_η_*    2^B @->[d]^2^β
    
      E_*' @->[r]_𝗉𝗋𝖾'    2^B'    
      E_* @->[r]^𝗉𝗈𝗌𝗍@->[d]_η_*    2^B @->[d]^2^β
    
      E_*' @->[r]_𝗉𝗈𝗌𝗍'    2^B'

are commutative.
masked_plain_text_def:
[B_MATH_TERM <cit.>]
Let N =(B,E, 𝗉𝗋𝖾,𝗉𝗈𝗌𝗍), N' =(B',E', 𝗉𝗋𝖾',𝗉𝗈𝗌𝗍') be Petri nets. A morphism (β,η):N → N' consists of a relation β⊆ B × B', such that β^op (=opposite to β) is a partial function B' → B, and a partial function η:E → E' such that β (^∙ e) = ^∙η(e), and β(e^∙) = η(e)^∙. On the other hand, the diagrams

    E_* @->[r]^𝗉𝗋𝖾@->[d]_η_*    2^B @->[d]^2^β
    
      E_*' @->[r]_𝗉𝗋𝖾'    2^B'    
      E_* @->[r]^𝗉𝗈𝗌𝗍@->[d]_η_*    2^B @->[d]^2^β
    
      E_*' @->[r]_𝗉𝗈𝗌𝗍'    2^B'

are commutative.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
Let e=uv be an edge of a graph G. The e-critical packing of G-e, denoted by P_e(G), is a maximum packing of the graph G-e with the following property.

    If |{ u, v }∩ P_e(G) | < 2,  then  P_e(G)  is a packing of  G.

def: A word $w$ is {\bf complete} for a finite set $S$ (or $S$-complete) if it contains, as subsequence, all the permutations of $S$. An \BF{$n$-complete word} is a $[n]$-complete word. The length of a shortest $n$-complete word is denoted $\lambda(n)$.

def:
\label{newdeltaclose} Let $G=(V,c)$ and $G=(V,c')$ be finite $C$-graphs where $C=[r]$ or $C=2^{[r]}$. Set
$$
\Delta(G,G')=\{xy\in {V\choose 2}: c(xy)\neq c'(xy)\}.
$$
Given $\delta>0$, we say $G$ and $G'$ are \emph{$\delta$-close}\footnote{In \cite{MT}, $\delta$-closeness is instead defines as $|\Delta(G,G')|\leq \delta n^2$.  For large $n$, this is basically the same as Definition \ref{newdeltaclose} up to a factor of $2$, and therefore doesn't change the statements of the results from \cite{MT}.  We have chosen to use Definition \ref{newdeltaclose} for convenience.} if $|\Delta(G,G')|\leq \delta{|V|\choose 2}$.

    Δ(G,G')={xy∈V 2: c(xy)≠ c'(xy)}.

For large n, this is basically the same as Definition <ref> up to a factor of 2, and therefore doesn't change the statements of the results from <cit.>.  We have chosen to use Definition <ref> for convenience.] if |Δ(G,G')|≤δ|V| 2.

def:
\label{deltaclosedg}
Given two digraphs $G=(V,E)$ and $G'=(V,E)$, let $\Delta(G,G')= E\Delta E'$.  Given $\delta>0$, we say $G$ and $G'$ are \emph{$\delta$-close}\footnote{Given $G$ and $G'$ two digraphs with the same vertex set of size $n$, write $G=G'\pm \delta n^2$ to denote that $G$ can be obtained from $G'$ by adding or removing at most $\beta n^2$ directed edges.  In \cite{OKTZ}, the authors deal with the notion of $\delta$-closeness given by $G=G'\pm \delta n^2$.  For large $n$, this is essentially interchangable (up to a factor of $2$) with Definition \ref{deltaclosedg}.  For convenience we will state their results using the notion in Definition \ref{deltaclosedg}.} if $|\Delta(G,G')|\leq \delta {n\choose 2}$.

In <cit.>, the authors deal with the notion of δ-closeness given by G=G'±δ n^2.  For large n, this is essentially interchangable (up to a factor of 2) with Definition <ref>.  For convenience we will state their results using the notion in Definition <ref>.] if |Δ(G,G')|≤δn 2.

def: A family ${\mathcal A} \subset {\mathcal P}[n]$ satisfies an $x_{ij}$-\emph{pairwise restriction} between layers $i$ and $j$ of the cube if $|A\setminus B| \neq x_{ij}$ for all $A\in {\mathcal A}^{(i)}$ and $B \in {\mathcal A}^{(j)}$.

def:
[Section 4 of \cite{W}]
Let $f=\sum_{S\subseteq[m]} c(S) \x^S$ be multiaffine with real nonnegative
coefficients, and assume that $f$ is Rayleigh.\\
\textup{(a)}\ The support $\supp(f)$ is a convex delta-matroid.\\
\textup{(b)}\ The coefficients are \emph{log-submodular}:\ for all
$A,B\subseteq[m]$,
$$
c(A\cap B) c(A\cup B) \leq c(A) c(B).
$$

[Section 4 of <cit.>]
Let f=∑_S⊆[m] c(S) ^S be multiaffine with real nonnegative
coefficients, and assume that f is Rayleigh.

 The support (f) is a convex delta-matroid.

 The coefficients are log-submodular: for all
A,B⊆[m],

    c(A∩ B) c(A∪ B) ≤ c(A) c(B).

def: Let $G$ be a group of order $v$, written multiplicatively, and let $D$ be a subset of $G$ with $k$ elements. Then $D$ is a $(v,k,\lambda,n)$-\emph{difference set in $G$} if the multiset $\{d_1 d_2^{-1}: d_1, d_2 \in D \text{ and } d_1 \ne d_2 \}$ contains every non-identity element of $G$ exactly $\lambda$ times. In this case, we define $n:=k- \lambda$.
plain_text_def: Let G be a group of order v, written multiplicatively, and let D be a subset of G with k elements. Then D is a (v,k,λ,n)-difference set in G if the multiset {d_1 d_2^-1: d_1, d_2 ∈ D  and  d_1  d_2 } contains every non-identity element of G exactly λ times. In this case, we define n:=k- λ.

In this case, we define n:=k- λ.

plain_text_def:
Let G be a group of order v, written multiplicatively, and let ℓ≥ 2. Suppose ℒ= {D_i,j : 0 ≤ i,j  ≤ℓ and i  j } is a collection of size ℓ (ℓ+1) of (v,k,λ,n)-difference sets in G. Then ℒ is a (v,k,λ,n; ℓ+1)-linking system of difference sets in G if there are integers μ, ν such that for all distinct i,j,h, the following equations hold in [G]:

    D_h,i D_i,j   = (μ-ν) D_h,j + ν G 
    
     D_i,j   = D_j,i^(-1) .

plain_text_def:
Let r be a positive integer.
For S_1⊆𝒟_1, S_2⊆𝒟_2, we say that the pair (S_1,S_2) is r-compatible if for every u∈ S_1 and v∈ S_2, denoting by E the left endpoint of u and F the upper endpoint of v, there exists a lattice point A∈ EF^∘ such that

    |(AF)_1|=r|(AF)_2∩ S_2|  or |(EA)_2|=r|(EA)_1∩ S_1|.

    |(AF)_1|=r|(AF)_2∩ S_2|  or |(EA)_2|=r|(EA)_1∩ S_1|.

def:
\label{def:crosscritical}
Let $c$ be a positive integer.
A graph $G$ is \emph{$c$-crossing-critical} if $cr(G)\ge c$, but every proper
subgraph $G'$ of $G$ has $cr(G')<c$.
plain_text_def:
Let c be a positive integer.
A graph G is c-crossing-critical if cr(G)≥ c, but every proper
subgraph G' of G has cr(G')<c.

subgraph G' of G has cr(G')<c.

\textit{poly}(n)$, where $\textit{poly}(n)$ is a polynomial factor.

def:
Suppose $P$ is a tree and $k,l< \omega$.  Suppose also that there exist ordinals $\ee_0\geqslant \ldots \geqslant \ee_l$ such that $$\text{\emph{rank}}(P)=\omega^{\omega^{\ee_0}}\cdot\ldots \cdot\omega^{\omega^{\ee_l}}.$$      Then for any function $f:\Lambda_2(P)\to k+1$,  there exist a subtree $Q$ of $P$ and a function $F:l+1\to k+1$ such that $\text{\emph{rank}}(Q)=\text{\emph{rank}}(P)$ and for each $(s,t)\in \Lambda_2(Q)$,   $\varsigma_Q(s,t)=\varsigma_P(s,t)$ and $F(\varsigma_Q(s,t))=f(s,t)$. 

\label{main1}
plain_text_def:
Suppose P is a tree and k,l< ω.  Suppose also that there exist ordinals _0⩾…⩾_l such that 
    rank(P)=ω^ω^_0·…·ω^ω^_l.
      Then for any function f:Λ_2(P)→ k+1,  there exist a subtree Q of P and a function F:l+1→ k+1 such that rank(Q)=rank(P) and for each (s,t)∈Λ_2(Q),   ς_Q(s,t)=ς_P(s,t) and F(ς_Q(s,t))=f(s,t).

    B_MATH_TERM(P)=ω^ω^_0·…·ω^ω^_l.
      Then for any function f:Λ_2(P)→ k+1,  there exist a subtree Q of P and a function F:l+1→ k+1 such that B_MATH_TERM(Q)=B_MATH_TERM(P) and for each (s,t)∈Λ_2(Q),   ς_Q(s,t)=ς_P(s,t) and F(ς_Q(s,t))=f(s,t).

def:
Fix  $k,l<\omega$. \begin{enumerate}[(i)]\item Suppose $\ee_0\geqslant \ldots \geqslant \ee_l$, $P$ is a tree with $\text{\emph{rank}}(P)= \omega^{\omega^{\ee_0}}\cdot\ldots \cdot\omega^{\omega^{\ee_l}}$, and $f:\Lambda_2(P)\to k+1$ is a function.  If $Q\subset P$ and $F:l+1\to k+1$ are as in Theorem \ref{main1}, $j\leqslant k$,  $A=\{i\leqslant l: F(i)=j\}$, and $\alpha =\omega^{\omega^{\ee_0}\cdot 1_A(0)}\cdot \ldots \cdot\omega^{\omega^{\ee_l}\cdot 1_A(l)},$ then there exists a subtree $R$ of $P$ with $\text{\emph{rank}}(R)=\alpha$  such that $f|_{\Lambda_2(R)}\equiv j$.   Here we obey the convention that if $A=\varnothing$, $\alpha=1$.     \item Let $F:l+1\to k+1$ be a function.   Fix  $\ee_0\geqslant \ldots \geqslant \ee_l$ and a tree $P$ with $\text{\emph{rank}}(P)=\omega^{\omega^{\ee_0}}\cdot\ldots \cdot\omega^{\omega^{\ee_l}}$. Define $f:\Lambda_2(P)\to k+1$ by $f(s,t)=F(\varsigma_P(s,t)).$  If $j\leqslant k$, $A=\{i\leqslant l: F(i)=j\}$, $\alpha=\omega^{\omega^{\ee_0}\cdot 1_A(0)}\cdot \ldots \cdot\omega^{\omega^{\ee_l}\cdot 1_A(l)},$ and $Q$ is any subtree of $P$ such that $f|_{\Lambda_2(Q)}\equiv j$, then $\text{\emph{rank}}(Q) \leqslant \alpha$. \end{enumerate}
\label{slop}
plain_text_def:
Fix  k,l<ω. 
  * Suppose _0⩾…⩾_l, P is a tree with rank(P)= ω^ω^_0·…·ω^ω^_l, and f:Λ_2(P)→ k+1 is a function.  If Q⊂ P and F:l+1→ k+1 are as in Theorem <ref>, j⩽ k,  A={i⩽ l: F(i)=j}, and α =ω^ω^_0· 1_A(0)·…·ω^ω^_l· 1_A(l), then there exists a subtree R of P with rank(R)=α  such that f|_Λ_2(R)≡ j.   Here we obey the convention that if A=∅, α=1.

def:
Let $\gamma$ be a non-zero ordinal and write $\gamma=\omega^{\ee_0}+\ldots +\omega^{\ee_l}$ with $\ee_0\geqslant \ldots \geqslant \ee_l$.  Let $\gamma_0=0$ and $\gamma_{i+1}=\gamma_i+\omega^{\ee_i}$ for $i=0, \ldots, l$.    For any tree $P$ with $\text{\emph{rank}}(P)=\gamma$, any $k<\omega$, and any $f:P\to k+1$, there exist a subtree $Q$ of $P$ and a function $F:l+1\to k+1$ such that $\text{\emph{rank}}(Q)=\text{\emph{rank}}(P)$ and for each $i\leqslant l$,  \begin{enumerate}[(i)]\item $Q^{\gamma_i}\setminus Q^{\gamma_{i+1}}=Q\cap (P^{\gamma_i}\setminus P^{\gamma_{i+1}})$, \item $\varsigma_{Q^{\gamma_i}\setminus Q^{\gamma_{i+1}}}=\varsigma_P|_{\Lambda_2(Q^{\gamma_i}\setminus Q^{\gamma_{i+1}})}$, \item $f|_{Q^{\gamma_i}\setminus Q^{\gamma_{i+1}}}\equiv F(i)$.   \end{enumerate}

\label{ds9}
plain_text_def:
Let γ be a non-zero ordinal and write γ=ω^_0+… +ω^_l with _0⩾…⩾_l.  Let γ_0=0 and γ_i+1=γ_i+ω^_i for i=0, …, l.    For any tree P with rank(P)=γ, any k<ω, and any f:P→ k+1, there exist a subtree Q of P and a function F:l+1→ k+1 such that rank(Q)=rank(P) and for each i⩽ l,  
  * Q^γ_i∖ Q^γ_i+1=Q∩ (P^γ_i∖ P^γ_i+1), 
  * ς_Q^γ_i∖ Q^γ_i+1=ς_P|_Λ_2(Q^γ_i∖ Q^γ_i+1), 
  * f|_Q^γ_i∖ Q^γ_i+1≡ F(i).

  * Q^γ_i∖ Q^γ_i+1=Q∩ (P^γ_i∖ P^γ_i+1),

  * f|_Q^γ_i∖ Q^γ_i+1≡ F(i).

def:
\begin{enumerate}[(i)]\item Let $\gamma$ be a non-zero ordinal and write $\gamma=\omega^{\ee_0}+\ldots +\omega^{\ee_l} $ with $\ee_0\geqslant \ldots \geqslant \ee_l$.    Let $\gamma_0=0$ and for $i<l$, let $\gamma_{i+1}=\gamma_i+\omega^{\ee_i}$.  Suppose $P$ is a tree with $\text{\emph{rank}}(P)= \gamma$, $k<\omega$, and $f:P\to k+1$ is a function.  Suppose $Q\subset P$ and $F:l+1\to k+1$ are as in Theorem \ref{ds9}.   Fix $j\leqslant k$ and let  $A=\{i\leqslant l: F(i)=j\}$ and $\alpha =\omega^{\ee_{a(0)}}+\ldots +\omega^{\ee_{a(p)}}$, where by convention $\alpha=0$ if $A=\varnothing$ and otherwise $A=\{a(0), \ldots, a(p)\}$ with $a(0)<\ldots <a(p)$.    Then there exists a subtree $R$ of $P$ with $\text{\emph{rank}}(R)=\alpha$  such that $f|_R\equiv j$.       \item For $k,l<\omega$, let $F:l+1\to k+1$ be a function.   Fix  $\ee_0\geqslant \ldots \geqslant \ee_l$ and let $\gamma_i$ be as in $(i)$.  Fix a tree $P$ with $\text{\emph{rank}}(P)=\omega^{\ee_0}+\ldots +\omega^{\ee_l}$ and define $f:P\to k+1$ by letting $f|_{P^{\gamma_i}\setminus P^{\gamma_{i+1}}}=F(i)$.     Then if $j\leqslant k$, $A=\{i\leqslant l: F(i)=j\}$, $\alpha=\omega^{\ee_{a(0)}}+\ldots +\omega^{\ee_{a(p)}}$, and $Q$ is any subtree of $P$ such that $f|_Q\equiv j$, then $\text{\emph{rank}}(Q) \leqslant \alpha$. Here we obey the same conventions on $\alpha$ and $A$ as in $(i)$.   \end{enumerate}

plain_text_def:
Let γ be an additively indecomposable ordinal.  For any tree P with  rank(P)= γ, any k<ω, and any f:Λ_2(P)→ k+1, there exist a subtree Q of P with rank(Q)=γ and F:λ(γ)→ k+1 such that for any (s,t)∈Λ_2(Q), F(ς_Q(s,t))=f(s,t)  and ς_Q(s,t)=ς_P(s,t).   

That is, every additively indecomposable ordinal is tractable.

Fix  $l,k<\omega$. \begin{enumerate}[(i)]\item Suppose $\ee_0\geqslant \ldots \geqslant \ee_l$, $P$ is a tree with $\text{\emph{rank}}(P)= \omega^{\omega^{\ee_0}}\cdot \ldots \cdot \omega^{\omega^{\ee_l}}=:\gamma$, $f:\Lambda_2(P)\to k+1$ is a function.  If $Q\subset P$ and $F:l+1\to k+1$ are as in Theorem \ref{big show}, $j\leqslant k$,  $A=\{i\leqslant l: F(i)=j\}$, and $\alpha =\omega^{\omega^{\ee_0}\cdot 1_A(0)}\cdot \ldots \cdot \omega^{\omega^{\ee_l}\cdot 1_A(l)},$ then there exists a subtree $R$ of $P$ with $\text{\emph{rank}}(R)=\alpha$ and such that $f|_{\Lambda_2(R)}\equiv j$.       \item Let $F:l+1\to k+1$ be a function.   Fix  $\ee_0\geqslant \ldots \geqslant \ee_l$ and a tree $P$ with $\text{\emph{rank}}(P)=\omega^{\omega^{\ee_0}}\cdot \ldots \cdot \omega^{\omega^{\ee_l}}$ and define $f:\Lambda_2(P)\to k+1$ by $f(s,t)=F(\varsigma_P(s,t)).$  Then if $j\leqslant k$, $A=\{i\leqslant l: F(i)=j\}$, $\alpha=\omega^{\omega^{\ee_0}\cdot 1_A(0)} \ldots \omega^{\omega^{\ee_l}\cdot 1_A(l)},$ and $Q$ is any subtree of $P$ such that $f|_{\Lambda_2(Q)}\equiv j$, it follows that $\text{\emph{rank}}(Q) \leqslant \alpha$. \end{enumerate}

def:
[Confusability] Two words ${\bx}$ and ${\by}$, are said to be $k$-\textit{confusable} if 
$D_{k}^*({\bx}) \cap D_{k}^*({\by}) \neq \varnothing.$ 
Similarly, they are said to be ${\le}k$-\textit{confusable} if 
$D_{\le k}^*({\bx}) \cap D_{\le k}^*({\by}) \neq \varnothing.$

def:
A word ${\bx}$ is said to be $k$-\textit{irreducible} if ${\bx}$ cannot be deduplicated into shorter words with deduplication of length $k$. In other words, if $\by\xRightarrow[k]{*} \bx$, then $\by=\bx$. 
The set of $k$-irreducible $q$-ary words is denoted by ${\rm Irr}_{k}(q)$ and the set of $k$-irreducible words of length $n$ is denoted by ${\rm Irr}_{k}(n,q)$.
The $k$-ancestors of ${\bx} \in \Sigma_q^*$ that are $k$-irreducible words are called the $k$-\textit{roots} of 
${\bx}$. The set of $k$-roots of $\bx$ is denoted by $R_{k}({\bx})$.
In a similar fashion, we have the definitions of ${\le}k$-{\em irreducible} words and ${\le}k$-roots of $\bx$, and 
the notation ${\rm Irr}_{\le k}(q)$, ${\rm Irr}_{\le k}(n,q)$, and $R_{\le k}(\bx)$.

. The set of k-roots of  is denoted by R_k().
In a similar fashion, we have the definitions of ≤k-irreducible words and ≤k-roots of , and 
the notation Irr_≤ k(q), Irr_≤ k(n,q), and R_≤ k().

The k-ancestors of ∈Σ_q^* that are k-irreducible words are called the k-B_MATH_TERM of 
. The set of k-roots of  is denoted by R_k().
In a similar fashion, we have the definitions of ≤k-irreducible words and ≤k-roots of , and 
the notation Irr_≤ k(q), Irr_≤ k(n,q), and R_≤ k().

def:
\label{def:cluster}
A \textit{$k$-cluster}\index{$k$-cluster} $C$ is a plane graph where all faces except one exterior face are triangles and that has the following properties:

\begin{itemize}
\item All vertices of $C$ have degree at most 6.

\item Vertices which are not on the boundary of $C$ have degree~5 or~6.

\item $C$ contains exactly $k$ vertices with degree 5 which are not on the boundary.

\item No two vertices with degree~5 which are not on the boundary are adjacent.

\item Vertices with degree~5 which are not on the boundary are at distance at least 2 from the boundary.

\item Between any two vertices $a,b$ of $C$ which have degree~5 and which are not on the boundary, there is a path $P$ from $a$ to $b$ so that each edge on $P$ contains exactly one vertex with degree~5 which is not in the boundary.

\item No subgraph of $C$ is a $k$-cluster.

\end{itemize}
plain_text_def:
A k-clusterk-cluster C is a plane graph where all faces except one exterior face are triangles and that has the following properties:



  * All vertices of C have degree at most 6.


  * Vertices which are not on the boundary of C have degree 5 or 6.


  * C contains exactly k vertices with degree 5 which are not on the boundary.


  * No two vertices with degree 5 which are not on the boundary are adjacent.


  * Vertices with degree 5 which are not on the boundary are at distance at least 2 from the boundary.


  * Between any two vertices a,b of C which have degree 5 and which are not on the boundary, there is a path P from a to b so that each edge on P contains exactly one vertex with degree 5 which is not in the boundary.


  * No subgraph of C is a k-cluster.
masked_plain_text_def:
A k-B_MATH_TERMk-B_MATH_TERM C is a plane graph where all faces except one exterior face are triangles and that has the following properties:



  * All vertices of C have degree at most 6.


  * Vertices which are not on the boundary of C have degree 5 or 6.


  * C contains exactly k vertices with degree 5 which are not on the boundary.


  * No two vertices with degree 5 which are not on the boundary are adjacent.


  * Vertices with degree 5 which are not on the boundary are at distance at least 2 from the boundary.


  * Between any two vertices a,b of C which have degree 5 and which are not on the boundary, there is a path P from a to b so that each edge on P contains exactly one vertex with degree 5 which is not in the boundary.


  * No subgraph of C is a k-B_MATH_TERM.

def:
[$k$-matching]
\label{defn:1}
Let $\mathcal{H}=(V,\mathcal{E})$ be an $r$-uniform hypergraph on $n$ vertices and fix a positive integer 
$k$ such that $1\le k\le r$. A $k$-\emph{matching} of $\mathcal{H}$ is a collection of edges $E_{1},\ldots,E_{j}\in\mathcal{E}$ such that every $T\in\binom{V}{k}$ is contained in at most one $E_{i}, i\in\{1,\ldots,j\}$. The maximum cardinality of a $k$-matching in a hypergraph, $\mathcal{H}$, is its $k$-\emph{matching number} and is denoted by $\nu_{k}(\mathcal{H})$.
plain_text_def:
[k-matching]

Let ℋ=(V,ℰ) be an r-uniform hypergraph on n vertices and fix a positive integer 
k such that 1≤ k≤ r. A k-matching of ℋ is a collection of edges E_1,…,E_j∈ℰ such that every T∈Vk is contained in at most one E_i, i∈{1,…,j}. The maximum cardinality of a k-matching in a hypergraph, ℋ, is its k-matching number and is denoted by ν_k(ℋ).
masked_plain_text_def:
[k-matching]

Let ℋ=(V,ℰ) be an r-uniform hypergraph on n vertices and fix a positive integer 
k such that 1≤ k≤ r. A k-B_MATH_TERM of ℋ is a collection of edges E_1,…,E_j∈ℰ such that every T∈Vk is contained in at most one E_i, i∈{1,…,j}. The maximum cardinality of a k-matching in a hypergraph, ℋ, is its k-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM and is denoted by ν_k(ℋ).

def:
\label{d:esp}
Let $\bPhi$ be a set of $d$-di\-mension\-al predicates.
We say that $\bPhi$ is \emph{Erd\H{o}s--Szekeres}
if for every $n$ there exists $N$ such that every sequence
$\seq \aa$ of length $N$  has a subsequence
$\seq \bb$ of length $n$ such that there is a predicate $\Phi\in\bPhi$
that holds everywhere on $\seq\bb$.
Let $\ES_{\bPhi}(n)$ denote the corresponding Ramsey
function, i.e. the smallest $N$ with the property above.
plain_text_def:
Let  be a set of d-di­mension­al predicates.
We say that  is Erdős–Szekeres
if for every n there exists N such that every sequence
å of length N  has a subsequence
 of length n such that there is a predicate Φ∈
that holds everywhere on .
Let _(n) denote the corresponding Ramsey
function, i.e. the smallest N with the property above.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let  be a set of d-di­mension­al predicates.
We say that  is B_MATH_TERMs–Szekeres
if for every n there exists N such that every sequence
å of length N  has a subsequence
 of length n such that there is a predicate Φ∈
that holds everywhere on .
Let _(n) denote the corresponding Ramsey
function, i.e. the smallest N with the property above.

def:
\label{zadj}
    If $U$ and $V$ are $Z_n$ instances of length $m$ such that $U \neq V$ and there does
    not exist a $Z_n$ instance $Y$ of length $m$ such that $\Delta(U) < \Delta(Y) < \Delta(V)$ or $\Delta(V) < \Delta(Y) < \Delta(U)$
    then $U$ and $V$ are said to be neighbors.
plain_text_def:
If U and V are Z_n instances of length m such that U ≠ V and there does
    not exist a Z_n instance Y of length m such that Δ(U) < Δ(Y) < Δ(V) or Δ(V) < Δ(Y) < Δ(U)
    then U and V are said to be neighbors.
masked_plain_text_def:
If U and V are Z_n instances of length m such that U ≠ V and there does
    not exist a Z_n instance Y of length m such that Δ(U) < Δ(Y) < Δ(V) or Δ(V) < Δ(Y) < Δ(U)
    then U and V are said to be B_MATH_TERMs.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
If $U$ is a $Z_n$ instance of length $2^n-1$ we say the set of
    $Z_{n+1}$ instances of the form $U q_i U$ is \textit{generated} by $U$.
    From Lemma~\ref{thm:zcnt} we see that each instance generates a set of
    size $q$.
plain_text_def:
If U is a Z_n instance of length 2^n-1 we say the set of
    Z_n+1 instances of the form U q_i U is generated by U.
    From Lemma <ref> we see that each instance generates a set of
    size q.
masked_plain_text_def:
If U is a Z_n instance of length 2^n-1 we say the set of
    Z_n+1 instances of the form U q_i U is B_MATH_TERMd by U.
    From Lemma <ref> we see that each instance B_MATH_TERMs a set of
    size q.

def:
Suppose that $A$ and $B$ are two sets in some ambient group, and that $K
\geq 1$ is a parameter. We say that $A$ is $K$-controlled by $B$, or that $B$
$K$-controls $A$, if $|B| \leq K|A|$ and there is some set $X$ in the
ambient group with $|X| \leq K$ and such that $A \subseteq (X \cdot B) \cap
(B \cdot X)$.
plain_text_def:
Suppose that A and B are two sets in some ambient group, and that K
≥ 1 is a parameter. We say that A is K-controlled by B, or that B
K-controls A, if |B| ≤ K|A| and there is some set X in the
ambient group with |X| ≤ K and such that A ⊆ (X · B) ∩
(B · X).
masked_plain_text_def:
Suppose that A and B are two sets in some ambient group, and that K
≥ 1 is a parameter. We say that A is K-B_MATH_TERMled by B, or that B
K-B_MATH_TERMs A, if |B| ≤ K|A| and there is some set X in the
ambient group with |X| ≤ K and such that A ⊆ (X · B) ∩
(B · X).
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
[ 
Floor diagrams marked by pairs of partitions ]
Let  be a labeled floor diagram of degree d and genus g. 
Let λ and ρ be two partitions with |λ|+|ρ|=d.
A (λ,ρ)-marking of  is a combinatorial decoration
of  obtained by the following modification of the procedure
used in Definition <ref>. 
We will illustrate the steps of this procedure using a running
example, in which d=4, g=1, λ=(2), ρ=(1,1),
and  is the labeled floor diagram from
Example <ref>:

    (80,15)(30,-4)(25,1.5)(0,0)2(7,0)(1,0)1(17.5,1.75)(2,-1)1(17.5,-1.75)(2,1)1(27,0)(1,0)1


Step 0.
Introduce ℓ(λ) new vertices denoted
v_1,…,v_ℓ(λ):  

    (80,20)(30,-4)(25,1.5)(0,0)2(7,0)(1,0)1(17.5,1.75)(2,-1)1(17.5,-1.75)(2,1)1(27,0)(1,0)1(40,0)2(40,0)*1(42,2)(0,0)v_1


Step 1.
For each original vertex v in , introduce some number (possibly none)
of additional new vertices, and connect v to each of them 
by a single edge directed away from v.
In addition, introduce some (possibly none) edges directed from v
to v_1,…,v_ℓ(λ). 
Assign positive integer weights to all these new edges, so that


  * for each original vertex v in , 
the total weight of all new edges (of both kinds) originating
at v is equal to 1-(v);

def:
\label{def2}
A graph $ G $ is said to be ($k_{1},k_{2}$)-\textit{regular} if $ \textrm{Deg}(G)=\{k_{1}, k_{2}\} $ and no adjacent vertices have the same degree.
plain_text_def: A graph G is said to be (k_1,k_2)-regular if Deg(G)={k_1, k_2} and no adjacent vertices have the same degree.
masked_plain_text_def: A graph G is said to be (k_1,k_2)-B_MATH_TERM if Deg(G)={k_1, k_2} and no adjacent vertices have the same degree.

plain_text_def:
Let S⊆T(n,k) be closed under rotations, and let α,β∈S. Then β is a substring of Greedy_α(S) (treated as a cycle) if and only if β is increasable in S to a rotation of α.
  
  Thus, if S⊆T(n,k) is closed under rotations, then S∈𝒢(n,k) if and only if there exists an α∈S such that every β∈S is increasable in S to α.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let S⊆T(n,k) be closed under rotations, and let α,β∈S. Then β is a substring of B_MATH_TERM_α(S) (treated as a cycle) if and only if β is increasable in S to a rotation of α.
  
  Thus, if S⊆T(n,k) is closed under rotations, then S∈𝒢(n,k) if and only if there exists an α∈S such that every β∈S is increasable in S to α.

we call $c_i$ {\em $P$-isolated}.

def:
\label{fin-def} Let $(G,+)$ be a discrete countable abelian  group, let $\X = (X, \B_X, \mu_X, (T_g)_{g \in G})$ be a $G$-system, and let $U = (U,\cdot)$ be a compact abelian group.  Let $k \geq 0$, and let $\X^{[k]} = (X^{[k]}, \B^{[k]}, \mu^{[k]}, (T_g^{[k]})_{g \in G} )$ be the $G$-system defined in Definition \ref{cubichk-def}.  
\begin{itemize}
\item For each $f \in M(\X,U)$, we define $d^{[k]} f \in M(\X^{[k]},U)$ to be the function
$$ d^{[k]} f((x_\w)_{\w \in \2^k}) := \prod_{\w \in \2^k} f(x_\w)^{\sgn(\w)}$$
where $\sgn(w_1,\ldots,w_k) := w_1 \ldots w_k \in \{-1,+1\}$.    
\item Similarly, for each $\rho \in M(G,\X,U)$, we define $d^{[k]} \rho \in M(G, \X^{[k]}, U)$ to be the function
$$ d^{[k]} \rho(g,(x_\w)_{\w \in \2^k}) := \prod_{\w \in \2^k} \rho(g, x_\w)^{\sgn(\w)}.$$
\item A \emph{$(G,\X,U)$-function of type $<k$} is any function $\rho \in M(G,\X,U)$ such that $d^{[k]} \rho$ is a $(G,\X^{[k]},U)$-coboundary.  We let $M_{<k}(G,\X,U)$ denote the space of $(G,\X,U)$-functions of type $<k$, and let $Z^1_{<k}(G,\X,U) := Z^1(G,\X,U) \cap M_{<k}(G,\X,U)$ 
denote the space of $(G,\X,U)$-cocycles of type $<k$.  % We also write $M_{<\omega}(G,\X,U) := \bigcup_k M_{<k}(G,\X,U)$ and $Z^1_{<\omega}(G,\X,U) = \bigcup_k Z^1_{<k}(G,\X,U)$.
\end{itemize}
plain_text_def:
Let (G,+) be a discrete countable abelian  group, let = (X, _X, μ_X, (T_g)_g ∈ G) be a G-system, and let U = (U,·) be a compact abelian group.  Let k ≥ 0, and let ^[k] = (X^[k], ^[k], μ^[k], (T_g^[k])_g ∈ G ) be the G-system defined in Definition <ref>.  


  * For each f ∈ M(,U), we define d^[k] f ∈ M(^[k],U) to be the function

    d^[k] f((x_)_∈^k) := ∏_∈^k f(x_)^()

where (w_1,…,w_k) := w_1 … w_k ∈{-1,+1}.    

  * Similarly, for each ρ∈ M(G,,U), we define d^[k]ρ∈ M(G, ^[k], U) to be the function

    d^[k]ρ(g,(x_)_∈^k) := ∏_∈^kρ(g, x_)^().


  * A (G,,U)-function of type <k is any function ρ∈ M(G,,U) such that d^[k]ρ is a (G,^[k],U)-coboundary.  We let M_<k(G,,U) denote the space of (G,,U)-functions of type <k, and let Z^1_<k(G,,U) := Z^1(G,,U) ∩ M_<k(G,,U) 
denote the space of (G,,U)-cocycles of type <k.

def:
[$
u$-triangular extremality]
We say that a graph $H$ on $n$ vertices is $
u$-\emph{triangular extreme} if it contains at least $(1-
u)n/3$ vertex disjoint triangles, 
here $0<\varepsilon\ll d\ll 
u\ll 1.$
plain_text_def:
[ν-triangular extremality]
We say that a graph H on n vertices is ν-triangular extreme if it contains at least (1-ν)n/3 vertex disjoint triangles, 
here 0<ε≪ d≪ν≪ 1.
masked_plain_text_def:
[ν-triangular extremality]
We say that a graph H on n vertices is ν-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM if it contains at least (1-ν)n/3 vertex disjoint triangles, 
here 0<ε≪ d≪ν≪ 1.

def:
If $A,B\subseteq V$ and $X\subseteq V\cup E$ are such that every
\emph{A-B} path in $G$ contains a vertex or an edge from $X$, we
say that $X$ \emph{separates} the sets $A$ and $B$ in $G$. More
generally we say that $X$ \emph{separates} $G$ if $G-X$ is
disconnected, that is, if $X$ separates in $G$ some two vertices
that are not in $X$. A separating set of vertices is a
\emph{separator} .
%
plain_text_def:
If A,B⊆ V and X⊆ V∪ E are such that every
A-B path in G contains a vertex or an edge from X, we
say that X separates the sets A and B in G. More
generally we say that X separates G if G-X is
disconnected, that is, if X separates in G some two vertices
that are not in X. A separating set of vertices is a
separator .
masked_plain_text_def:
If A,B⊆ V and X⊆ V∪ E are such that every
A-B path in G contains a vertex or an edge from X, we
say that X B_MATH_TERMs the sets A and B in G. More
generally we say that X B_MATH_TERMs G if G-X is
disconnected, that is, if X B_MATH_TERMs in G some two vertices
that are not in X. A separating set of vertices is a
separator .

def:
A $k$-regular spanning subgraph is called a $k$-factor. Thus, a subgraph
$H\subseteq G$ is a 1-factor of $G$ if and only if $E(H)$ is a matching of
$V$.
%
plain_text_def:
A k-regular spanning subgraph is called a k-factor. Thus, a subgraph
H⊆ G is a 1-factor of G if and only if E(H) is a matching of
V.
masked_plain_text_def:
A k-regular spanning subgraph is called a B_MATH_TERM. Thus, a subgraph
H⊆ G is a 1-factor of G if and only if E(H) is a matching of
V.

plain_text_def:
Let G be a (multiplicative) group and let K≥1. A finite set A⊂ G is called a K-approximate (sub)group if



  * it is symmetric, which is to say that A^-1=A, and contains the identity;

  * there is a symmetric subset X with |X|≤ K such that A^2⊂ XA.

If A generates a nilpotent subgroup of step s then we say that A is an s-step K-approximate group .

If A generates a nilpotent subgroup of step s then we say that A is an s-step K-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM .

def:
For divisors $\calD,\calE$, denote  
$$
(\calD\cap \calE)(v)=\min(\calD(v),\calE(v))
$$
and
$$
(\calD\cup \calE)(v)=\max(\calD(v),\calE(v)).
$$ 
For a divisor $\calD$, we define its $\calP$-\emph{part} as $\calD^\calP=\calD\cap \calP$, and its $\calQ$-\emph{part} as $\calD^\calQ=\calD\cap \calQ$.

    (∩)(v)=min((v),(v))

and

    (∪)(v)=max((v),(v)).
 
For a divisor , we define its -part as ^=∩, and its -part as ^=∩.

def:
\label{def:good} 
 A graph $G$ on $V$ is called `\emph{$(n,C)$-good}' if the following properties hold.
 
\begin{enumerate}[$(P1)$]

\item
There exists  a matching $\cM$ of $G[V_0]$ with $|\cM|=2\epsilon n$ such that for all $U\subset V\setminus V(\cM)$ with $\displaystyle |U|\leq  \frac{\delta n}{C^2\log n}$, 
we have $$\Big|\Big\{ \{a,b\}\in \cM \; \big| \; a\sim u, b\sim u \mbox{ for some } u\in U\Big\}\Big|\geq  \frac{C^2\log n}{16 n} |\cM| |U|.$$

\item

 Let $k=1 \mbox{ or } 2$, and $\cL$ be a collection of pairwise disjoint $k$-subsets of $V$. 
 
 If $\displaystyle |\cL|\leq \frac{\delta}{C^k}\Big(\frac{n}{\log n}\Big)^{k/2}$, then, for $V_i$ with $V_i\cap\Big(\bigcup_{L\in \cL}L\Big)=\emptyset$, $i=1,..., 6$, we have that
\begin{equation}\label{eq:P2_1}
|N_{_{\! B(\cL,V_i)}}(\cL)|\geq (1-\delta)C^k\Big(\frac{\log n}{n}\Big)^{k/2}|\cL| |V_i|.
\end{equation}


 If $\displaystyle |\cL|\geq \frac{\log n}{C^{k-1}}\Big(\frac{n}{\log n}\Big)^{k/2}$, then, for all $U$ with $\displaystyle |U|\geq \frac{\log n}{C^{k-1}}\Big(\frac{n}{\log n}\Big)^{k/2}$ and $U\cap\Big(\bigcup_{L\in \cL}L\Big)=\emptyset$, 
the graph $B(\cL,U)$ has at least one edge.

\vskip 1em
\noindent \Big(No requirement is needed when $\displaystyle\frac{\delta}{C^k}\Big(\frac{n}{\log n}\Big)^{k/2}<|\cL|<\frac{\log n}{C^{k-1}}\Big(\frac{n}{\log n}\Big)^{k/2}$\Big).

\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
A graph G on V is called `(n,C)-good' if the following properties hold.
 



  * There exists  a matching  of G[V_0] with ||=2ϵ n such that for all U⊂ V∖ V() with |U|≤δ n/C^2log n, 
we have 
    |{{a,b}∈ |   a∼ u, b∼ u  u∈ U}|≥C^2log n/16 n || |U|.



  * 

 Let k=1  2, and  be a collection of pairwise disjoint k-subsets of V. 
 
 If ||≤δ/C^k(n/log n)^k/2, then, for V_i with V_i∩(⋃_L∈L)=∅, i=1,..., 6, we have that

    |N__ B(,V_i)()|≥ (1-δ)C^k(log n/n)^k/2|| |V_i|.



 If ||≥log n/C^k-1(n/log n)^k/2, then, for all U with |U|≥log n/C^k-1(n/log n)^k/2 and U∩(⋃_L∈L)=∅, 
the graph B(,U) has at least one edge.

1em
(No requirement is needed when δ/C^k(n/log n)^k/2<||<log n/C^k-1(n/log n)^k/2).
masked_plain_text_def:
A graph G on V is called `B_MATH_TERM' if the following properties hold.

we have 
    |{{a,b}∈ |   a∼ u, b∼ u  u∈ U}|≥C^2log n/16 n || |U|.



  * 

 Let k=1  2, and  be a collection of pairwise disjoint k-subsets of V. 
 
 If ||≤δ/C^k(n/log n)^k/2, then, for V_i with V_i∩(⋃_L∈L)=∅, i=1,..., 6, we have that

    |N__ B(,V_i)()|≥ (1-δ)C^k(log n/n)^k/2|| |V_i|.



 If ||≥log n/C^k-1(n/log n)^k/2, then, for all U with |U|≥log n/C^k-1(n/log n)^k/2 and U∩(⋃_L∈L)=∅, 
the graph B(,U) has at least one edge.

def:
\label{defpolarspace}
A \index{polar space}\emph{polar space of rank $d$} , $d\geq3$, is an incidence geometry $(\Pi,\Omega)$ with $\Pi$ a set whose elements are called points and $\Omega$ a set of subsets of $\Pi$ satisfying the following axioms.
\begin{enumerate}
\item Any element $\omega\in\Omega$ together with the elements of $\Omega$ that are contained in 
$\omega$, is a projective geometry of dimension at most $d-1$. 
\item The intersection of two elements of $\Omega$ is an element of $\Omega$ 
(the set $\Omega$ is closed under intersections).
\item For a point $P\in\Pi$ and an element $\omega\in\Omega$ of dimension $d-1$ 
such that $P$ is not contained in $\omega$ there is a unique element $\omega'\in\Omega$ of dimension $d-1$ 
containing $P$ such that $\omega\cap\omega'$ is a hyperplane of $\omega$. The element $\omega$ is the 
union of all 1-dimensional elements of $\Omega$ that contain $P$ and are contained in $\omega$.
\item There exist two elements $\Omega$ both of dimension $d-1$ whose intersection is empty.
\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
A polar spacepolar space of rank d , d≥3, is an incidence geometry (Π,Ω) with Π a set whose elements are called points and Ω a set of subsets of Π satisfying the following axioms.


  * Any element ω∈Ω together with the elements of Ω that are contained in 
ω, is a projective geometry of dimension at most d-1. 

  * The intersection of two elements of Ω is an element of Ω 
(the set Ω is closed under intersections).

  * For a point P∈Π and an element ω∈Ω of dimension d-1 
such that P is not contained in ω there is a unique element ω'∈Ω of dimension d-1 
containing P such that ω∩ω' is a hyperplane of ω. The element ω is the 
union of all 1-dimensional elements of Ω that contain P and are contained in ω.

  * There exist two elements Ω both of dimension d-1 whose intersection is empty.
masked_plain_text_def:
A polar spaceB_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM , d≥3, is an incidence geometry (Π,Ω) with Π a set whose elements are called points and Ω a set of subsets of Π satisfying the following axioms.


  * Any element ω∈Ω together with the elements of Ω that are contained in 
ω, is a projective geometry of dimension at most d-1. 

  * The intersection of two elements of Ω is an element of Ω 
(the set Ω is closed under intersections).

  * For a point P∈Π and an element ω∈Ω of dimension d-1 
such that P is not contained in ω there is a unique element ω'∈Ω of dimension d-1 
containing P such that ω∩ω' is a hyperplane of ω. The element ω is the 
union of all 1-dimensional elements of Ω that contain P and are contained in ω.

  * There exist two elements Ω both of dimension d-1 whose intersection is empty.

def: A permutation $\pi\in S_n$ is called $t$-\emph{stack-sortable} if $s^t(\pi)=123\cdots n$. Let $\mathcal W_t(n)$ denote the set of $t$-stack-sortable permutations in $S_n$. Let $W_t(n)=|\mathcal W_t(n)|$.

plain_text_def:
A directed graph D on n vertices is called (n,λ,p)-pseudo-random if the following hold:
    
        
  (P1) (1 -λ)np ≤
        d_D^+(v), d_D^-(v)≤ (1 +λ)np for every v∈ V(D);
        
  (P2) For every X⊆ V(D) of size |X|≤4log^8n/p we have
        e_D(X)≤ (1-λ)|X|log^8.02n;
        
  (P3) For every two disjoint subsets X,Y⊆ V(D) of sizes
        |X|,|Y|≥log^1.1n/p we have e_D(X,Y)=
        (1±λ)|X||Y|p.
masked_plain_text_def:
A directed graph D on n vertices is called (n,λ,p)-B_MATH_TERM if the following hold:
    
        
  (P1) (1 -λ)np ≤
        d_D^+(v), d_D^-(v)≤ (1 +λ)np for every v∈ V(D);
        
  (P2) For every X⊆ V(D) of size |X|≤4log^8n/p we have
        e_D(X)≤ (1-λ)|X|log^8.02n;
        
  (P3) For every two disjoint subsets X,Y⊆ V(D) of sizes
        |X|,|Y|≥log^1.1n/p we have e_D(X,Y)=
        (1±λ)|X||Y|p.
