def:
A $2$-$(n,\kappa)$-\emph{design} $\mathcal{D}$ 
is a pair $(\mathcal{P},\mathcal{B})$, where
 $\mathcal{P}$ is a set of $n$ points, and $\mathcal{B}$ is a collection  of $\kappa$-subsets  of $\mathcal{P}$,  such that each subset of $\mathcal{P}$ of size $2$ appears in exactly one member of $\mathcal{B}$. The members of $\mathcal{B}$ are called blocks.
plain_text_def:
A 2-(n,κ)-design 𝒟 
is a pair (𝒫,ℬ), where
 𝒫 is a set of n points, and ℬ is a collection  of κ-subsets  of 𝒫,  such that each subset of 𝒫 of size 2 appears in exactly one member of ℬ. The members of ℬ are called blocks.
masked_plain_text_def:
A 2-(n,κ)-B_MATH_TERM 𝒟 
is a pair (𝒫,ℬ), where
 𝒫 is a set of n points, and ℬ is a collection  of κ-subsets  of 𝒫,  such that each subset of 𝒫 of size 2 appears in exactly one member of ℬ. The members of ℬ are called blocks.

def:
Given $\eps,\eps_k>0$,
$r,t_0,t_1\in\NATS$, a $k$-graph $G$ and a $(k-1)$-complex $\cJ$ on $V(G)$, we
call $\cJ$ a $(t_0,t_1,\eps,\eps_k,r)$-regular slice for $G$ if
$\cJ$ is $(t_0,t_1,\eps)$-equitable and $G$ is $(\eps_k,r)$-regular with respect to all but at most
$\eps_k\binom{t}{k}$ of the $k$-sets of clusters of $\cJ$, where $t$ is the number of clusters of $\cJ$.

def:
\label{def:robust}
Say that $M$ is $(i,\lambda,\lambda',a)$-robust 
if for any rainbow matching $M'$
which is $\lambda$-close to $M$,
any $c\in R$ such that $m_c=vt(v)\in M'$ 
with $v\in \cup_{j=1}^i V_j$, and 
any $E_{\textit{fix}}\subseteq M'\setminus \{m_c\}$, 
any $V_{\textit{avoid}}\subseteq V\setminus  V(M')$ 
and $C_{\textit{avoid}}\subseteq C\setminus C(M')$, 
each of size at most $a$,
there is a rainbow matching $M''$ in $G$ such that 
\begin{itemize}
\item [(1)] $c\notin C(M'')$ and $v\notin V(M'')$,
\item [(2)] $M''$ is $\lambda'$-close to $M$,
\item [(3)] $M''$ fixes $E_{\textit{fix}}$,
and avoids $C_{\textit{avoid}}$ and $V_{\textit{avoid}}$.
\end{itemize}
plain_text_def:
Say that M is (i,λ,λ',a)-robust 
if for any rainbow matching M'
which is λ-close to M,
any c∈ R such that m_c=vt(v)∈ M' 
with v∈∪_j=1^i V_j, and 
any E_fix⊆ M'∖{m_c}, 
any V_avoid⊆ V∖  V(M') 
and C_avoid⊆ C∖ C(M'), 
each of size at most a,
there is a rainbow matching M” in G such that 


  (1) c∉ C(M”) and v∉ V(M”),

  (2) M” is λ'-close to M,

  (3) M” fixes E_fix,
and avoids C_avoid and V_avoid.
masked_plain_text_def:

if for any rainbow matching M'
which is λ-close to M,
any c∈ R such that m_c=vt(v)∈ M' 
with v∈∪_j=1^i V_j, and 
any E_B_MATH_TERM⊆ M'∖{m_c}, 
any V_B_MATH_TERM⊆ V∖  V(M') 
and C_B_MATH_TERM⊆ C∖ C(M'),

there is a rainbow matching M” in G such that

  (2) M” is λ'-close to M,

  (3) M” fixes E_B_MATH_TERM,
and avoids C_B_MATH_TERM and V_B_MATH_TERM.

def:
[$(k,\delta)$-linear forms condition, arithmetic setting]\label{def_lfc_arithmetic}
Let $k\geq 2$ and $\delta >0$. We say that a function $\func[\nu]{\ZZ_N}{[0,\infty)}$ satisfies the $(k,\delta)$-\textit{linear forms condition} (or $(k,\delta)$-\textit{LFC} in short) if
\[
\left| \E_{x_{1}^{(0)},x_{1}^{(1)},\ldots, x_{k}^{(0)}, x_{k}^{(1)} \in \ZZ_N} \left[ \prod_{j=1}^{k} \prod_{\omega \in \{0,1\}^{[k]\setminus \{j\}}} \nu \left( \sum_{i=1}^{k} (j-i) x_{i}^{(\omega_i)} \right)^{n_{j,\omega}} \right]  - 1 \right| \leq \delta,
\]
for any choice of exponents $n_{j,\omega} \in \{ 0,1\}$.
plain_text_def:
[(k,δ)-linear forms condition, arithmetic setting]
Let k≥ 2 and δ >0. We say that a function [ν]_N[0,∞) satisfies the (k,δ)-linear forms condition (or (k,δ)-LFC in short) if

    | _x_1^(0),x_1^(1),…, x_k^(0), x_k^(1)∈_N[ ∏_j=1^k∏_ω∈{0,1}^[k]∖{j}ν( ∑_i=1^k (j-i) x_i^(ω_i))^n_j,ω]  - 1 | ≤δ,

for any choice of exponents n_j,ω∈{ 0,1}.
masked_plain_text_def:
[(k,δ)-linear forms condition, arithmetic setting]
Let k≥ 2 and δ >0. We say that a function [ν]_N[0,∞) satisfies the (k,δ)-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM (or (k,δ)-B_MATH_TERM in short) if

    | _x_1^(0),x_1^(1),…, x_k^(0), x_k^(1)∈_N[ ∏_j=1^k∏_ω∈{0,1}^[k]∖{j}ν( ∑_i=1^k (j-i) x_i^(ω_i))^n_j,ω]  - 1 | ≤δ,

for any choice of exponents n_j,ω∈{ 0,1}.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
[(k,δ)-linear forms condition, hypergraph setting]
Let δ >0.  We say that a weighted (k-1)-uniform k-partite hypergraph ν satisfies the (k,δ)-linear forms condition ((k,δ)-LFC ) if

    | _x_1^(0),x_1^(1)∈ X_1,…, x_k^(0), x_k^(1)∈ X_k[ ∏_j=1^k∏_ω∈{ 0,1}^[k]∖{j}ν( (x^(ω))_-j)^n_j,ω] - 1 | ≤δ,

for any choice of exponents n_j,ω∈{ 0,1}, with x^(ω) = (x_1^(ω_1), …, x_k^(ω_k) ).
masked_plain_text_def:
[(k,δ)-linear forms condition, hypergraph setting]
Let δ >0.  We say that a weighted (k-1)-uniform k-partite hypergraph ν satisfies the (k,δ)-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM ((k,δ)-B_MATH_TERM ) if

    | _x_1^(0),x_1^(1)∈ X_1,…, x_k^(0), x_k^(1)∈ X_k[ ∏_j=1^k∏_ω∈{ 0,1}^[k]∖{j}ν( (x^(ω))_-j)^n_j,ω] - 1 | ≤δ,

for any choice of exponents n_j,ω∈{ 0,1}, with x^(ω) = (x_1^(ω_1), …, x_k^(ω_k) ).

plain_text_def:
We say that a measure ν: →∞ satisfies the l_0-correlation condition if whenever we have l ≤ l_0 linear forms of the form f+h_1, … f+h_l with h_1, h_2, … h_l∈ , then

    ( ν(f+h_1) …ν(f+h_l) | f ∈) ≤∑_1 ≤ i ≤ j ≤ q τ(h_i-h_j)

where τ is a function →^+ having the property that (τ(f)^p | f∈) =O_p(1) for every p>1.
masked_plain_text_def:
We say that a measure ν: →∞ satisfies the l_0-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM if whenever we have l ≤ l_0 linear forms of the form f+h_1, … f+h_l with h_1, h_2, … h_l∈ , then

    ( ν(f+h_1) …ν(f+h_l) | f ∈) ≤∑_1 ≤ i ≤ j ≤ q τ(h_i-h_j)

where τ is a function →^+ having the property that (τ(f)^p | f∈) =O_p(1) for every p>1.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
Let $G$ be a graph and let $\{c_0, c_1, c_2, c_3\} \subseteq V(G)$. Then a $(c_0, c_1, c_2, c_3)$-\textit{skeleton} is an ordered list 
$S=(C_0, C_2, Z, P_0, P_1, P_2, P_3)$ such that

\begin{enumerate}
\item  $C_0$, $C_2$, and $Z$ are vertex disjoint cycles, $c_0,c_1\in V(C_0)$,  $c_2,c_3\in V(C_2)$, 

\item  for each $i\in \{0,1,2,3\}$, $P_i$ is a path in $G$ from $c_i$ to some vertex  $z_i\in V(Z)$ that is internally disjoint from 
$V(C_0)\cup V(C_2)\cup V(Z)$, 

\item  $P_0,P_1,P_2,P_3$ are pairwise vertex disjoint, and $z_{0}, z_{1}, z_{3}, z_{2}$ occur on $Z$ in this cyclic order.
\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
Let G be a graph and let {c_0, c_1, c_2, c_3}⊆ V(G). Then a (c_0, c_1, c_2, c_3)-skeleton is an ordered list 
S=(C_0, C_2, Z, P_0, P_1, P_2, P_3) such that



  * C_0, C_2, and Z are vertex disjoint cycles, c_0,c_1∈ V(C_0),  c_2,c_3∈ V(C_2), 


  * for each i∈{0,1,2,3}, P_i is a path in G from c_i to some vertex  z_i∈ V(Z) that is internally disjoint from 
V(C_0)∪ V(C_2)∪ V(Z), 


  * P_0,P_1,P_2,P_3 are pairwise vertex disjoint, and z_0, z_1, z_3, z_2 occur on Z in this cyclic order.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let G be a graph and let {c_0, c_1, c_2, c_3}⊆ V(G). Then a (c_0, c_1, c_2, c_3)-B_MATH_TERM is an ordered list 
S=(C_0, C_2, Z, P_0, P_1, P_2, P_3) such that



  * C_0, C_2, and Z are vertex disjoint cycles, c_0,c_1∈ V(C_0),  c_2,c_3∈ V(C_2), 


  * for each i∈{0,1,2,3}, P_i is a path in G from c_i to some vertex  z_i∈ V(Z) that is internally disjoint from 
V(C_0)∪ V(C_2)∪ V(Z), 


  * P_0,P_1,P_2,P_3 are pairwise vertex disjoint, and z_0, z_1, z_3, z_2 occur on Z in this cyclic order.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{goninequality}
The gonality of $U(f)$ is at most $\emph{lw}(\Delta(f))$. If
$\Delta(f)$ is equivalent to $d\Sigma$
for some $d \geq 2$, or
to $2 \Upsilon$,
then it is at most $\emph{lw}(\Delta(f)) - 1$.
plain_text_def:
The gonality of U(f) is at most lw(Δ(f)). If
Δ(f) is equivalent to dΣ
for some d ≥ 2, or
to 2 Υ,
then it is at most lw(Δ(f)) - 1.
masked_plain_text_def:
The gonality of U(f) is at most B_MATH_TERM(Δ(f)). If
Δ(f) is equivalent to dΣ
for some d ≥ 2, or
to 2 Υ,
then it is at most B_MATH_TERM(Δ(f)) - 1.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{lwDelta1} Let $\Delta$ be a two-dimensional lattice polygon.
Then
\[ \emph{lw}(\Delta) = \emph{lw}(\Delta^{(1)}) + 2,\]
unless $\Delta \cong d \Sigma$ for some integer $d \geq 2$, in which
case $\emph{lw}(\Delta) = \emph{lw}(\Delta^{(1)}) + 3 = d$.
plain_text_def:
Let Δ be a two-dimensional lattice polygon.
Then

    lw(Δ) = lw(Δ^(1)) + 2,

unless Δ≅ d Σ for some integer d ≥ 2, in which
case lw(Δ) = lw(Δ^(1)) + 3 = d.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let Δ be a two-dimensional lattice polygon.
Then

    B_MATH_TERM(Δ) = B_MATH_TERM(Δ^(1)) + 2,

unless Δ≅ d Σ for some integer d ≥ 2, in which
case B_MATH_TERM(Δ) = B_MATH_TERM(Δ^(1)) + 3 = d.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{smallwidth}
Conjecture~\ref{gongeneric} is true for all lattice polygons $\Delta$ for which $\emph{lw}(\Delta^{(1)}) \leq 2$.
plain_text_def: Conjecture <ref> is true for all lattice polygons Δ for which lw(Δ^(1)) ≤ 2.
masked_plain_text_def: Conjecture <ref> is true for all lattice polygons Δ for which B_MATH_TERM(Δ^(1)) ≤ 2.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
Let B be a finite alphabet. Any finite word over B will be called a pattern. Let ∼ be an equivalence relation over A^*. We now define a language-valued morphism that we will call a substitution[We here use the term `substitution' to avoid any confusion with the term `morphism'. In the literature, the word substitution is sometimes interchanged with morphism or non-erasing prolongable morphism.]. 
Let h:B→ 2^A^* be a map satisfying

  
  * for all b∈ B, h(b) is a non-empty set and ε∉h(b);
  
  * for all b∈ B, if u,v∈ h(b), then u∼ v;

Note that the image of every letter b∈ B is a subset of an equivalence class for ∼. The map h is then extended to a morphism from B^* to 2^A^* by setting h(ε)={ε} and h(PQ)=h(P)h(Q) for all P,Q∈ B^*. We say that the morphism h is a ∼-substitution.  

Let P∈ B^* be non-empty. The pattern P is ∼-unavoidable over A if the language 

    ℒ_∼(P):=⋃_h:B^*→ 2^A^*
     h is a ∼-substitution h(P)⊂ A^*

is unavoidable over A. Otherwise,  P is ∼-avoidable over A. If ∼ is the equality relation, we get back to the classical notion of avoidance. Every =-substitution is a non-erasing morphism and conversely. Note that it is enough to consider in the union defining ℒ_∼(P), the substitutions mapping letters of B to equivalence classes of ∼. The set ℒ_∼(P) is called the pattern language associated with P and ∼.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let B be a finite alphabet. Any finite word over B will be called a pattern. Let ∼ be an equivalence relation over A^*. We now define a language-valued morphism that we will call a substitution[We here use the term `substitution' to avoid any confusion with the term `morphism'. In the literature, the word substitution is sometimes interchanged with morphism or non-erasing prolongable morphism.]. 
Let h:B→ 2^A^* be a map satisfying

  
  * for all b∈ B, h(b) is a non-empty set and ε∉h(b);
  
  * for all b∈ B, if u,v∈ h(b), then u∼ v;

Note that the image of every letter b∈ B is a subset of an equivalence class for ∼. The map h is then extended to a morphism from B^* to 2^A^* by setting h(ε)={ε} and h(PQ)=h(P)h(Q) for all P,Q∈ B^*. We say that the morphism h is a ∼-substitution.  

Let P∈ B^* be non-empty. The pattern P is ∼-unavoidable over A if the language 

    ℒ_∼(P):=⋃_h:B^*→ 2^A^*
     h is a ∼-substitution h(P)⊂ A^*

is unavoidable over A. Otherwise,  P is ∼-avoidable over A. If ∼ is the equality relation, we get back to the classical notion of B_MATH_TERM. Every =-substitution is a non-erasing morphism and conversely. Note that it is enough to consider in the union defining ℒ_∼(P), the substitutions mapping letters of B to equivalence classes of ∼. The set ℒ_∼(P) is called the pattern language associated with P and ∼.

def:
\label{taugraph}
The $\tau$\textit{-graph} corresponding to an ordered pair list $\sigma$ is an at most in-degree one, out-degree one directed graph $\mathscr{T}_{\sigma} = (V, \; E)$, where $V = \{ b_1, b_2, \ldots, b_k \}$ and $(b_i, b_j) \in E$ if and only if $b_i + 1 = b_j$ in some permutation in $T_{\sigma}$.
plain_text_def: The τ-graph corresponding to an ordered pair list σ is an at most in-degree one, out-degree one directed graph 𝒯_σ = (V,   E), where V = { b_1, b_2, …, b_k } and (b_i, b_j) ∈ E if and only if b_i + 1 = b_j in some permutation in T_σ.
masked_plain_text_def: The τB_MATH_TERM corresponding to an ordered pair list σ is an at most in-degree one, out-degree one directed graph 𝒯_σ = (V,   E), where V = { b_1, b_2, …, b_k } and (b_i, b_j) ∈ E if and only if b_i + 1 = b_j in some permutation in T_σ.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def: Let $A$ and $B$ be two sets in some ambient abelian group, and $K \geq 1$. We say that $B$ \emph{$K$-controls} $A$ if $|B| \leq K|A|$ and if there is some set $X$ in the ambient group with $|X| \leq K$ and such that $A \subseteq B + X$.
plain_text_def: Let A and B be two sets in some ambient abelian group, and K ≥ 1. We say that B K-controls A if |B| ≤ K|A| and if there is some set X in the ambient group with |X| ≤ K and such that A ⊆ B + X.
masked_plain_text_def: Let A and B be two sets in some ambient abelian group, and K ≥ 1. We say that B K-B_MATH_TERMs A if |B| ≤ K|A| and if there is some set X in the ambient group with |X| ≤ K and such that A ⊆ B + X.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def: A combinatorial disk $H$ satisfies a $(k,D)$\textit{-linear isoperimetric inequality} (LII) if $|F|\leq D$ for all bounded faces $F$ of $H$ and the number of bounded faces of $H$ is bounded above by $k|\partial_{top}H|$.
plain_text_def: A combinatorial disk H satisfies a (k,D)-linear isoperimetric inequality (LII) if |F|≤ D for all bounded faces F of H and the number of bounded faces of H is bounded above by k|∂_topH|.
masked_plain_text_def: A combinatorial disk H satisfies a (k,D)B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM (LII) if |F|≤ D for all bounded faces F of H and the number of bounded faces of H is bounded above by k|∂_topH|.

def:
Suppose~$\eps>0$ and~$0<p<1$.  Let $k$ and~$\ell$ with $k\le \ell $
  be positive integers.  We call an $n$-vertex graph~$G$
  $(\eps,p,k,\ell)$-\emph{pseudorandom} if
  \begin{equation}\label{eq:pseudodisc}
    \bigl|e(X,Y)-p|X||Y|\bigr|< \eps p |X||Y|
  \end{equation}
  for any disjoint subsets $X$, $Y\subseteq V(G)$ with
  $|X|\ge\eps p^{k}n$ and $|Y|\ge\eps p^{\ell}n$.
plain_text_def:
Suppose >0 and 0<p<1.  Let k and ℓ with k≤ℓ
  be positive integers.  We call an n-vertex graph G
  (,p,k,ℓ)-pseudorandom if
  
    |e(X,Y)-p|X||Y||<  p |X||Y|

  for any disjoint subsets X, Y⊆ V(G) with
  |X|≥ p^kn and |Y|≥ p^ℓn.
masked_plain_text_def:
Suppose >0 and 0<p<1.  Let k and ℓ with k≤ℓ
  be positive integers.  We call an n-vertex graph G
  (,p,k,ℓ)-B_MATH_TERM if
  
    |e(X,Y)-p|X||Y||<  p |X||Y|

  for any disjoint subsets X, Y⊆ V(G) with
  |X|≥ p^kn and |Y|≥ p^ℓn.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
A Boolean function f = f(x_1, …, x_n) is called canalyzing[The notion of canalyzing functions was introduced in <cit.> and 
is widely used in biological applications of Boolean networks. The lro functions form a subclass of canalyzing functions and are known in this context as nested canalyzing.]
if there exists i ∈ [n] such that f_|x_i=0 or f_|x_i=1 is a constant function.
masked_plain_text_def:
A Boolean function f = f(x_1, …, x_n) is called B_MATH_TERM[The notion of canalyzing functions was introduced in <cit.> and 
is widely used in biological applications of Boolean networks. The lro functions form a subclass of canalyzing functions and are known in this context as nested canalyzing.]
if there exists i ∈ [n] such that f_|x_i=0 or f_|x_i=1 is a constant function.

def:
[Allouche and Shallit \protect\cite{jps}]
Let $\mathcal{A}$ be a set of non-negative integers. Then we say that $%
\mathcal{A}$ is a $k$\emph{-automatic set} if its characteristic sequence
\[
a_{n}=\left\{
\begin{array}{ll}
1, & \hbox{if $n\in \mathcal{A}$;} \\
0, & \hbox{otherwise,}%
\end{array}%
\right.
\]%
defines a $k$-automatic sequence.
plain_text_def:
[Allouche and Shallit <cit.>]
Let 𝒜 be a set of non-negative integers. Then we say that 𝒜 is a k-automatic set if its characteristic sequence

    a_n={[         1,    if n∈𝒜;;         0, otherwise, ]
    .

defines a k-automatic sequence.
masked_plain_text_def:
[Allouche and Shallit <cit.>]
Let 𝒜 be a set of non-negative integers. Then we say that 𝒜 is a kB_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM if its characteristic sequence

    a_n={[         1,    if n∈𝒜;;         0, otherwise, ]
    .

defines a k-automatic sequence.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
[extended linked ordering]
Let $G$ be a $n$-vertex graph and $X\subseteq V(G)$.
An ordering $\sigma=\langle v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\rangle$ of $G$ is $X$-\emph{linked} if  $X=\{v_{n-|X|+1},\ldots,v_{n}\}$
and 
for every $i,j\in[n-|X|,n]$ where $i<j$
%for any two vertices $u,u'\in X$ where $u\leq_{\sigma} u'$, 
there exist $\min \{\delta(\{{v_{1},\ldots,v_h}\}) \mid  i\leq h\leq j \}$ edge-disjoint paths between $\{v_{1},\ldots,v_{i}\}$ and $\{v_{j},\ldots,v_{n}\}$ in $G$.
plain_text_def:
[extended linked ordering]
Let G be a n-vertex graph and X⊆ V(G).
An ordering σ=⟨ v_1,…,v_n⟩ of G is X-linked if  X={v_n-|X|+1,…,v_n}
and 
for every i,j∈[n-|X|,n] where i<j

there exist min{δ({v_1,…,v_h}) |  i≤ h≤ j } edge-disjoint paths between {v_1,…,v_i} and {v_j,…,v_n} in G.
masked_plain_text_def:
[extended linked ordering]
Let G be a n-vertex graph and X⊆ V(G).
An ordering σ=⟨ v_1,…,v_n⟩ of G is X-B_MATH_TERM if  X={v_n-|X|+1,…,v_n}
and 
for every i,j∈[n-|X|,n] where i<j

there exist min{δ({v_1,…,v_h}) |  i≤ h≤ j } edge-disjoint paths between {v_1,…,v_i} and {v_j,…,v_n} in G.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{def2_mu_satur}A point set $S\subset \Pi _{q}$ is $(1,\mu)
$-\emph{saturating} if for every point $Q$ of $\Pi
_{q}\setminus S$ the number of secants of $S$ through $Q$ is at
least $\mu $, counted with multiplicity. Here the multiplicity
of a secant $\ell $ is computed as ${\binom{{\#(\ell \,\cap
S)}}{{2}}}.$
plain_text_def:
A point set S⊂Π _q is (1,μ)-saturating if for every point Q of Π
_q∖ S the number of secants of S through Q is at
least μ, counted with multiplicity. Here the multiplicity
of a secant ℓ is computed as #(ℓ ∩
S)2.
masked_plain_text_def:
A point set S⊂Π _q is (1,μ)-B_MATH_TERM if for every point Q of Π
_q∖ S the number of secants of S through Q is at
least μ, counted with multiplicity. Here the multiplicity
of a secant ℓ is computed as #(ℓ ∩
S)2.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
Define the partition $\lambda^{[i]}$ to be the partition obtained from the code
of a strict partition $\lambda$ by inserting a U between the $i^{\text{th}}$ pair
of consecutive R's (with the convention that three consecutive R's counts as two
pairs, four consecutive R's counts as three pairs, and so on).  Equivalently,
$\lambda^{[i]}$ is the partition obtained from the code of $\lambda$ by inserting
a U after the $i^{\textit{th}}$ R which is immediately followed by an R.
plain_text_def:
Define the partition λ^[i] to be the partition obtained from the code
of a strict partition λ by inserting a U between the i^th pair
of consecutive R's (with the convention that three consecutive R's counts as two
pairs, four consecutive R's counts as three pairs, and so on).  Equivalently,
λ^[i] is the partition obtained from the code of λ by inserting
a U after the i^th R which is immediately followed by an R.
masked_plain_text_def:
Define the partition λ^[i] to be the partition obtained from the code
of a strict partition λ by inserting a U between the i^th pair
of consecutive R's (with the convention that three consecutive R's counts as two
pairs, four consecutive R's counts as three pairs, and so on).  Equivalently,
λ^[i] is the partition obtained from the code of λ by inserting
a U after the i^B_MATH_TERM R which is immediately followed by an R.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
[Structure  and number of shortest paths]\label{thm:structure-2}
Under the same conditions as in Theorem \ref{thm:distances}, there is a shortest path between $v_r, v_b$ that has the following structure, whp:

\begin{enumerate}
\item[(1)]\emph{(Degree-increasing phase)} For both $q\in\{r,b\}$, starting from $v_q$, a path segment of length $T_q({\beta_n})=\log \log (n^{{\beta_n}})/|\log (\tau-2)|+\Theta_{\Pv}(1)$ as in \eqref{def:ti-bi} ends with a vertex $v_q^\star$ with degree
 \be\label{eq:degree-at-segment} d_{v_q^\star}\sim n^{{\beta_n} (\tau-2)^{\bnq({\beta_n})}},\ee where $\bnq({\beta_n})$ is from \eqref{def:ti-bi}. The vertex $v_q^\star$ can be chosen to be the maximal degree vertex among all vertices that are reachable from $v_q$ on a path of length $T_q({\beta_n})$.
  For any $k<i_{\star\sss{(q)}}({\beta_n})$, the degree of the $(T_q({\beta_n})-k)$th vertex on the path between $v_q, v_q^\star$  is  $\sim n^{{\beta_n} (\tau-2)^{\bnq({\beta_n})+k}}$, where $i_{\star\sss{(q)}}({\beta_n})$ are tight random variables given below in \eqref{eq:value_i*-al} and \eqref{eq:istar-b}.

\item[(2)]\label{phase-2}\emph{(Connection among high-degree vertices phase)} A path of length
\be\label{eq:connecting-segment} \left\lceil    \frac{1/{\beta_n}-(\tau-2)^{b_n^{\sss{(r)}}({\beta_n})}-(\tau-2)^{b_n^{\sss{(b)}}({\beta_n})}}{3-\tau} \right\rceil +1\ee connects $v_r^\star, v_b^\star$ using only vertices with degree at least $n^{{\beta_n} f_n^\ell}$, where,  in agreement with Theorem \ref{thm:structure-1}, $f^\ell_n:=f^\ell({\beta_n}, (\tau-2)^{\bnr({\beta_n})}, (\tau-2)^{\bnb({\beta_n})})$.
Further, Phase (2) is valid for all shortest paths, whp. That is, whp, for any shortest path $\CP_{v_r, v_b}^\star$, the segment between the $T_r({\beta_n})$th and the $|\CP_{v_r, v_b}^\star|-T_b({\beta_n})$th vertex has length as in \eqref{eq:connecting-segment}, and it only contains vertices with degree at least $n^{{\beta_n} f^\ell_n}$.
\end{enumerate}
Finally, as a consequence of Theorem \ref{thm:structure-1}, the number of shortest paths between $v_r, v_b$ satisfies $\Pv_{\sss{Y}}-whp$
\[ \#\{ \CP_{v_r, v_b}^\star \}\sim n^{{\beta_n} f^u_n},\]
where $f^u_n:=f^u({\beta_n}, (\tau-2)^{\bnr({\beta_n})}, (\tau-2)^{\bnb({\beta_n})} )\in[0,1)$ fluctuates with $n$.
plain_text_def:
[Structure  and number of shortest paths]
Under the same conditions as in Theorem <ref>, there is a shortest path between v_r, v_b that has the following structure, whp:



  (1)(Degree-increasing phase) For both q∈{r,b}, starting from v_q, a path segment of length T_q(β_n)=loglog (n^β_n)/|log (τ-2)|+Θ_(1) as in (<ref>) ends with a vertex v_q^⋆ with degree
  d_v_q^⋆∼n^β_n (τ-2)^(β_n),where (β_n) is from (<ref>). The vertex v_q^⋆ can be chosen to be the maximal degree vertex among all vertices that are reachable from v_q on a path of length T_q(β_n).
  For any k<i_⋆(q)(β_n), the degree of the (T_q(β_n)-k)th vertex on the path between v_q, v_q^⋆  is  ∼ n^β_n (τ-2)^(β_n)+k, where i_⋆(q)(β_n) are tight random variables given below in (<ref>) and (<ref>).


  (2)(Connection among high-degree vertices phase) A path of length
 ⌈1/β_n-(τ-2)^b_n^(r)(β_n)-(τ-2)^b_n^(b)(β_n)/3-τ ⌉+1connects v_r^⋆, v_b^⋆ using only vertices with degree at least n^β_n f_n^ℓ, where,  in agreement with Theorem <ref>, f^ℓ_n:=f^ℓ(β_n, (τ-2)^(β_n), (τ-2)^(β_n)).
Further, Phase (2) is valid for all shortest paths, whp. That is, whp, for any shortest path _v_r, v_b^⋆, the segment between the T_r(β_n)th and the |_v_r, v_b^⋆|-T_b(β_n)th vertex has length as in (<ref>), and it only contains vertices with degree at least n^β_n f^ℓ_n.

Finally, as a consequence of Theorem <ref>, the number of shortest paths between v_r, v_b satisfies _Y-whp

    #{_v_r, v_b^⋆}∼ n^β_n f^u_n,

where f^u_n:=f^u(β_n, (τ-2)^(β_n), (τ-2)^(β_n) )∈[0,1) fluctuates with n.
masked_plain_text_def:
[Structure  and number of shortest paths]
Under the same conditions as in Theorem <ref>, there is a shortest path between v_r, v_b that has the following structure, whp:



  (1)B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM For both q∈{r,b}, starting from v_q, a path segment of length T_q(β_n)=loglog (n^β_n)/|log (τ-2)|+Θ_(1) as in (<ref>) ends with a vertex v_q^⋆ with degree
  d_v_q^⋆∼n^β_n (τ-2)^(β_n),where (β_n) is from (<ref>). The vertex v_q^⋆ can be chosen to be the maximal degree vertex among all vertices that are reachable from v_q on a path of length T_q(β_n).
  For any k<i_⋆(q)(β_n), the degree of the (T_q(β_n)-k)th vertex on the path between v_q, v_q^⋆  is  ∼ n^β_n (τ-2)^(β_n)+k, where i_⋆(q)(β_n) are tight random variables given below in (<ref>) and (<ref>).

 ⌈1/β_n-(τ-2)^b_n^(r)(β_n)-(τ-2)^b_n^(b)(β_n)/3-τ ⌉+1connects v_r^⋆, v_b^⋆ using only vertices with degree at least n^β_n f_n^ℓ, where,  in agreement with Theorem <ref>, f^ℓ_n:=f^ℓ(β_n, (τ-2)^(β_n), (τ-2)^(β_n)).
Further, Phase (2) is valid for all shortest paths, whp. That is, whp, for any shortest path _v_r, v_b^⋆, the segment between the T_r(β_n)th and the |_v_r, v_b^⋆|-T_b(β_n)th vertex has length as in (<ref>), and it only contains vertices with degree at least n^β_n f^ℓ_n.

where f^u_n:=f^u(β_n, (τ-2)^(β_n), (τ-2)^(β_n) )∈[0,1) fluctuates with n.

def:
Let $r$ be a positive integer. A code $C \subseteq V$ is said to be $r$-\emph{identifying} in $G$ if for all $u,v \in V$ ($u \neq v$) the set $I_r(C;u)$ is nonempty and
\[
I_r(C;u) \neq I_r(C;v) \textrm{.}
\]
plain_text_def:
Let r be a positive integer. A code C ⊆ V is said to be r-identifying in G if for all u,v ∈ V (u ≠ v) the set I_r(C;u) is nonempty and

    I_r(C;u) ≠ I_r(C;v) .
masked_plain_text_def:
Let r be a positive integer. A code C ⊆ V is said to be r-B_MATH_TERM in G if for all u,v ∈ V (u ≠ v) the set I_r(C;u) is nonempty and

    I_r(C;u) ≠ I_r(C;v) .
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
For $\alpha>0$ and $L\in\mathbb N$, we say that a pair of graphs $(F, F^*)$, both on the same vertex set~$V$ of order~$n$
    and with densities $p$ and $p^*$, respectively, is \emph{$(\alpha,L)$-coquasirandom} if for
    every set $S\subset V$ of at most $L$ vertices and every subset $R\subseteq S$ we have
    \[|N_{F}(R)\cap N_{F^*}(S\setminus R)|
    =(1\pm\alpha)p^{|R|}(p^*)^{|S\setminus R|}n\,.\]
plain_text_def:
For α>0 and L∈ℕ, we say that a pair of graphs (F, F^*), both on the same vertex set V of order n
    and with densities p and p^*, respectively, is (α,L)-coquasirandom if for
    every set S⊂ V of at most L vertices and every subset R⊆ S we have
    
    |N_F(R)∩ N_F^*(S∖ R)|
        =(1±α)p^|R|(p^*)^|S∖ R|n .
masked_plain_text_def:
For α>0 and L∈ℕ, we say that a pair of graphs (F, F^*), both on the same vertex set V of order n
    and with densities p and p^*, respectively, is (α,L)-B_MATH_TERM if for
    every set S⊂ V of at most L vertices and every subset R⊆ S we have
    
    |N_F(R)∩ N_F^*(S∖ R)|
        =(1±α)p^|R|(p^*)^|S∖ R|n .

def: An unordered triple $\omega$ is said to be a $d$-\emph{weight class} if there exists a $d$-minimal triangle $S$ satisfying $W(S) = \omega$.

def: A triangle $T$ is said to be $d$\emph{-minimal} if $T \cap \mathcal{L}_d$ consists precisely of the vertices of $T$.
plain_text_def: A triangle T is said to be d-minimal if T ∩ℒ_d consists precisely of the vertices of T.
masked_plain_text_def: A triangle T is said to be dB_MATH_TERM if T ∩ℒ_d consists precisely of the vertices of T.

def:
Let $C$ be a code in $K_q^3$ and $i$ be an integer such that $1\leq i\le q$. Define an $x_i$\textit{-layer} of the graph $K_q^3$, denoted by $D^1_i$, as the set of vertices which fixes the coordinate $x=i$, i.e., $D^1_i=\{(i,y,z)\mid 1\leq y,z\leq q\}$. Analogously, we define a $y_i$\emph{-layer} $D^2_i$ and a $z_i$\emph{-layer} $D^3_i$. Let $j$ be an integer such that $1\le j\le3$. Define then $X^j_i = \{ v \in D_i^j \mid I(C;v)\cap D^j_i=\emptyset \}$ and $Y_i^j = \{ v \in D_i^j \mid I(C;v)\cap D^j_i= \{ v \} \}$. %Furthermore, let $\hat{X}^j_i$ be a subset of $V(K_q\square K_q)$ corresponding to $X^j_i$ and $\hat{Y}^j_i$ be a subset of $V(K_q\square K_q)$ corresponding to $Y^j_i$. So $(y_j,z_k)\in \hat{X}^1_i$ if $(x_i,y_j,z_k)\in X^1_i$.
Furthermore, we use the following notation: $X^j=\bigcup_{i=1}^q X_i^j$, $Y^j=\bigcup_{i=1}^q Y_i^j$ and $X=\bigcup_{j=1}^3 X^j$, $ Y=\bigcup_{j=1}^3 Y^j$ and $C^j_i=C\cap D^j_i$. A codeword which does not belong to $Y$ is called a \emph{corner} , and a \emph{fellow} is a codeword belonging to $Y$ such that it has another codeword in its open neighbourhood.
plain_text_def:
Let C be a code in K_q^3 and i be an integer such that 1≤ i≤ q. Define an x_i-layer of the graph K_q^3, denoted by D^1_i, as the set of vertices which fixes the coordinate x=i, i.e., D^1_i={(i,y,z)| 1≤ y,z≤ q}. Analogously, we define a y_i-layer D^2_i and a z_i-layer D^3_i. Let j be an integer such that 1≤ j≤3. Define then X^j_i = { v ∈ D_i^j | I(C;v)∩ D^j_i=∅} and Y_i^j = { v ∈ D_i^j | I(C;v)∩ D^j_i= { v }}. 
Furthermore, we use the following notation: X^j=⋃_i=1^q X_i^j, Y^j=⋃_i=1^q Y_i^j and X=⋃_j=1^3 X^j, Y=⋃_j=1^3 Y^j and C^j_i=C∩ D^j_i. A codeword which does not belong to Y is called a corner , and a fellow is a codeword belonging to Y such that it has another codeword in its open neighbourhood.

Let C be a code in K_q^3 and i be an integer such that 1≤ i≤ q. Define an x_iB_MATH_TERM of the graph K_q^3, denoted by D^1_i, as the set of vertices which fixes the coordinate x=i, i.e., D^1_i={(i,y,z)| 1≤ y,z≤ q}. Define then X^j_i = { v ∈ D_i^j | I(C;v)∩ D^j_i=∅} and Y_i^j = { v ∈ D_i^j | I(C;v)∩ D^j_i= { v }}. 
Furthermore, we use the following notation: X^j=⋃_i=1^q X_i^j, Y^j=⋃_i=1^q Y_i^j and X=⋃_j=1^3 X^j, Y=⋃_j=1^3 Y^j and C^j_i=C∩ D^j_i. A codeword which does not belong to Y is called a corner , and a fellow is a codeword belonging to Y such that it has another codeword in its open neighbourhood.

def:
\label{def:classical}
A \emph{classical parking function} of length $n$ is a sequence $s \in [n]^n$ such that for all $i \in [n]$,
\[
|\{j : s_j \geq i\}| \leq n-i+1.
\]
Additionally, we may consider the case when $m \leq n$ drivers attempt to park. We call these $(n,m)$-parking functions and the definition is the same as in the classical case for $s \in [n]^m$.

% If the sequence $s$ is such that $s_i \leq s_{i+1}$ for all $i \geq 1$, we say the parking function is \emph{increasing} .
plain_text_def:
A classical parking function of length n is a sequence s ∈ [n]^n such that for all i ∈ [n],

    |{j : s_j ≥ i}| ≤ n-i+1.

Additionally, we may consider the case when m ≤ n drivers attempt to park. We call these (n,m)-parking functions and the definition is the same as in the classical case for s ∈ [n]^m.
masked_plain_text_def:
A classical parking function of length n is a sequence s ∈ [n]^n such that for all i ∈ [n],

    |{j : s_j ≥ i}| ≤ n-i+1.

Additionally, we may consider the case when m ≤ n drivers attempt to park. We call these (n,m)-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM and the definition is the same as in the classical case for s ∈ [n]^m.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
For ϵ>0, d>0 and Δ>0,  consider a graph  G=(V,E)  of maximum degree at most Δ.
We say that G admits a “sparse block partition" B= B(ϵ,  d, Δ) 
 if  V can be partitioned  into the set of blocks  B for which  the following is true:


  * Every B∈ B is a tree with at most one extra edge.

  * Each vertex v in the outer boundary of a multi-vertex block B has the following  properties:


  * v is an r-breakpoint for r> max{ diam(B),  loglog n },

  * v has exactly one neighbor inside B,

  * if B contains a cycle C, then 
(v,C)≥max{2  log(|C| Δ), loglog d/log d( |C|+logΔ) }


  * Each vertex u∈ B, for any B∈ B, 
does not belong to any cycle of length <d^2.
masked_plain_text_def:
For ϵ>0, d>0 and Δ>0,  consider a graph  G=(V,E)  of maximum degree at most Δ.
We say that G admits a “B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM" B= B(ϵ,  d, Δ) 
 if  V can be partitioned  into the set of blocks  B for which  the following is true:


  * Every B∈ B is a tree with at most one extra edge.

  * Each vertex v in the outer boundary of a multi-vertex block B has the following  properties:


  * v is an r-breakpoint for r> max{ diam(B),  loglog n },

  * v has exactly one neighbor inside B,

  * if B contains a cycle C, then 
(v,C)≥max{2  log(|C| Δ), loglog d/log d( |C|+logΔ) }


  * Each vertex u∈ B, for any B∈ B, 
does not belong to any cycle of length <d^2.

def:
\label{densitydef}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Let $\k_1\le \k_2\le \l$ be cardinals. A set $\mathcal D\su
[\l]^{\k_1}$ is \emph{dense in $[\l]^{\k_2}$} if for every
  $X\in [\l]^{\k_2}$ there is $Y\in \mathcal D$ such that $Y\su X$.
\item For $\k_1\le\k_2\le
 \l$ the \emph{$(\k_1,\k_2)$-density of $\l$} , denoted by $\mathcal
 D(\theta,\k_1,\k_2)$,  is  the least
 cardinality of a set $\mathcal D\su [\theta]^{\k_1}$ which is dense
 in $[\l]^{\k_2}$.
\item For $\k\le$ the \emph{$\k$-density of $\l$} , denoted by
  $\mathcal D(\l,\k)$,  is  $\mathcal
  D(\l,\k,\k)$. 
\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
* Let _̨1≤_̨2≤ł be cardinals. A set 𝒟
[ł]^_̨1 is dense in [ł]^_̨2 if for every
  X∈ [ł]^_̨2 there is Y∈𝒟 such that Y X.

  * For _̨1≤_̨2≤ł the (_̨1,_̨2)-density of ł , denoted by 𝒟(θ,_̨1,_̨2),  is  the least
 cardinality of a set 𝒟 [θ]^_̨1 which is dense
 in [ł]^_̨2.

  * For ≤̨ the $̨-density ofł, denoted by𝒟(ł,)̨,  is𝒟(ł,,̨)̨.
masked_plain_text_def:
* Let _̨1≤_̨2≤ł be cardinals. A set 𝒟
[ł]^_̨1 is dense in [ł]^_̨2 if for every
  X∈ [ł]^_̨2 there is Y∈𝒟 such that Y X.

  * For _̨1≤_̨2≤ł the (_̨1,_̨2)-B_MATH_TERM of ł , denoted by 𝒟(θ,_̨1,_̨2),  is  the least
 cardinality of a set 𝒟 [θ]^_̨1 which is dense
 in [ł]^_̨2.

  * For ≤̨ the $̨-B_MATH_TERM ofł, denoted by𝒟(ł,)̨,  is𝒟(ł,,̨)̨.

def: A path $u_1u_2\ldots u_l$ in $G$ is said to be a ``decreasing path'' if for $2\leq i\leq l$, $\alpha(u_i)<\alpha(u_{i-1})$ and $\beta(u_i)<\beta(u_{i-1})$.
plain_text_def: A path u_1u_2… u_l in G is said to be a “decreasing path” if for 2≤ i≤ l, α(u_i)<α(u_i-1) and β(u_i)<β(u_i-1).
masked_plain_text_def: A path u_1u_2… u_l in G is said to be a “B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM” if for 2≤ i≤ l, α(u_i)<α(u_i-1) and β(u_i)<β(u_i-1).
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
[\cite{Stoj1}]
If
$\overrightarrow{SD}=a\text{\textbf{\emph{i}}}+b\text{\textbf{\emph{j}}}+c\text{\textbf{\emph{k}}}$,
then
$$
|\overrightarrow{SD}|=\min(|a-c|+|b-c|,|a-b|+|b-c|,|a-b|+|a-c|).
$$
plain_text_def:
[<cit.>]
If
SD=ai+bj+ck,
then

    |SD|=min(|a-c|+|b-c|,|a-b|+|b-c|,|a-b|+|a-c|).
masked_plain_text_def:
[<cit.>]
If
SD=aB_MATH_TERM+bB_MATH_TERM+cB_MATH_TERM,
then

    |SD|=min(|a-c|+|b-c|,|a-b|+|b-c|,|a-b|+|a-c|).
labeled_def: O O O O O

def:
Given a vertex $v$, we call the rectangle of side $(a,b)$ starting at $v$
the set $R^v_{a,b}=\{v+ \alpha\text{\emph{\textbf{i}}} + \beta
\text{\emph{\textbf{j}}}, 0\leq \alpha < a, 0\leq \beta < b\}$. We call
such a rectangle a square if $a=b$. Notice that in the triangular grid the
node set is generated by
$\{\emph{\textbf{i}},\emph{\textbf{j}},\emph{\textbf{k}}\}$, where
$\emph{\textbf{k}}= -\emph{\textbf{i}} - \emph{\textbf{j}}$, as we have
explained in Section \ref{sec:tri}.
plain_text_def:
Given a vertex v, we call the rectangle of side (a,b) starting at v
the set R^v_a,b={v+ αi + βj, 0≤α < a, 0≤β < b}. We call
such a rectangle a square if a=b. Notice that in the triangular grid the
node set is generated by
{i,j,k}, where
k= -i - j, as we have
explained in Section <ref>.
masked_plain_text_def:
Given a vertex v, we call the rectangle of side (a,b) starting at v
the set R^v_a,b={v+ αB_MATH_TERM + βB_MATH_TERM, 0≤α < a, 0≤β < b}. We call
such a rectangle a square if a=b. Notice that in the triangular grid the
node set is generated by
{B_MATH_TERM,B_MATH_TERM,B_MATH_TERM}, where
B_MATH_TERM= -B_MATH_TERM - B_MATH_TERM, as we have
explained in Section <ref>.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def: The original distance L_m/2 of the m^th BFB fold from the end of the structure is the shortest distance of any subsequent copy of that fold to either end. If L_n<L_m  and n>m then all copies of the m^th BFB fold are permanently excised from the BFB product. Thus if the m^th BFB fold is to avoid extinction through a series of N BFBs then L_m<min_{n>m}L_n. Subsequently, if we have a series L_1,L_2,...,L_N of BFB lengths, the only BFB folds that survive will be a subset with increasing length, in the same order that they occurred.
masked_plain_text_def: The original distance L_m/2 of the m^B_MATH_TERM BFB fold from the end of the structure is the shortest distance of any subsequent copy of that fold to either end. If L_n<L_m  and n>m then all copies of the m^B_MATH_TERM BFB fold are permanently excised from the BFB product. Thus if the m^B_MATH_TERM BFB fold is to avoid extinction through a series of N BFBs then L_m<min_{n>m}L_n. Subsequently, if we have a series L_1,L_2,...,L_N of BFB lengths, the only BFB folds that survive will be a subset with increasing length, in the same order that they occurred.

def:
The probability density $M_{k,N}(x,L)$ that the $k^{\emph{th}}$ BFB of a series $L_1,L_2,...,L_N$ is the minimum with length $x$ is given by

$M_{k,N}(x,L)=\frac{1}{2^{k}L}W_k(x,L)(1-\sum_{i=1}^{N-k}\frac{1}{2^i}W_i(x,x))$

where $L$ is the original length and,

$W_k(x,y)=\int_x^{2y}\int_x^{2z_1}...\int_x^{2z_{k-1}}\frac{1}{z_1...z_k}dz_k...dz_1 = \sum_{j=0}^{k}a_{j+1}^k(x) \log^j(2^ky)$,

$a^k$ is the $k+1$ length vector $\prod_{r=1}^kB_r$, and $B_r$ is the $(r+1) \times r$ matrix

$
\left( 
\begin{array}{c c c c c}
-\log(2^{r-1}x) & -\frac{1}{2}\log^2(2^{r-1}x) & \cdots & -\frac{1}{r}\log^r(2^{r-1}x) \\
1 & 0 & \cdots & 0 \\
0 & \frac{1}{2} & \cdots & 0\\
\vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\
0 & 0 & \cdots & \frac{1}{r}\\
 \end{array} 
\right)
$
\label{OrderTheorem}
\QED
plain_text_def:
The probability density M_k,N(x,L) that the k^th BFB of a series L_1,L_2,...,L_N is the minimum with length x is given by

M_k,N(x,L)=1/2^kLW_k(x,L)(1-∑_i=1^N-k1/2^iW_i(x,x))

where L is the original length and,

W_k(x,y)=∫_x^2y∫_x^2z_1...∫_x^2z_k-11/z_1...z_kdz_k...dz_1 = ∑_j=0^ka_j+1^k(x) log^j(2^ky),

a^k is the k+1 length vector ∏_r=1^kB_r, and B_r is the (r+1) × r matrix

( 
[      -log(2^r-1x) -1/2log^2(2^r-1x)                 ⋯ -1/rlog^r(2^r-1x);                 1                 0                 ⋯                 0;                 0               1/2                 ⋯                 0;                 ⋮                 ⋮                 ⋱                 ⋮;                 0                 0                 ⋯               1/r;                   ])
masked_plain_text_def:
The probability density M_k,N(x,L) that the k^B_MATH_TERM BFB of a series L_1,L_2,...,L_N is the minimum with length x is given by

M_k,N(x,L)=1/2^kLW_k(x,L)(1-∑_i=1^N-k1/2^iW_i(x,x))

where L is the original length and,

W_k(x,y)=∫_x^2y∫_x^2z_1...∫_x^2z_k-11/z_1...z_kdz_k...dz_1 = ∑_j=0^ka_j+1^k(x) log^j(2^ky),

a^k is the k+1 length vector ∏_r=1^kB_r, and B_r is the (r+1) × r matrix

( 
[      -log(2^r-1x) -1/2log^2(2^r-1x)                 ⋯ -1/rlog^r(2^r-1x);                 1                 0                 ⋯                 0;                 0               1/2                 ⋯                 0;                 ⋮                 ⋮                 ⋱                 ⋮;                 0                 0                 ⋯               1/r;                   ])

plain_text_def:
For a non-simply-laced diagram we define elementary transformations or moves. A move _i is a map sending a labaling å to another labeling å' defined as follows

    å' = _i(å)    a'_j = a_j     j  i  , 
     a'_i = a_i + ∑_k≥ a_k     j=i  ,

where k runs on the neighbors of the vertex i excluding shorter neighbors with even multiple edges, and the summation is done modulo 2. As in the previous case, the move _i can change only the vertex i.
masked_plain_text_def:
For a non-simply-laced diagram we define elementary transformations or B_MATH_TERM. A move _i is a map sending a labaling å to another labeling å' defined as follows

    å' = _i(å)    a'_j = a_j     j  i  , 
     a'_i = a_i + ∑_k≥ a_k     j=i  ,

where k runs on the neighbors of the vertex i excluding shorter neighbors with even multiple edges, and the summation is done modulo 2. As in the previous case, the move _i can change only the vertex i.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
For $k,h\in\N$ with $h>1$, the $(h,k)$-\emph{recurrence set} of $A$ is the following set
of $h$-tuples:
$$R_{k}^{h}(A)=\left\{\{t_1<\ldots<t_h\}\in[\N]^h\,\big|\,
|(A+t_1)\cap\ldots\cap(A+t_h)|\ge k\right\}.$$
plain_text_def:
For k,h∈ with h>1, the (h,k)-recurrence set of A is the following set
of h-tuples:

    R_k^h(A)={{t_1<…<t_h}∈[]^h | 
    |(A+t_1)∩…∩(A+t_h)|≥ k}.
masked_plain_text_def:
For k,h∈ with h>1, the (h,k)-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM of A is the following set
of h-tuples:

    R_k^h(A)={{t_1<…<t_h}∈[]^h | 
    |(A+t_1)∩…∩(A+t_h)|≥ k}.
labeled_def: O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
[TSO-padding (new)]
Given a finite width tree structured order with tree/expression \begin{math}T\end{math},
 let \begin{math}l\end{math} be an integer such that \begin{math}2^l\end{math} is greater than
  the maximum number of \begin{math}\Lex\end{math} nodes on a path from a leaf of \begin{math}T\end{math} to its root;
 let \begin{math}c\end{math} be an integer such that \begin{math}2^c\end{math} is greater than
  the maximum number of \begin{math}\ContreLex\end{math} nodes on a path from a leaf of \begin{math}T\end{math} to its root.
A \begin{math}l\end{math}-lex-padding is a set of \begin{math}l\end{math} contiguous bits that will serve as a counter for \begin{math}\Lex\end{math} nodes.
A \begin{math}c\end{math}-contrelex-padding is a set of \begin{math}c\end{math} contiguous bits that will serve as a counter for \begin{math}\ContreLex\end{math} nodes.
A \begin{math}(l,c)\end{math}-\emph{TSO-padding} is a \begin{math}l\end{math}-lex-padding
and a \begin{math}c\end{math}-contrelex-padding that are contiguous.
plain_text_def:
[TSO-padding (new)]
Given a finite width tree structured order with tree/expression T,
 let l be an integer such that 2^l is greater than
  the maximum number of  nodes on a path from a leaf of T to its root;
 let c be an integer such that 2^c is greater than
  the maximum number of  nodes on a path from a leaf of T to its root.
A l-lex-padding is a set of l contiguous bits that will serve as a counter for  nodes.
A c-contrelex-padding is a set of c contiguous bits that will serve as a counter for  nodes.
A (l,c)-TSO-padding is a l-lex-padding
and a c-contrelex-padding that are contiguous.
masked_plain_text_def:
[TSO-padding (new)]
Given a finite width tree structured order with tree/expression T,
 let l be an integer such that 2^l is greater than
  the maximum number of  nodes on a path from a leaf of T to its root;
 let c be an integer such that 2^c is greater than
  the maximum number of  nodes on a path from a leaf of T to its root.
A l-lex-padding is a set of l contiguous bits that will serve as a counter for  nodes.
A c-contrelex-padding is a set of c contiguous bits that will serve as a counter for  nodes.
A (l,c)-B_MATH_TERM is a l-lex-padding
and a c-contrelex-padding that are contiguous.

def:
Let $r$ and $k$ be positive integers and \(G=(V,E)\) be a graph. Let 
\(X\subset V\) and \(F \subset E\).
	We say that \(F\) is an \emph{\((X,r,k)\)-factor} of 
\(G\) if, for every \(v\in X\), we have \(d_F(v) = (r/k)d_G(v)\).
plain_text_def:
Let r and k be positive integers and G=(V,E) be a graph. Let 
X⊂ V and F ⊂ E.
	We say that F is an (X,r,k)-factor of 
G if, for every v∈ X, we have d_F(v) = (r/k)d_G(v).
masked_plain_text_def:
Let r and k be positive integers and G=(V,E) be a graph. Let 
X⊂ V and F ⊂ E.
	We say that F is an (X,r,k)-B_MATH_TERM of 
G if, for every v∈ X, we have d_F(v) = (r/k)d_G(v).
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
Let k and ℓ be positive integers such that k-ℓ is a 
positive even number. Let G=(V,E) be a graph and let X⊂ V.
We say that a partition ℱ={M_1,…,M_ℓ,F_1,…,F_(k-ℓ)/2} of E is an 
(X,ℓ,k)-fractional factorization of G if the following holds.
	
		
  * M_i is an (X,1,k)-factor of G, for 1≤ i≤ℓ;
		
  * F_j is an Eulerian (X,2,k)-factor of G, for 1≤ j≤ (k-ℓ)/2.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let k and ℓ be positive integers such that k-ℓ is a 
positive even number. Let G=(V,E) be a graph and let X⊂ V.
We say that a partition ℱ={M_1,…,M_ℓ,F_1,…,F_(k-ℓ)/2} of E is an 
(X,ℓ,k)-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM of G if the following holds.
	
		
  * M_i is an (X,1,k)-factor of G, for 1≤ i≤ℓ;
		
  * F_j is an Eulerian (X,2,k)-factor of G, for 1≤ j≤ (k-ℓ)/2.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{def:bip-factor}
Let \(k\) and \(\ell\) be positive integers such that $k-\ell$ is a positive 
even number, and let \(G=(A_1,A_2;E)\) be a bipartite graph. 

Let \(\mathcal{F}_1,\mathcal{F}_2\) be families of subsets of \(E\)
and put \(G_i = G[\cup_{F\in\mathcal{F}_i}F]\), for \(i=1,2\).
We say that \(\mathbb{F}=(\mathcal{F}_1,\mathcal{F}_2)\) is an 
\emph{\((\ell,k)\)-bifactorization of \(G\)}
if the following holds.
\begin{itemize}
 \item [(i)] \(\{G_1,G_2\}\) is a decomposition of \(G\) ;
 \item [(ii)] \(\mathcal{F}_i\) is an \((A_i,\ell,k)\)-fractional 
factorization of $G_i$, for $1\leq i\leq 2$.
\end{itemize}
%Furthermore, if there exists an \((\ell,k)\)-bifactorization of \(G\), then we 
%say that \(G\) \emph{admits an 
%\((\ell,k)\)-bifactorization} or that \(G\) is \emph{\((\ell,k)\)-bifactorable} .
If \(G\) admits an \((\ell,k)\)-bifactorization,
we say that \(G\) is \((\ell,k)\)-bifactorable.
plain_text_def:
Let k and ℓ be positive integers such that k-ℓ is a positive 
even number, and let G=(A_1,A_2;E) be a bipartite graph. 

Let ℱ_1,ℱ_2 be families of subsets of E
and put G_i = G[∪_F∈ℱ_iF], for i=1,2.
We say that 𝔽=(ℱ_1,ℱ_2) is an 
(ℓ,k)-bifactorization of G
if the following holds.

 
  (i) {G_1,G_2} is a decomposition of G ;
 
  (ii) ℱ_i is an (A_i,ℓ,k)-fractional 
factorization of G_i, for 1≤ i≤ 2.




If G admits an (ℓ,k)-bifactorization,
we say that G is (ℓ,k)-bifactorable.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let k and ℓ be positive integers such that k-ℓ is a positive 
even number, and let G=(A_1,A_2;E) be a bipartite graph. 

Let ℱ_1,ℱ_2 be families of subsets of E
and put G_i = G[∪_F∈ℱ_iF], for i=1,2.
We say that 𝔽=(ℱ_1,ℱ_2) is an 
(ℓ,k)-B_MATH_TERM of G
if the following holds.

 
  (i) {G_1,G_2} is a decomposition of G ;
 
  (ii) ℱ_i is an (A_i,ℓ,k)-fractional 
factorization of G_i, for 1≤ i≤ 2.




If G admits an (ℓ,k)-B_MATH_TERM,
we say that G is (ℓ,k)-bifactorable.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{Hi-chain}Let $v_{i}\in H_{i}$, for some $i\geq 1$. Then, a sequence $%
(v_{0},v_{1},\ldots ,v_{i-1},v_{i})$ of vertices, such that $v_{j}\in H_{j}$%
, $j=0,1,\ldots ,i-1$, and $v_{j-1}v_{j}\notin E$, $j=1,2,\ldots ,i$, is an $%
H_{i}$\emph{-chain} of $v_{i}$.
plain_text_def:
Let v_i∈ H_i, for some i≥ 1. Then, a sequence (v_0,v_1,… ,v_i-1,v_i) of vertices, such that v_j∈ H_j
, j=0,1,… ,i-1, and v_j-1v_j∉ E, j=1,2,… ,i, is an H_i-chain of v_i.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let v_i∈ H_i, for some i≥ 1. Then, a sequence (v_0,v_1,… ,v_i-1,v_i) of vertices, such that v_j∈ H_j
, j=0,1,… ,i-1, and v_j-1v_j∉ E, j=1,2,… ,i, is an H_iB_MATH_TERM of v_i.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{d.protected}
Given $X\sbs [0,t]^d$ and $Y=\{y_1,y_2,\dots,y_K\}\sbs \Re^d$, we say $X$ is $(R,\e)$-\emph{protected} by $Y$ at $p$ if 
\[
X\cap (B(p,R)\stm B(p,1))= Y'\approx_\e (Y+p)\quad\text{and}\quad Y'\sbs B(p,\sqrt R).
\]
plain_text_def:
Given X [0,t]^d and Y={y_1,y_2,…,y_K}^d, we say X is (R,)-protected by Y at p if 

    X∩ (B(p,R) B(p,1))= Y'≈_ (Y+p)  and   Y' B(p,√(R)).
masked_plain_text_def:
Given X [0,t]^d and Y={y_1,y_2,…,y_K}^d, we say X is (R,)-B_MATH_TERM by Y at p if 

    X∩ (B(p,R) B(p,1))= Y'≈_ (Y+p)  and   Y' B(p,√(R)).
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def: Let $f(z) = \sum_{n=0}^\infty a(n) q^n$ and $g(z) = \sum_{n=0}^\infty b(n) q^n$ both be modular forms in $M_k(\Gamma_0(N),\chi)$ for some positive integer $N$ and character $\chi$.  If $$p \vert (a(n) - b(n)) \quad \forall \quad 0 \leq n \leq \frac{k}{12} N \cdot \prod_{d \, \text{\emph{prime}}: d \vert N} \left(1+\frac{1}{d}\right),$$ then $f(z) \equiv g(z)$ mod $p$.
plain_text_def:
Let f(z) = ∑_n=0^∞ a(n) q^n and g(z) = ∑_n=0^∞ b(n) q^n both be modular forms in M_k(Γ_0(N),χ) for some positive integer N and character χ.  If 
    p | (a(n) - b(n))   ∀   0 ≤ n ≤k/12 N ·∏_d  prime: d | N(1+1/d),
 then f(z) ≡ g(z) mod p.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let f(z) = ∑_n=0^∞ a(n) q^n and g(z) = ∑_n=0^∞ b(n) q^n both be modular forms in M_k(Γ_0(N),χ) for some positive integer N and character χ.  If 
    p | (a(n) - b(n))   ∀   0 ≤ n ≤k/12 N ·∏_d  B_MATH_TERM: d | N(1+1/d),
 then f(z) ≡ g(z) mod p.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{df2}
Let $\Delta$ be a $(d-1)$-dimensional pure simplicial complex. For any $i=1,\dots,n$ we define the graph $G^i(\Delta)$ as follow:
\begin{itemize}
\item [-] The set of vertices is $V(G^i(\Delta))=\{V_i\}\cup \{F\in \Im (\Delta): v_i\notin F\},$ where $V_i$ is a new vertex.
\item [-] The set of egdes  is
$$E(G^i(\Delta))=
 \{\{F,G\}:  |F\cap G|=d-1\}\cup $$
$$
\{\{V_i,F\}:\text { there exists a facet } G\ni v_i \text{ and } |G\cap F|=d-1\}.
$$
\end{itemize}
The graph $G^i(\Delta)$ is called the $v_i$-\textit{graph} of $\Delta.$
plain_text_def:
Let Δ be a (d-1)-dimensional pure simplicial complex. For any i=1,…,n we define the graph G^i(Δ) as follow:


  - The set of vertices is V(G^i(Δ))={V_i}∪{F∈ (Δ): v_i∉ F}, where V_i is a new vertex.

  - The set of egdes  is

    E(G^i(Δ))=
     {{F,G}:  |F∩ G|=d-1}∪


    {{V_i,F}: there exists a facet  G∋ v_i  and  |G∩ F|=d-1}.


The graph G^i(Δ) is called the v_i-graph of Δ.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let Δ be a (d-1)-dimensional pure simplicial complex. For any i=1,…,n we define the graph G^i(Δ) as follow:


  - The set of vertices is V(G^i(Δ))={V_i}∪{F∈ (Δ): v_i∉ F}, where V_i is a new vertex.

  - The set of egdes  is

    E(G^i(Δ))=
     {{F,G}:  |F∩ G|=d-1}∪


    {{V_i,F}: there exists a facet  G∋ v_i  and  |G∩ F|=d-1}.


The graph G^i(Δ) is called the v_i-B_MATH_TERM of Δ.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
Let G be a ∂-graph on  with a lensless nondegeneral medial strand arrangement ℳ.  Suppose P and Q are a circular pair corresponding to boundary arcs D_1 and D_2.  Then the IO-graph morphism [G,i,j]: P → Q represented by G admits an embedded elementary factorization.  Hence, the rank-connection principle holds for P and Q for any network Γ on G.  Moreover,

	
  * X([Γ,i,j]) = 2m(P,Q) = #(transverse strands) + |P ∩ Q|.
	
  * X([Γ,i,j]) = #(input stubs) = # (D_1-reentrant strands).
	
  * X([Γ,i,j]) = #(output stubs) = #(D_2-reentrant strands).
masked_plain_text_def:
Let G be a ∂-graph on  with a lensless nondegeneral medial strand arrangement ℳ.  Suppose P and Q are a circular pair corresponding to boundary arcs D_1 and D_2.  Then the IO-graph morphism [G,i,j]: P → Q represented by G admits an embedded elementary factorization.  Hence, the rank-connection principle holds for P and Q for any network Γ on G.  Moreover,

	
  * X([Γ,i,j]) = 2m(P,Q) = #B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM + |P ∩ Q|.
	
  * X([Γ,i,j]) = #(B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM) = # (D_1B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM).
	
  * X([Γ,i,j]) = #(B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM) = #(D_2B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM).
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
A function ν : _N → [0,∞) satisfies the
  k-linear forms condition[As in the footnote to
    Definition <ref>, in our proof of
    Theorem <ref> we will make the simplifying assumption
    that N is coprime to
    (k-1)!. In the proof of the Green-Tao
    theorem, one can always make this assumption.] if
  
    _x_1^(0), x_1^(1), …, x_k^(0),x_k^(1)∈_N[
        ∏_j=1^k ∏_ω∈{0,1}^[k]∖{j}ν( ∑_i=1^k (j-i) x_i^(ω_i))^n_j,ω]  = 1 + o(1)

  for any choice of exponents n_j,ω∈{0,1}.
masked_plain_text_def:
A function ν : _N → [0,∞) satisfies the
  k-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM[As in the footnote to
    Definition <ref>, in our proof of
    Theorem <ref> we will make the simplifying assumption
    that N is coprime to
    (k-1)!. In the proof of the Green-Tao
    theorem, one can always make this assumption.] if
  
    _x_1^(0), x_1^(1), …, x_k^(0),x_k^(1)∈_N[
        ∏_j=1^k ∏_ω∈{0,1}^[k]∖{j}ν( ∑_i=1^k (j-i) x_i^(ω_i))^n_j,ω]  = 1 + o(1)

  for any choice of exponents n_j,ω∈{0,1}.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
Given $\epsilon>0$ and disjoint subsets $A, B$ of the vertex set of a graph $G$, we say that the pair $(A, B)$ is $\epsilon$\textit{-regular in} $G$  if, for every pair $(A', B')$ with $A'\subseteq A$, $|A'|\geq \epsilon |A|$, $B' \subseteq B$, $|B'|\geq \epsilon |B|$, we have
$$ 
 \left| d(A',B')-d(A,B)\right| <\epsilon.
$$
When there is no danger of confusion, we simply say that the pair $(A,B)$ is $\eps$-regular.
plain_text_def:
Given ϵ>0 and disjoint subsets A, B of the vertex set of a graph G, we say that the pair (A, B) is ϵ-regular in G  if, for every pair (A', B') with A'⊆ A, |A'|≥ϵ |A|, B' ⊆ B, |B'|≥ϵ |B|, we have

    | d(A',B')-d(A,B)| <ϵ.

When there is no danger of confusion, we simply say that the pair (A,B) is -regular.
masked_plain_text_def:
Given ϵ>0 and disjoint subsets A, B of the vertex set of a graph G, we say that the pair (A, B) is ϵB_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM G  if, for every pair (A', B') with A'⊆ A, |A'|≥ϵ |A|, B' ⊆ B, |B'|≥ϵ |B|, we have

    | d(A',B')-d(A,B)| <ϵ.

When there is no danger of confusion, we simply say that the pair (A,B) is -regular.

plain_text_def:
Let M be a mixed graph with vertex set V(M)={v_1,v_2,…,v_n} and d_k is the degree of v_k, k=1,2,…,n. Let H(M) and R_H(M) be the Hermitian-adjacency matrix and Hermitian-Randić matrix of M, respectively. If M has isolated vertices, then detH(M)=detR_H(M)=0. If M has no isolated vertices, then

    detR_H(M)=1/d_1d_2⋯ d_ndetH(M).
masked_plain_text_def:
Let M be a mixed graph with vertex set V(M)={v_1,v_2,…,v_n} and d_k is the degree of v_k, k=1,2,…,n. Let H(M) and R_H(M) be the Hermitian-adjacency matrix and Hermitian-Randić matrix of M, respectively. If M has isolated vertices, then B_MATH_TERMH(M)=B_MATH_TERMR_H(M)=0. If M has no isolated vertices, then

    B_MATH_TERMR_H(M)=1/d_1d_2⋯ d_nB_MATH_TERMH(M).

plain_text_def:
Let M be a mixed graph of order n and μ_1≥μ_2≥⋯≥μ_n be the Hermitian-Randić spectrum of R_H(M). Let M_U be the underlying graph of M, p=|detR_H(M)|. Then 
    √(2R_-1(M_U)+n(n-1)p^2/n)≤ℰ_R_H(M)≤√(2nR_-1(M_U)),

with equalities hold both in the lower bound and upper bound if and only if there exists a constant c=|μ_i|^2 for all i such that R^2_H(M)=c I_n.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let M be a mixed graph of order n and μ_1≥μ_2≥⋯≥μ_n be the Hermitian-Randić spectrum of R_H(M). Let M_U be the underlying graph of M, p=|B_MATH_TERMR_H(M)|. Then 
    √(2R_-1(M_U)+n(n-1)p^2/n)≤ℰ_R_H(M)≤√(2nR_-1(M_U)),

with equalities hold both in the lower bound and upper bound if and only if there exists a constant c=|μ_i|^2 for all i such that R^2_H(M)=c B_MATH_TERM_n.

def:
[$\gamma$-compatible pair of matchings]
Assume that the tagged triangulation $T$ does not contain either $\zg$, $\zg^{(p)}$, or $\zg^{(q)}$.  Let $P_p$ and $P_q$ be $\gamma$-symmetric matchings of  $G_{T^\circ,\zLp}$ and $G_{T^\circ,\zLq}$, respectively.  By Lemma \ref{twoends}, without loss of generality, $P_p|_{G_{T^\circ,\zg_p,1}}$ and
$P_q|_{G_{T^\circ,\zg_q,1}}$ are perfect matchings.  We say that $(P_p,P_q)$ is a $\zg$-\emph{compatible} pair if the restrictions satisfy $$P_p|_{G_{T^\circ,\gamma_p,1}}
\cong P_q|_{G_{T^\circ,\gamma_q,1}}.$$
plain_text_def:
[γ-compatible pair of matchings]
Assume that the tagged triangulation T does not contain either , ^(p), or ^(q).  Let P_p and P_q be γ-symmetric matchings of  G_T^∘, and G_T^∘,, respectively.  By Lemma <ref>, without loss of generality, P_p|_G_T^∘,_p,1 and
P_q|_G_T^∘,_q,1 are perfect matchings.  We say that (P_p,P_q) is a -compatible pair if the restrictions satisfy 
    P_p|_G_T^∘,γ_p,1≅ P_q|_G_T^∘,γ_q,1.
masked_plain_text_def:
[γ-compatible pair of matchings]
Assume that the tagged triangulation T does not contain either , ^(p), or ^(q).  Let P_p and P_q be γ-symmetric matchings of  G_T^∘, and G_T^∘,, respectively.  By Lemma <ref>, without loss of generality, P_p|_G_T^∘,_p,1 and
P_q|_G_T^∘,_q,1 are perfect matchings.  We say that (P_p,P_q) is a -B_MATH_TERM pair if the restrictions satisfy 
    P_p|_G_T^∘,γ_p,1≅ P_q|_G_T^∘,γ_q,1.

def:
\label{quadrictheorem}
Let $f \in k[x^{\pm 1}, y^{\pm 1}]$ be non-degenerate with respect to its Newton polygon
 $\Delta = \Delta(f)$ and assume that $\Delta^{(1)}$ is two-dimensional. Then $U(f)$ is non-hyperelliptic
 and the Zariski closure of the image of (\ref{canonicalembedding}) is a canonical model of $U(f)$.
 If moreover $\Delta^{(2)} \neq \emptyset$, then the ideal of
 the latter is generated by $\mathcal{I}( \emph{Tor}(\Delta^{(1)}))$ and the quadrics $\{Q_w \}_{w \in \Delta^{(2)} \cap \mathbb{Z}^2}$
 described above.
plain_text_def:
Let f ∈ k[x^± 1, y^± 1] be non-degenerate with respect to its Newton polygon
 Δ = Δ(f) and assume that Δ^(1) is two-dimensional. Then U(f) is non-hyperelliptic
 and the Zariski closure of the image of (<ref>) is a canonical model of U(f).
 If moreover Δ^(2)≠∅, then the ideal of
 the latter is generated by ℐ( Tor(Δ^(1))) and the quadrics {Q_w }_w ∈Δ^(2)∩ℤ^2
 described above.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let f ∈ k[x^± 1, y^± 1] be non-degenerate with respect to its Newton polygon
 Δ = Δ(f) and assume that Δ^(1) is two-dimensional. Then U(f) is non-hyperelliptic
 and the Zariski closure of the image of (<ref>) is a canonical model of U(f).
 If moreover Δ^(2)≠∅, then the ideal of
 the latter is generated by ℐ( B_MATH_TERM(Δ^(1))) and the quadrics {Q_w }_w ∈Δ^(2)∩ℤ^2
 described above.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
Let f ∈ k[x^± 1,y^± 1] be non-degenerate with respect to its Newton polygon
 Δ = Δ(f) and suppose that ♯(Δ^(1)∩ℤ^2) ≥ 4. Then
 
   
  * if Δ^(1)≅ (d-3)Σ for d ≥ 5 then ci(U(f)) = d-4 and cd(U(f)) = 2,
   
  * if Δ^(1)≅Υ then ci(U(f)) = 1 and cd(U(f)) = 1,
   
  * if Δ^(1)≅ 2Υ then ci(U(f)) = 3 and cd(U(f)) = 3,
   
  * in all other cases ci(U(f)) = lw(Δ^(1)) and cd(U(f)) = 1.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let f ∈ k[x^± 1,y^± 1] be non-degenerate with respect to its Newton polygon
 Δ = Δ(f) and suppose that ♯(Δ^(1)∩ℤ^2) ≥ 4. Then
 
   
  * if Δ^(1)≅ (d-3)Σ for d ≥ 5 then B_MATH_TERM(U(f)) = d-4 and B_MATH_TERM(U(f)) = 2,
   
  * if Δ^(1)≅Υ then B_MATH_TERM(U(f)) = 1 and B_MATH_TERM(U(f)) = 1,
   
  * if Δ^(1)≅ 2Υ then B_MATH_TERM(U(f)) = 3 and B_MATH_TERM(U(f)) = 3,
   
  * in all other cases B_MATH_TERM(U(f)) = B_MATH_TERM(Δ^(1)) and B_MATH_TERM(U(f)) = 1.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{theorem_schreyer}
Let $f \in k[x^{\pm 1}, y^{\pm 1}]$ be non-degenerate with respect to its Newton polygon
$\Delta = \Delta(f)$. Suppose that $\emph{lw}(\Delta^{(1)}) = 2$ and that $\Delta \not \cong 2\Upsilon$.
Then $U(f)$ is tetragonal and Schreyer's invariants $b_1,b_2$ equal
\[ \sharp(\partial \Delta^{(1)} \cap \mathbb{Z}^2) - 4 \qquad \text{resp.} \qquad
\sharp (\Delta^{(2)} \cap \mathbb{Z}^2) - 1.\]
If moreover $b_1 > b_2$ then Schreyer's surface $\mu(Y)$ equals $\emph{Tor}(\Delta^{(1)})$ (assuming
that $U(f)$ is canonically embedded using (\ref{canonicalembedding})).
plain_text_def:
Let f ∈ k[x^± 1, y^± 1] be non-degenerate with respect to its Newton polygon
Δ = Δ(f). Suppose that lw(Δ^(1)) = 2 and that Δ≇2Υ.
Then U(f) is tetragonal and Schreyer's invariants b_1,b_2 equal

    ♯(∂Δ^(1)∩ℤ^2) - 4     resp.    ♯ (Δ^(2)∩ℤ^2) - 1.

If moreover b_1 > b_2 then Schreyer's surface μ(Y) equals Tor(Δ^(1)) (assuming
that U(f) is canonically embedded using (<ref>)).
masked_plain_text_def:
Let f ∈ k[x^± 1, y^± 1] be non-degenerate with respect to its Newton polygon
Δ = Δ(f). Suppose that B_MATH_TERM(Δ^(1)) = 2 and that Δ≇2Υ.
Then U(f) is tetragonal and Schreyer's invariants b_1,b_2 equal

    ♯(∂Δ^(1)∩ℤ^2) - 4     resp.    ♯ (Δ^(2)∩ℤ^2) - 1.

If moreover b_1 > b_2 then Schreyer's surface μ(Y) equals B_MATH_TERM(Δ^(1)) (assuming
that U(f) is canonically embedded using (<ref>)).
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{theorem_secondary}
Let $f, \Delta, g^1_\gamma$ and $E_1, \dots, E_{\gamma - 1}$ be as in the statement of Theorem~\ref{thm_maroni}.
Assume moreover that $\emph{lw}(\Delta) \geq 4$, that $\Delta^{(2)} \neq \emptyset$ and that $\Delta$ is well-aligned with respect to $(0,1)$. Let $B_\ell=-1+\sharp\{(i,j)\in \Delta^{(2)}\cap\mathbb{Z}^2\,|\,j=\ell\}$
for $\ell=2, \dots, \gamma - 2$.
Then the multiset of secondary scrollar invariants of $U(f)$ with respect to $g^1_\gamma$ is given by
\[ \{ E_{j_1 -1} + E_{j_2 + 1} - \epsilon_{j_1,j_2} \}_{2 \leq j_1 \leq j_2 \leq \gamma - 2} \quad \cup \quad  \{ B_\ell \}_{2 \leq \ell \leq \gamma - 2},\]
where the $\epsilon_{j_1,j_2}$'s are defined as in (\ref{defepsilons}).
plain_text_def:
Let f, Δ, g^1_γ and E_1, …, E_γ - 1 be as in the statement of Theorem <ref>.
Assume moreover that lw(Δ) ≥ 4, that Δ^(2)≠∅ and that Δ is well-aligned with respect to (0,1). Let B_ℓ=-1+♯{(i,j)∈Δ^(2)∩ℤ^2 | j=ℓ}
for ℓ=2, …, γ - 2.
Then the multiset of secondary scrollar invariants of U(f) with respect to g^1_γ is given by

    { E_j_1 -1 + E_j_2 + 1 - ϵ_j_1,j_2}_2 ≤ j_1 ≤ j_2 ≤γ - 2  ∪  { B_ℓ}_2 ≤ℓ≤γ - 2,

where the ϵ_j_1,j_2's are defined as in (<ref>).
masked_plain_text_def:
Let f, Δ, g^1_γ and E_1, …, E_γ - 1 be as in the statement of Theorem <ref>.
Assume moreover that B_MATH_TERM(Δ) ≥ 4, that Δ^(2)≠∅ and that Δ is well-aligned with respect to (0,1). Let B_ℓ=-1+♯{(i,j)∈Δ^(2)∩ℤ^2 | j=ℓ}
for ℓ=2, …, γ - 2.
Then the multiset of secondary scrollar invariants of U(f) with respect to g^1_γ is given by

    { E_j_1 -1 + E_j_2 + 1 - ϵ_j_1,j_2}_2 ≤ j_1 ≤ j_2 ≤γ - 2  ∪  { B_ℓ}_2 ≤ℓ≤γ - 2,

where the ϵ_j_1,j_2's are defined as in (<ref>).
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
Let $n$ be a positive integer. Let $f:\left\{  1,2,\ldots,n\right\}
\rightarrow\left\{  1,2,\ldots,n\right\}  $ be any map such that $f\left(
n\right)  =n$.

We say that the map $f$ is $n$\textit{-potent} if for every $i\in\left\{
1,2,\ldots,n\right\}  $, there exists some $k\in\mathbb{N}$ such that
$f^{k}\left(  i\right)  =n$. (In less formal terms, $f$ is $n$-potent if and
only if every element of $\left\{  1,2,\ldots,n\right\}  $ eventually arrives
at $n$ when being subjected to repeated application of $f$.)
plain_text_def:
Let n be a positive integer. Let f:{  1,2,…,n}→{  1,2,…,n} be any map such that f(
n)  =n.

We say that the map f is n-potent if for every i∈{
1,2,…,n}, there exists some k∈ℕ such that
f^k(  i)  =n. (In less formal terms, f is n-potent if and
only if every element of {  1,2,…,n} eventually arrives
at n when being subjected to repeated application of f.)
masked_plain_text_def:
Let n be a positive integer. Let f:{  1,2,…,n}→{  1,2,…,n} be any map such that f(
n)  =n.

We say that the map f is nB_MATH_TERM if for every i∈{
1,2,…,n}, there exists some k∈ℕ such that
f^k(  i)  =n. (In less formal terms, f is n-potent if and
only if every element of {  1,2,…,n} eventually arrives
at n when being subjected to repeated application of f.)

def:
\label{def:permflag}
A permutation $\tau$-\emph{flag} $S^{\tau}$ is a permutation $S$ together with a distinguished subpermutation $\tau$, also called an intersection \emph{type} .
plain_text_def: A permutation τ-flag S^τ is a permutation S together with a distinguished subpermutation τ, also called an intersection type .
masked_plain_text_def: A permutation τ-B_MATH_TERM S^τ is a permutation S together with a distinguished subpermutation τ, also called an intersection type .
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
Let $G=(V,E)$ be a connected graph. Define 
\begin{eqnarray*}
R_1(G)&=&\{v\in V: \emph{comp}(G-v)=2, \; p(v)=1\}\\
R_2(G)&=&\{v\in V: \emph{comp}(G-v)=2, \; p(v)=0\}\\
R_3(G)&=&\{v\in V: \emph{comp}(G-v)\geq 3\}\\
%R_4(G)&=&\{v\in V: p(v)\geq 1\}\\
%\mathcal{L}(G)&=&\bigcup_{v\in V}\{\text{an arbitrary all-but-one elements of } L(v;\bar{G})\}\\
\mathcal{L}(G)&=&\bigcup_{v\in V}\{\text{all-but-one bases of pendant paths attached to } v\}\\
M(G)&=&R_2(G)\cup R_3(G)\cup \mathcal{L}(G). 
\end{eqnarray*} 
When there is no scope for confusion, the dependence on $G$ will be omitted.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
A graph $G = (\omega_1, E)$ is a \emph{Hajnal-M\'{a}t\'{e} graph} if, for
	all $\beta < \omega_1$, the set $N_G^{<}(\beta) := \{\alpha < \beta \mid
	\{\alpha, \beta\} \in E\}$ is either finite or a set of order type $\omega$
	converging to $\beta$.
plain_text_def:
A graph G = (ω_1, E) is a Hajnal-Máté graph if, for
	all β < ω_1, the set N_G^<(β) := {α < β|{α, β}∈ E} is either finite or a set of order type ω
	converging to β.
masked_plain_text_def:
A graph G = (ω_1, E) is a B_MATH_TERMté graph if, for
	all β < ω_1, the set N_G^<(β) := {α < β|{α, β}∈ E} is either finite or a set of order type ω
	converging to β.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
Let $M = \{x \in \bin \mid wt(x) \leq \frac{n}{2}\},$ where 
$wt(x)$ is the Hamming weight of $x$.  
We say that $\alpha \in \bin$ has the $\epsilon$-\emph{shifting property} if 
$M \cup (\alpha+M) \geq \left(\frac{1}{2}+\epsilon\right) 2^n$.
plain_text_def:
Let M = {x ∈| wt(x) ≤n/2}, where 
wt(x) is the Hamming weight of x.  
We say that α∈ has the ϵ-shifting property if 
M ∪ (α+M) ≥(1/2+ϵ) 2^n.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let M = {x ∈| wt(x) ≤n/2}, where 
wt(x) is the Hamming weight of x.  
We say that α∈ has the ϵ-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM if 
M ∪ (α+M) ≥(1/2+ϵ) 2^n.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
Given λ∈ (0,1], γ∈  (0,1], and a graph G on N vertices, 
 we say that G is  (λ,γ)-supersaturated 
if for any subset S ⊆ V(G) with |S| ≥λ N, we have

    e(S)≥γ (|S|/N )^2 e(G).

In addition, let λ=λ(n)>0 and γ=γ(n)>0. A sequence 
{G_n}_n ∈ℕ is called (λ(n), γ(n))-supersaturated 
if G_n is 
(λ(n), γ(n))-supersaturated for each n ∈ℕ.
masked_plain_text_def:
Given λ∈ (0,1], γ∈  (0,1], and a graph G on N vertices, 
 we say that G is  (λ,γ)-B_MATH_TERM 
if for any subset S ⊆ V(G) with |S| ≥λ N, we have

    e(S)≥γ (|S|/N )^2 e(G).

In addition, let λ=λ(n)>0 and γ=γ(n)>0. A sequence 
{G_n}_n ∈ℕ is called (λ(n), γ(n))-B_MATH_TERM 
if G_n is 
(λ(n), γ(n))-B_MATH_TERM for each n ∈ℕ.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{d:supersaturated}
Given $\lambda$ and $\gamma$, we say that a graph $G$ is $(\lambda,\gamma)$-\emph{supersaturated} if
for any subset $S \subseteq V(G)$ with $|S| \geq \lambda N$, we have
\[e(S)\geq \gamma \left (\frac{|S|}{N} \right )^2e(G_n).\]
Further, given $\lambda = \lambda(n) \in [0,1]$, $\gamma = \gamma(n) \in  [0,1]$, and a sequence of graphs $\{G_n\}_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ on $N = N(n)$ vertices, 
we say that $\{G\}_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ is a $(\lambda$,$\gamma)$-\emph{supersaturated} graph if %where $e(S)$ denotes the number of edges in $G_n[S]$, and $e(G_n)$ denotes the total number of edges in $G_n$.
$G_n$ is $(\lambda(n),\gamma(n))$-supersaturated for all $n\in\mathbb{N}$.
plain_text_def:
Given λ and γ, we say that a graph G is (λ,γ)-supersaturated if
for any subset S ⊆ V(G) with |S| ≥λ N, we have

    e(S)≥γ (|S|/N )^2e(G_n).

Further, given λ = λ(n) ∈ [0,1], γ = γ(n) ∈  [0,1], and a sequence of graphs {G_n}_n ∈ℕ on N = N(n) vertices, 
we say that {G}_n ∈ℕ is a (λ,γ)-supersaturated graph if 
G_n is (λ(n),γ(n))-supersaturated for all n∈ℕ.
masked_plain_text_def:
Given λ and γ, we say that a graph G is (λ,γ)-B_MATH_TERM if
for any subset S ⊆ V(G) with |S| ≥λ N, we have

    e(S)≥γ (|S|/N )^2e(G_n).

Further, given λ = λ(n) ∈ [0,1], γ = γ(n) ∈  [0,1], and a sequence of graphs {G_n}_n ∈ℕ on N = N(n) vertices, 
we say that {G}_n ∈ℕ is a (λ,γ)-B_MATH_TERM graph if 
G_n is (λ(n),γ(n))-supersaturated for all n∈ℕ.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def: For a finite graph $G=(V,E)$, let $P$ denote an edge-partition $E = (E_1, E_2,..., E_k)$ and define $G_i=(V, E_i)$ for all $i$. If for all pairs $(r,s) \in [k] \times [k]$ we have $G_r \cong G_s$, then $P$ is a $k$\textit{-structurally-symmetric partition} of $G$.
plain_text_def: For a finite graph G=(V,E), let P denote an edge-partition E = (E_1, E_2,..., E_k) and define G_i=(V, E_i) for all i. If for all pairs (r,s) ∈ [k] × [k] we have G_r ≅ G_s, then P is a k-structurally-symmetric partition of G.
masked_plain_text_def: For a finite graph G=(V,E), let P denote an edge-partition E = (E_1, E_2,..., E_k) and define G_i=(V, E_i) for all i. If for all pairs (r,s) ∈ [k] × [k] we have G_r ≅ G_s, then P is a kB_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM of G.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O

def: If there exists a  $k$\textit{-structurally-symmetric partition} for $G$ that can be drawn with $cr_k(G)$ crossings then we say that the graph $G$ is $k$\textit{-structurally-symmetric} .
plain_text_def: If there exists a  k-structurally-symmetric partition for G that can be drawn with cr_k(G) crossings then we say that the graph G is k-structurally-symmetric .
masked_plain_text_def: If there exists a  kB_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM for G that can be drawn with cr_k(G) crossings then we say that the graph G is kB_MATH_TERM .
labeled_def: O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{gapcw}
Let $p_n$ satisfy $p_n = \Omega(n^{-c}), c<1/2$. Then for all $\epsilon > 0, \delta > 0$ there exists an $N$ such that for all $n\ge N,$ $$P[ \emph{GAPCW}(G_n) < 1 + \delta] > 1-\epsilon.$$
plain_text_def:
Let p_n satisfy p_n = Ω(n^-c), c<1/2. Then for all ϵ > 0, δ > 0 there exists an N such that for all n≥ N, 
    P[ GAPCW(G_n) < 1 + δ] > 1-ϵ.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let p_n satisfy p_n = Ω(n^-c), c<1/2. Then for all ϵ > 0, δ > 0 there exists an N such that for all n≥ N, 
    P[ B_MATH_TERM(G_n) < 1 + δ] > 1-ϵ.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{gapdcw}
Let $p_n$ satisfy $p_n = \Omega(n^{-c}), c<1/2,$ and let $\{G_n\}$ be a sequence of directed acyclic graphs sampled from a $D(n,p_n)$ distribution. Then for all $\epsilon > 0,\delta>0$ there exists an $N$ such that for all $n\ge N,$ $$P[ \emph{GAPCW}(G_n)<1+\delta] > 1-\epsilon.$$
plain_text_def:
Let p_n satisfy p_n = Ω(n^-c), c<1/2, and let {G_n} be a sequence of directed acyclic graphs sampled from a D(n,p_n) distribution. Then for all ϵ > 0,δ>0 there exists an N such that for all n≥ N, 
    P[ GAPCW(G_n)<1+δ] > 1-ϵ.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let p_n satisfy p_n = Ω(n^-c), c<1/2, and let {G_n} be a sequence of directed acyclic graphs sampled from a D(n,p_n) distribution. Then for all ϵ > 0,δ>0 there exists an N such that for all n≥ N, 
    P[ B_MATH_TERM(G_n)<1+δ] > 1-ϵ.

def:
\label{def}
Let G be a connected graph with $n$ vertices that has minimum degree $\delta$ and maximum degree $\Delta$. Let $\mu_1\geq\mu_2\geq\cdots\geq\mu_n$ be the eigenvalues of the adjacency matrix of G, and set $\lambda=\max_{2\leq i\leq n}|\mu_i|=\max\{|\mu_2|,|\mu_n|\}$. We will call $G$ an $(n,\delta,\Delta,\lambda)$-graph.
plain_text_def: Let G be a connected graph with n vertices that has minimum degree δ and maximum degree Δ. Let μ_1≥μ_2≥⋯≥μ_n be the eigenvalues of the adjacency matrix of G, and set λ=max_2≤ i≤ n|μ_i|=max{|μ_2|,|μ_n|}. We will call G an (n,δ,Δ,λ)-graph.
masked_plain_text_def: Let G be a connected graph with n vertices that has minimum degree δ and maximum degree Δ. Let μ_1≥μ_2≥⋯≥μ_n be the eigenvalues of the adjacency matrix of G, and set λ=max_2≤ i≤ n|μ_i|=max{|μ_2|,|μ_n|}. We will call G an B_MATH_TERM.

def:
If $\sigma(i)-k>\sigma(i+1)$, $i$ is called a $k$-\emph{descent} of $\sigma$.
Let $\DES_k(\sigma)$ denote the set of $k$-descents of $\sigma$,
and let $\des_k(\sigma)$ be the number of such $k$-descents.

and let _k(σ) be the number of such k-descents.

def:
A poset $P$ is called {\it purely $n$-dimensional} if every simplex of $P^\flat$
lies in an $n$-simplex; and {\it pure} if it is purely $n$-dimensional for some $n$.
(Some authors call such posets ranked or graded, but those terms may also mean
something else.)
$P$ will be called an {\it $n$-pseudo-manifold with coboundary $Q$} if $P$ is
purely $n$-dimensional, $P$ is a cell complex with coboundary $Q$, and
the $1$-skeleton $(P^*)^{(1)}$ (which consists of atoms and elements that
cover atoms) is a cell complex (in other words, a graph).
For brevity, $P^*$ will be called an {\it $n$-pseudo$^*$-manifold with boundary
$Q^*$}.

It is easy to see that if $P$ is a closed $n$-pseudo-manifold, then $C^*P$ is an
$(n+1)$-pseudo-manifold with coboundary $P$.
Dually, $C(P^*)$ is an $(n+1)$-pseudo$^*$-manifold with boundary $P^*$.
plain_text_def:
A poset P is called purely n-dimensional if every simplex of P^♭
lies in an n-simplex; and pure if it is purely n-dimensional for some n.
(Some authors call such posets ranked or graded, but those terms may also mean
something else.)
P will be called an n-pseudo-manifold with coboundary Q if P is
purely n-dimensional, P is a cell complex with coboundary Q, and
the 1-skeleton (P^*)^(1) (which consists of atoms and elements that
cover atoms) is a cell complex (in other words, a graph).
For brevity, P^* will be called an n-pseudo^*-manifold with boundary
Q^*.

It is easy to see that if P is a closed n-pseudo-manifold, then C^*P is an
(n+1)-pseudo-manifold with coboundary P.
Dually, C(P^*) is an (n+1)-pseudo^*-manifold with boundary P^*.
masked_plain_text_def:
A poset P is called purely n-dimensional if every simplex of P^♭
lies in an n-simplex; and pure if it is purely n-dimensional for some n.
(Some authors call such posets ranked or graded, but those terms may also mean
something else.)
P will be called an n-B_MATH_TERM with coboundary Q if P is
purely n-dimensional, P is a cell complex with coboundary Q, and
the 1-skeleton (P^*)^(1) (which consists of atoms and elements that
cover atoms) is a cell complex (in other words, a graph).
For brevity, P^* will be called an n-pseudo^*-manifold with boundary
Q^*.

It is easy to see that if P is a closed n-B_MATH_TERM, then C^*P is an
(n+1)-B_MATH_TERM with coboundary P.
Dually, C(P^*) is an (n+1)-pseudo^*-manifold with boundary P^*.
