def:
A monotone map of posets $f\:P\to Q$, will be called a {\it [pseudo-]comanifold}
if $f^{-1}(\fll\sigma\flr)$ is a [pseudo$^*$-]manifold with boundary
$f^{-1}(\partial\fll\sigma\flr)$ for each $\sigma\in Q$.

Depending on the structure of $Q$, a [pseudo-]comanifold $f\:P\to Q$ may have
dimension and/or codimension.
If $Q^*$ has pure cones, then $f$ is of {\it dimension} $d$ if
$f^{-1}(\fll\sigma\flr)$ is of dimension $d-i$ for each $\sigma\in Q$ with
$\fll\sigma^*\flr$ of dimension $i$.

More important is codimension.
If $Q$ itself has pure cones, then $f$ of {\it codimension} $k$, or simply is
a {\it $k$-[pseudo-]comanifold}, if $f^{-1}(\fll\sigma\flr)$ is of dimension
$i-k$ for each $\sigma\in Q$ with $\fll\sigma\flr$ of dimension $i$.

When $Q$ is a cell complex, $k$-comanifolds are a combinatorial form of
``$k$-mock bundles'', introduced by Buoncristiano, Rourke and Sanderson;
$k$-[pseudo-]comanifolds work as geometric representatives of $k$-dimensional
unoriented PL cobordism [resp.\ $\bmod 2$ cohomology] classes of $|Q|$ \cite{BRS}.

When $Q$ is purely $n$-dimensional, both dimension $d$ and codimension $k$ are
defined for [pseudo-]manifolds into $Q$; obviously, $k=n-d$.
plain_text_def:
A monotone map of posets f P→ Q, will be called a [pseudo-]comanifold
if f^-1(σ) is a [pseudo^*-]manifold with boundary
f^-1(∂σ) for each σ∈ Q.

Depending on the structure of Q, a [pseudo-]comanifold f P→ Q may have
dimension and/or codimension.
If Q^* has pure cones, then f is of dimension d if
f^-1(σ) is of dimension d-i for each σ∈ Q with
σ^* of dimension i.

More important is codimension.
If Q itself has pure cones, then f of codimension k, or simply is
a k-[pseudo-]comanifold, if f^-1(σ) is of dimension
i-k for each σ∈ Q with σ of dimension i.

When Q is a cell complex, k-comanifolds are a combinatorial form of
“k-mock bundles”, introduced by Buoncristiano, Rourke and Sanderson;
k-[pseudo-]comanifolds work as geometric representatives of k-dimensional
unoriented PL cobordism [resp. 2 cohomology] classes of |Q| <cit.>.

When Q is purely n-dimensional, both dimension d and codimension k are
defined for [pseudo-]manifolds into Q; obviously, k=n-d.
masked_plain_text_def:
A monotone map of posets f P→ Q, will be called a [pseudo-]B_MATH_TERM
if f^-1(σ) is a [pseudo^*-]manifold with boundary
f^-1(∂σ) for each σ∈ Q.

Depending on the structure of Q, a [pseudo-]B_MATH_TERM f P→ Q may have
dimension and/or codimension.
If Q^* has pure cones, then f is of dimension d if
f^-1(σ) is of dimension d-i for each σ∈ Q with
σ^* of dimension i.

More important is codimension.
If Q itself has pure cones, then f of codimension k, or simply is
a k-[pseudo-]B_MATH_TERM, if f^-1(σ) is of dimension
i-k for each σ∈ Q with σ of dimension i.

When Q is a cell complex, k-B_MATH_TERMs are a combinatorial form of
“k-mock bundles”, introduced by Buoncristiano, Rourke and Sanderson;
k-[pseudo-]B_MATH_TERMs work as geometric representatives of k-dimensional
unoriented PL cobordism [resp. 2 cohomology] classes of |Q| <cit.>.

When Q is purely n-dimensional, both dimension d and codimension k are
defined for [pseudo-]manifolds into Q; obviously, k=n-d.

def:
\label{def:valid}
Let $\mathbb G$ be a graph on vertex set $[\nR]$, let $T$ be a tree,
$\rho\in[0,1]$ and $L\in\mathbb N$. A mapping $h\colon V(T)\rightarrow [\nR]$ is
a \emph{$(\rho,L)$-valid assignment} of $T$ to $\mathbb G$ if 
\begin{enumerate}[label={\rm \arabic{*}.},ref={\rm \arabic{*}}]  
  \item \label{def:valid:hom} $h$ is a homomorphism from $T$ to
  $\mathbb G$,
  \item \label{def:valid:N}$|h(\neighbor_T(x))|\le 2$, for every $x\in V(T)$,
  \item \label{def:valid:place} $|h^{-1}(i)|<(1-\rho)L$, for every $i\in[\nR]$.
\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
Let 𝔾 be a graph on vertex set [], let T be a tree,
ρ∈[0,1] and L∈ℕ. A mapping h V(T)→ [] is
a (ρ,L)-valid assignment of T to 𝔾 if 
  
  
  *  h is a homomorphism from T to
  𝔾,
  
  * |h(_T(x))|≤ 2, for every x∈ V(T),
  
  *  |h^-1(i)|<(1-ρ)L, for every i∈[].
masked_plain_text_def:
Let 𝔾 be a graph on vertex set [], let T be a tree,
ρ∈[0,1] and L∈ℕ. A mapping h V(T)→ [] is
a (ρ,L)-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM of T to 𝔾 if 
  
  
  *  h is a homomorphism from T to
  𝔾,
  
  * |h(_T(x))|≤ 2, for every x∈ V(T),
  
  *  |h^-1(i)|<(1-ρ)L, for every i∈[].
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{PisRes}
Let $\mc P$ be a monotone increasing graph property, let
$G=G_n$ denote a family of graphs (where $G_n$ is a graph on $n$
vertices), let $0< p=p(n)< 1$ and let $0\le r\le 1$. We
say that $\mc P$ is $(G,p,r)$-\emph{resilient} if the local
resilience of a graph $G'\sim \gnp(G,p)$ with respect to
$\mc P$ is \aas at least $r$.
plain_text_def:
Let P be a monotone increasing graph property, let
G=G_n denote a family of graphs (where G_n is a graph on n
vertices), let 0< p=p(n)< 1 and let 0≤ r≤ 1. We
say that P is (G,p,r)-resilient if the local
resilience of a graph G'∼(G,p) with respect to
P is at least r.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let P be a monotone increasing graph property, let
G=G_n denote a family of graphs (where G_n is a graph on n
vertices), let 0< p=p(n)< 1 and let 0≤ r≤ 1. We
say that P is (G,p,r)-B_MATH_TERM if the local
resilience of a graph G'∼(G,p) with respect to
P is at least r.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
%Suppose $D = \{x_1, \dots , x_m\}$ is an {\bf $(n,m,\lambda)$-difference set} in $\G$.
Let $\G$ be an additive abelian group of order $n$.
An \textbf{\textit{$(n,m,\lambda)$-difference set}} (or \textbf{\textit{$(n,m,\lambda)$-DS}})
is a set  $A_1 \subseteq \G$, such that
the following multiset equation holds:
\[ \D(A_1) = \lambda (\G \setminus \{0\}).\]
plain_text_def:
Let  be an additive abelian group of order n.
An (n,m,λ)-difference set (or (n,m,λ)-DS)
is a set  A_1 ⊆, such that
the following multiset equation holds:

    (A_1) = λ (∖{0}).

Let  be an additive abelian group of order n.
An (n,m,λ)-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM (or (n,m,λ)-DS)
is a set  A_1 ⊆, such that
the following multiset equation holds:

    (A_1) = λ (∖{0}).

def:
Let $\G$ be an additive abelian group of order $n$.
An \textbf{\textit{$(n,m,k,\lambda)$-external difference family}} (or \textbf{\textit{$(n,m,k,\lambda)$-EDF}})
is a set of $m$ disjoint $k$-subsets of $\G$, say $A_1, \dots , A_m$, such that
the following multiset equation holds:
\[ \bigcup _{\{ i,j : i \neq j\} }^{}\D(A_i,A_j)  = \lambda (\G \setminus \{0\}).\]
plain_text_def:
Let  be an additive abelian group of order n.
An (n,m,k,λ)-external difference family (or (n,m,k,λ)-EDF)
is a set of m disjoint k-subsets of , say A_1, … , A_m, such that
the following multiset equation holds:

    ⋃ _{ i,j : i ≠ j}^(A_i,A_j)  = λ (∖{0}).
masked_plain_text_def:
Let  be an additive abelian group of order n.
An (n,m,k,λ)-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM (or (n,m,k,λ)-EDF)
is a set of m disjoint k-subsets of , say A_1, … , A_m, such that
the following multiset equation holds:

    ⋃ _{ i,j : i ≠ j}^(A_i,A_j)  = λ (∖{0}).

def:
Let $\G$ be an additive abelian group of order $n$.
A \textbf{\textit{$(n,m,k,\lambda)$-bounded external difference family}} 
(or \textbf{\textit{$(n,m,k,\lambda)$-BEDF}})
is a set of $m$ disjoint $k$-subsets of $\G$, say $A_1, \dots , A_m$, such that
the following condition holds for every $g \in \G \setminus \{0\}$:
\[ |\{ x-y: x-y = g, x \in A_i, y \in A_j,  i \neq j\}|  \leq \lambda .\]
plain_text_def:
Let  be an additive abelian group of order n.
A (n,m,k,λ)-bounded external difference family 
(or (n,m,k,λ)-BEDF)
is a set of m disjoint k-subsets of , say A_1, … , A_m, such that
the following condition holds for every g ∈∖{0}:

    |{ x-y: x-y = g, x ∈ A_i, y ∈ A_j,  i ≠ j}|  ≤λ .
masked_plain_text_def:
Let  be an additive abelian group of order n.
A (n,m,k,λ)-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM 
(or (n,m,k,λ)-BEDF)
is a set of m disjoint k-subsets of , say A_1, … , A_m, such that
the following condition holds for every g ∈∖{0}:

    |{ x-y: x-y = g, x ∈ A_i, y ∈ A_j,  i ≠ j}|  ≤λ .

plain_text_def:
Let  be an additive abelian group of order n.
An (n,m,k;λ)-strong external difference family
(or (n,m,k;λ)-SEDF)
is a set of m disjoint k-subsets of , say A_1, … , A_m, such that
the following multiset equation holds for every i, 1 ≤ i ≤ m:

    ⋃ _{ j : j ≠ i}^(A_i,A_j)   = λ (∖{0}).

def:
Let $\G$ be an additive abelian group of order $n$.
An \textbf{\textit{$(n,m;k_1, \dots , k_m;\lambda)$-generalized external difference family}} 
(or \textbf{\textit{$(n,m;k_1, \dots , k_m;\lambda)$-GEDF}})
is a set of $m$ disjoint subsets of $\G$, say $A_1, \dots , A_m$, such that
$|A_i| = k_i$ for $1 \leq i \leq m$ and 
the following multiset equation holds:
\[ \bigcup _{\{ i,j : i \neq j\} }^{}\D(A_i,A_j)   = \lambda (\G \setminus \{0\}).\]

term: Bounded generalized strong external difference family
def:
Let $\G$ be an additive abelian group of order $n$.
An \textbf{\textit{$(n,m;k_1, \dots , k_m;\lambda_1, \dots , \lambda_m)$-bounded generalized strong external difference family}} 
(or \textbf{\textit{$(n,m;k_1, \dots , k_m;\lambda_1, \dots , \lambda_m)$-BGSEDF}})
is a set of $m$ disjoint subsets of $\G$, say $A_1, \dots , A_m$, such that
$|A_i| = k_i$ for $1 \leq i \leq m$ and 
the following multiset equation holds for every $j$, $1 \leq j \leq m$, 
and for every $g \in \G \setminus \{0\}$:
\[ |\{ x-y: x-y = g, x \in A_i, y \in A_j,  i \neq j\}|  \leq \lambda_j .\]
plain_text_def:
Let  be an additive abelian group of order n.
An (n,m;k_1, … , k_m;λ_1, … , λ_m)-bounded generalized strong external difference family 
(or (n,m;k_1, … , k_m;λ_1, … , λ_m)-BGSEDF)
is a set of m disjoint subsets of , say A_1, … , A_m, such that
|A_i| = k_i for 1 ≤ i ≤ m and 
the following multiset equation holds for every j, 1 ≤ j ≤ m, 
and for every g ∈∖{0}:

    |{ x-y: x-y = g, x ∈ A_i, y ∈ A_j,  i ≠ j}|  ≤λ_j .
plain_text_term: Bounded generalized strong external difference family

(or (n,m;k_1, … , k_m;λ_1, … , λ_m)-BGSEDF)

|A_i| = k_i for 1 ≤ i ≤ m and

and for every g ∈∖{0}:

    |{ x-y: x-y = g, x ∈ A_i, y ∈ A_j,  i ≠ j}|  ≤λ_j .

def:
Let $\G$ be an additive abelian group of order $n$.
An \textbf{\textit{$(n,m;c_1, \dots , c_{\ell} ;k_1, \dots , k_{\ell};\lambda_1, \dots , \lambda_{\ell})$-partitioned external difference family}}
(or \textbf{\textit{$(n,m;c_1, \dots , c_{\ell} ;k_1, \dots , k_{\ell};\lambda_1, \dots , \lambda_{\ell})$-PEDF}})
is a set of $m= \sum_i c_i$ disjoint subsets of $\G$, say $A_1, \dots , A_m$, such that
there are $c_h$ subsets of size $k_h$, for $1 \leq h \leq \ell$, and 
the following multiset equation holds for every $h$, $1 \leq h \leq \ell$:
\[ \bigcup _{\{ i : |A_i| = c_h\} }^{} \bigcup _{\{ j : j \neq i\} }^{}\D(A_i,A_j)   = \lambda_i (\G \setminus \{0\}).\]
plain_text_def:
Let  be an additive abelian group of order n.
An (n,m;c_1, … , c_ℓ ;k_1, … , k_ℓ;λ_1, … , λ_ℓ)-partitioned external difference family
(or (n,m;c_1, … , c_ℓ ;k_1, … , k_ℓ;λ_1, … , λ_ℓ)-PEDF)
is a set of m= ∑_i c_i disjoint subsets of , say A_1, … , A_m, such that
there are c_h subsets of size k_h, for 1 ≤ h ≤ℓ, and 
the following multiset equation holds for every h, 1 ≤ h ≤ℓ:

    ⋃ _{ i : |A_i| = c_h}^⋃ _{ j : j ≠ i}^(A_i,A_j)   = λ_i (∖{0}).
masked_plain_text_def:

(or (n,m;c_1, … , c_ℓ ;k_1, … , k_ℓ;λ_1, … , λ_ℓ)-PEDF)
is a set of m= ∑_i c_i disjoint subsets of , say A_1, … , A_m, such that
there are c_h subsets of size k_h, for 1 ≤ h ≤ℓ, and 
the following multiset equation holds for every h, 1 ≤ h ≤ℓ:

    ⋃ _{ i : |A_i| = c_h}^⋃ _{ j : j ≠ i}^(A_i,A_j)   = λ_i (∖{0}).

plain_text_def:
A weighted bipartite graph G  X  Y → [0,1] is said to satisfy the discrepancy condition (q,ϵ) if
  
    ∫_x ∈ X
            
     y ∈ Y (G(x,y) - q) u(x) v(y)  dxdy ≤ϵ

  for all functions u  X → [0,1] and v  Y → [0,1]. In any weighted graph G, if X and Y are subsets of vertices of G, we say that the pair (X, Y)_G satisfies (q,  ϵ) if the induced weighted graph on X  Y satisfies (q,ϵ).
masked_plain_text_def:
A weighted bipartite graph G  X  Y → [0,1] is said to satisfy the B_MATH_TERMrepancy condition _MATH_TERM(q,ϵ) if
  
    ∫_x ∈ X
            
     y ∈ Y (G(x,y) - q) u(x) v(y)  dxdy ≤ϵ

  for all functions u  X → [0,1] and v  Y → [0,1]. In any weighted graph G, if X and Y are subsets of vertices of G, we say that the pair (X, Y)_G satisfies _MATH_TERM(q,  ϵ) if the induced weighted graph on X  Y satisfies _MATH_TERM(q,ϵ).

def:
\label{def:eps_negdef}
		A symmetric matrix $M\in\Real^{m\times m}$ is called $\epsilon$-\emph{negative definite} if the probability of finding a $d$-dimensional linear subspace $D\in G(d,m)$ so that $A$ is convex over $D$ is smaller than $\epsilon^d$. That is, $P_r(\set{M\vert_D \succeq 0})\leq \epsilon^d$ where the probability is taken with respect to a Haar $O(m)$-invariant measure on the Grassmannian $G_r(d,m)$.
plain_text_def: A symmetric matrix M∈^m× m is called ϵ-negative definite if the probability of finding a d-dimensional linear subspace D∈ G(d,m) so that A is convex over D is smaller than ϵ^d. That is, P_r(M|_D ≽ 0)≤ϵ^d where the probability is taken with respect to a Haar O(m)-invariant measure on the Grassmannian G_r(d,m).
masked_plain_text_def: A symmetric matrix M∈^m× m is called ϵ-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM if the probability of finding a d-dimensional linear subspace D∈ G(d,m) so that A is convex over D is smaller than ϵ^d. That is, P_r(M|_D ≽ 0)≤ϵ^d where the probability is taken with respect to a Haar O(m)-invariant measure on the Grassmannian G_r(d,m).
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
Given positive integers $x,y$ and an AD-Young diagram $(Y, A, D)$ such
that $Y$ has $k$ rows, we say that $(Y, A, D)$ is $x,y$\emph{-alternating}
if $A,D$ satisfy the property that
if $x - 1 \le i \le k-y$, then $i \in A$ if and only if $i + 1 \in D$.
plain_text_def:
Given positive integers x,y and an AD-Young diagram (Y, A, D) such
that Y has k rows, we say that (Y, A, D) is x,y-alternating
if A,D satisfy the property that
if x - 1 ≤ i ≤ k-y, then i ∈ A if and only if i + 1 ∈ D.
masked_plain_text_def:
Given positive integers x,y and an AD-Young diagram (Y, A, D) such
that Y has k rows, we say that (Y, A, D) is x,yB_MATH_TERM
if A,D satisfy the property that
if x - 1 ≤ i ≤ k-y, then i ∈ A if and only if i + 1 ∈ D.

def:
\label{quadrictheorem}
Let $f \in k[x^{\pm 1}, y^{\pm 1}]$ be non-degenerate with respect to its Newton polygon
 $\Delta = \Delta(f)$ and assume that $\Delta^{(1)}$ is two-dimensional. Then $U(f)$ is non-hyperelliptic
 and the Zariski closure of the image of (\ref{canonicalembedding}) is a canonical model of $U(f)$.
 If moreover $\Delta^{(2)} \neq \emptyset$, then the ideal of
 the latter is generated by $\mathcal{I}( \emph{Tor}(\Delta^{(1)}))$ and the quadrics $\{Q_w \}_{w \in \Delta^{(2)} \cap \mathbb{Z}^2}$.
plain_text_def:
Let f ∈ k[x^± 1, y^± 1] be non-degenerate with respect to its Newton polygon
 Δ = Δ(f) and assume that Δ^(1) is two-dimensional. Then U(f) is non-hyperelliptic
 and the Zariski closure of the image of (<ref>) is a canonical model of U(f).
 If moreover Δ^(2)≠∅, then the ideal of
 the latter is generated by ℐ( Tor(Δ^(1))) and the quadrics {Q_w }_w ∈Δ^(2)∩ℤ^2.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let f ∈ k[x^± 1, y^± 1] be non-degenerate with respect to its Newton polygon
 Δ = Δ(f) and assume that Δ^(1) is two-dimensional. Then U(f) is non-hyperelliptic
 and the Zariski closure of the image of (<ref>) is a canonical model of U(f).
 If moreover Δ^(2)≠∅, then the ideal of
 the latter is generated by ℐ( B_MATH_TERM(Δ^(1))) and the quadrics {Q_w }_w ∈Δ^(2)∩ℤ^2.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
Let f ∈ k[x^± 1,y^± 1] be non-degenerate with respect to its Newton polygon
 Δ = Δ(f) and suppose that ♯(Δ^(1)∩ℤ^2) ≥ 4. Then
 
   
  * if Δ^(1)≅ (d-3)Σ for d ≥ 5 then ci(U(f)) = d-4 and cd(U(f)) = 2,
   
  * if Δ^(1)≅Υ then ci(U(f)) = 1 and cd(U(f)) = 1,
   
  * if Δ^(1)≅ 2Υ then ci(U(f)) = 3 and cd(U(f)) = 3,
   
  * in all other cases ci(U(f)) = lw(Δ^(1)) and cd(U(f)) = 1.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let f ∈ k[x^± 1,y^± 1] be non-degenerate with respect to its Newton polygon
 Δ = Δ(f) and suppose that ♯(Δ^(1)∩ℤ^2) ≥ 4. Then
 
   
  * if Δ^(1)≅ (d-3)Σ for d ≥ 5 then B_MATH_TERM(U(f)) = d-4 and B_MATH_TERM(U(f)) = 2,
   
  * if Δ^(1)≅Υ then B_MATH_TERM(U(f)) = 1 and B_MATH_TERM(U(f)) = 1,
   
  * if Δ^(1)≅ 2Υ then B_MATH_TERM(U(f)) = 3 and B_MATH_TERM(U(f)) = 3,
   
  * in all other cases B_MATH_TERM(U(f)) = B_MATH_TERM(Δ^(1)) and B_MATH_TERM(U(f)) = 1.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{theorem_schreyer}
Let $f \in k[x^{\pm 1}, y^{\pm 1}]$ be non-degenerate with respect to its Newton polygon
$\Delta = \Delta(f)$. Suppose that $\emph{lw}(\Delta^{(1)}) = 2$ and that $\Delta \not \cong 2\Upsilon$.
Then $U(f)$ is tetragonal and Schreyer's invariants $b_1,b_2$ equal
\[ \sharp(\partial \Delta^{(1)} \cap \mathbb{Z}^2) - 4 \qquad \text{resp.} \qquad
\sharp (\Delta^{(2)} \cap \mathbb{Z}^2) - 1.\]
If moreover $b_1 > b_2$ then Schreyer's surface $\mu(Y)$ equals $\emph{Tor}(\Delta^{(1)})$ (assuming
that $U(f)$ is canonically embedded using (\ref{canonicalembedding})).
plain_text_def:
Let f ∈ k[x^± 1, y^± 1] be non-degenerate with respect to its Newton polygon
Δ = Δ(f). Suppose that lw(Δ^(1)) = 2 and that Δ≇2Υ.
Then U(f) is tetragonal and Schreyer's invariants b_1,b_2 equal

    ♯(∂Δ^(1)∩ℤ^2) - 4     resp.    ♯ (Δ^(2)∩ℤ^2) - 1.

If moreover b_1 > b_2 then Schreyer's surface μ(Y) equals Tor(Δ^(1)) (assuming
that U(f) is canonically embedded using (<ref>)).
masked_plain_text_def:
Let f ∈ k[x^± 1, y^± 1] be non-degenerate with respect to its Newton polygon
Δ = Δ(f). Suppose that B_MATH_TERM(Δ^(1)) = 2 and that Δ≇2Υ.
Then U(f) is tetragonal and Schreyer's invariants b_1,b_2 equal

    ♯(∂Δ^(1)∩ℤ^2) - 4     resp.    ♯ (Δ^(2)∩ℤ^2) - 1.

If moreover b_1 > b_2 then Schreyer's surface μ(Y) equals B_MATH_TERM(Δ^(1)) (assuming
that U(f) is canonically embedded using (<ref>)).

def:
\label{theorem_secondary}
Let $f, \Delta, g^1_\gamma$ and $E_1, \dots, E_{\gamma - 1}$ be as in the statement of Theorem~\ref{thm_maroni}.
Assume moreover that $\emph{lw}(\Delta) \geq 4$, that $\Delta^{(2)} \neq \emptyset$ and that $\Delta$ is well-aligned with respect to $(0,1)$. Let $B_\ell=-1+\sharp\{(i,j)\in \Delta^{(2)}\cap\mathbb{Z}^2\,|\,j=\ell\}$
for $\ell=2, \dots, \gamma - 2$.
Then the multiset of secondary scrollar invariants of $U(f)$ with respect to $g^1_\gamma$ is given by
\[ \{ E_{j_1 -1} + E_{j_2 + 1} - \epsilon_{j_1,j_2} \}_{2 \leq j_1 \leq j_2 \leq \gamma - 2} \quad \cup \quad  \{ B_\ell \}_{2 \leq \ell \leq \gamma - 2},\]
where the $\epsilon_{j_1,j_2}$'s are defined as in (\ref{defepsilons}).
plain_text_def:
Let f, Δ, g^1_γ and E_1, …, E_γ - 1 be as in the statement of Theorem <ref>.
Assume moreover that lw(Δ) ≥ 4, that Δ^(2)≠∅ and that Δ is well-aligned with respect to (0,1). Let B_ℓ=-1+♯{(i,j)∈Δ^(2)∩ℤ^2 | j=ℓ}
for ℓ=2, …, γ - 2.
Then the multiset of secondary scrollar invariants of U(f) with respect to g^1_γ is given by

    { E_j_1 -1 + E_j_2 + 1 - ϵ_j_1,j_2}_2 ≤ j_1 ≤ j_2 ≤γ - 2  ∪  { B_ℓ}_2 ≤ℓ≤γ - 2,

where the ϵ_j_1,j_2's are defined as in (<ref>).
masked_plain_text_def:
Let f, Δ, g^1_γ and E_1, …, E_γ - 1 be as in the statement of Theorem <ref>.
Assume moreover that B_MATH_TERM(Δ) ≥ 4, that Δ^(2)≠∅ and that Δ is well-aligned with respect to (0,1). Let B_ℓ=-1+♯{(i,j)∈Δ^(2)∩ℤ^2 | j=ℓ}
for ℓ=2, …, γ - 2.
Then the multiset of secondary scrollar invariants of U(f) with respect to g^1_γ is given by

    { E_j_1 -1 + E_j_2 + 1 - ϵ_j_1,j_2}_2 ≤ j_1 ≤ j_2 ≤γ - 2  ∪  { B_ℓ}_2 ≤ℓ≤γ - 2,

where the ϵ_j_1,j_2's are defined as in (<ref>).

def:
\label{def_famofrec}
Let $G,H$ be countable commutative semigroups and let $p\in\beta G$ be an ultrafilter. Let $\Gamma$ be a set of functions from $H\to G$.
We say that $\Gamma$ is an \emph{R-family\footnote{R stands for \textit{returns} .} with respect to $p$} if for every finite set $F\subset\Gamma$, every $A\in p$ and every IP-set $(y_\alpha)_{\alpha\in{\mathcal F}}$ in $H$, there exist $x\in G$ and $\alpha\in{\mathcal F}$ such that
$$x+f(y_\alpha)\in A\qquad\qquad\forall f\in F$$
plain_text_def:
Let G,H be countable commutative semigroups and let p∈β G be an ultrafilter. Let Γ be a set of functions from H→ G.
We say that Γ is an R-family[R stands for returns .] with respect to p if for every finite set F⊂Γ, every A∈ p and every IP-set (y_α)_α∈ℱ in H, there exist x∈ G and α∈ℱ such that

    x+f(y_α)∈ A        ∀ f∈ F
masked_plain_text_def:
Let G,H be countable commutative semigroups and let p∈β G be an ultrafilter. Let Γ be a set of functions from H→ G.
We say that Γ is an B_MATH_TERM[R stands for returns .] with respect to p if for every finite set F⊂Γ, every A∈ p and every IP-set (y_α)_α∈ℱ in H, there exist x∈ G and α∈ℱ such that

    x+f(y_α)∈ A        ∀ f∈ F

def:
[$\Lambda$-system]Let $G$ be a countable commutative semigroup and let $\Lambda$ be a countable \shd{} in $G$.
A set $A\subset G$ is a $\Lambda$\emph{-system} if for every \shp{} $(m,\F,c)\in\Lambda$ there exists ${\bf s}={\bf s}(m,\F,c)\in G^{m+1}$ such that
  \begin{enumerate}
    \item $D\big(m_1,\F_1,c_1;{\bf s}\big)\cap D\big(m_2,\F_2,c_2;{\bf s}\big)=\emptyset$ whenever $(m_1,\F_1,c_1)\neq(m_2,\F_2,c_2)$.
    \item For all $\alpha\in{\mathcal F}(\Lambda)=\{\alpha\subset\Lambda:0<|\alpha|<\infty\}$ we have
    $$\sum_{(m,\F,c)\in\alpha}D\big(m,\F,c;{\bf s}(m,\F,c)\big)\subset A$$
  \end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
[Λ-system]Let G be a countable commutative semigroup and let Λ be a countable  in G.
A set A⊂ G is a Λ-system if for every  (m,,c)∈Λ there exists s= s(m,,c)∈ G^m+1 such that
  
    
  * D(m_1,_1,c_1; s)∩ D(m_2,_2,c_2; s)=∅ whenever (m_1,_1,c_1)≠(m_2,_2,c_2).
    
  * For all α∈ℱ(Λ)={α⊂Λ:0<|α|<∞} we have
    
    ∑_(m,,c)∈αD(m,,c; s(m,,c))⊂ A
masked_plain_text_def:
[Λ-system]Let G be a countable commutative semigroup and let Λ be a countable  in G.
A set A⊂ G is a ΛB_MATH_TERM if for every  (m,,c)∈Λ there exists s= s(m,,c)∈ G^m+1 such that
  
    
  * D(m_1,_1,c_1; s)∩ D(m_2,_2,c_2; s)=∅ whenever (m_1,_1,c_1)≠(m_2,_2,c_2).
    
  * For all α∈ℱ(Λ)={α⊂Λ:0<|α|<∞} we have
    
    ∑_(m,,c)∈αD(m,,c; s(m,,c))⊂ A

def: Given a weighted set $S$, the set of $S$\textit{-labeled graphs} is the set of graphs where each vertex is labelled by an element in $S$. We shall denote this set as $LG(S)$. We define the weight $w(g)$ of an element $g$ of $LG(S)$ to simply be the sum of the weights of its labels. We will also denote the subset of $LG(S)$ consisting of connected $S$-labeled graphs as $LCG(S)$. Note that we consider two graphs in $LG(S)$ to be equivalent if they are equivalent under a graph isomorphism that sends labeled vertices to similarly labeled vertices.
plain_text_def: Given a weighted set S, the set of S-labeled graphs is the set of graphs where each vertex is labelled by an element in S. We shall denote this set as LG(S). We define the weight w(g) of an element g of LG(S) to simply be the sum of the weights of its labels. We will also denote the subset of LG(S) consisting of connected S-labeled graphs as LCG(S). Note that we consider two graphs in LG(S) to be equivalent if they are equivalent under a graph isomorphism that sends labeled vertices to similarly labeled vertices.
masked_plain_text_def: Given a weighted set S, the set of SB_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM is the set of graphs where each vertex is labelled by an element in S. We shall denote this set as LG(S). We define the weight w(g) of an element g of LG(S) to simply be the sum of the weights of its labels. We will also denote the subset of LG(S) consisting of connected S-labeled graphs as LCG(S). Note that we consider two graphs in LG(S) to be equivalent if they are equivalent under a graph isomorphism that sends labeled vertices to similarly labeled vertices.

def:
For a path or cycle $H$ and a matching $M$ in a bipartite graph $\Gamma$, we say $H$ is $M$-\emph{alternating} if $E(H) \setminus M$ is a matching.
%and $|E(H) \setminus M| \geq |E(H) \cap M|$.
plain_text_def: For a path or cycle H and a matching M in a bipartite graph Γ, we say H is M-alternating if E(H) ∖ M is a matching.
masked_plain_text_def: For a path or cycle H and a matching M in a bipartite graph Γ, we say H is M-B_MATH_TERM if E(H) ∖ M is a matching.

def: A pair of distinct vertices $(x,y)$ in $G$ is said to be $(\ell,L)$-\emph{bad} for some $2 \leq \ell \leq 2k$ and some $L$ if there is an $L$-admissible, but not $L$-good, path of length $\ell$ from $x$ to $y$.
plain_text_def: A pair of distinct vertices (x,y) in G is said to be (ℓ,L)-bad for some 2 ≤ℓ≤ 2k and some L if there is an L-admissible, but not L-good, path of length ℓ from x to y.
masked_plain_text_def: A pair of distinct vertices (x,y) in G is said to be (ℓ,L)-B_MATH_TERM for some 2 ≤ℓ≤ 2k and some L if there is an L-admissible, but not L-good, path of length ℓ from x to y.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
Let v∈ V(G). A divisor D is said to be v-reduced if:


  * the divisor D is “effective away from v” – that is, for all w∈ V(G) ∖{ v }, D(w)≥ 0, and

  * for any U⊂ V(G)∖{ v }, the divisor obtained by firing all vertices in U is not effective away from v.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let v∈ V(G). A divisor D is said to be v-B_MATH_TERM if:


  * the divisor D is “effective away from v” – that is, for all w∈ V(G) ∖{ v }, D(w)≥ 0, and

  * for any U⊂ V(G)∖{ v }, the divisor obtained by firing all vertices in U is not effective away from v.

def:
\label{def.kA-coalg}Let $A$ be a commutative $\mathbf{k}$-algebra.

\textbf{(a)} Let $H$ be a $\mathbf{k}$-module, and let $G$ be an $A$-module.
For any $\mathbf{k}$-linear map $f:H\rightarrow G$, we let $f^{\sharp}$ denote
the $A$-linear map%
\[
\underline{A}\otimes H\rightarrow G,\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ a\otimes h\mapsto
af\left(  h\right)  .
\]
(It is easy to see that this latter map is indeed well-defined and
$A$-linear.) For any $A$-linear map $g:\underline{A}\otimes H\rightarrow G$,
we let $g^{\flat}$ denote the $\mathbf{k}$-linear map%
\[
H\rightarrow G,\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ h\mapsto g\left(  1\otimes h\right)  .
\]


Sometimes we will use the notations $f^{\sharp\left(  A,\mathbf{k}\right)  }$
and $g^{\flat\left(  A,\mathbf{k}\right)  }$ instead of $f^{\sharp}$ and
$g^{\flat}$ when the $A$ and the $\mathbf{k}$ are not clear from the context.

It is easy to see that $\left(  f^{\sharp}\right)  ^{\flat}=f$ for any
$\mathbf{k}$-linear map $f:H\rightarrow G$, and that $\left(  g^{\flat
}\right)  ^{\sharp}=g$ for any $A$-linear map $g:\underline{A}\otimes
H\rightarrow G$. Thus, the maps%
\begin{align}
\left\{  \mathbf{k}\text{-linear maps }H\rightarrow G\right\}   &
\rightarrow\left\{  A\text{-linear maps }\underline{A}\otimes H\rightarrow
G\right\}  ,\nonumber\\
f  &  \mapsto f^{\sharp} \label{eq.def.kA-coalg.dies}%
\end{align}
and%
\begin{align}
\left\{  A\text{-linear maps }\underline{A}\otimes H\rightarrow G\right\}   &
\rightarrow\left\{  \mathbf{k}\text{-linear maps }H\rightarrow G\right\}
,\nonumber\\
g  &  \mapsto g^{\flat} \label{eq.def.kA-coalg.bemol}%
\end{align}
are mutually inverse.

This is a particular case of an adjunction between functors (namely, the
Hom-tensor adjunction, with a slight simplification, also known as the
induction-restriction adjunction); this is also the reason why we are using
the $\sharp$ and $\flat$ notations. The maps (\ref{eq.def.kA-coalg.dies}) and
(\ref{eq.def.kA-coalg.bemol}) are natural in $H$ and $G$.

\textbf{(b)} Let $H$ be a $\mathbf{k}$-coalgebra, and let $G$ be an
$A$-coalgebra. A $\mathbf{k}$-linear map $f:H\rightarrow G$ is said to be a
$\left(  \mathbf{k},\underline{A}\right)  $\textit{-coalgebra homomorphism} if
the $A$-linear map $f^{\sharp}:\underline{A}\otimes H\rightarrow G$ is an
$A$-coalgebra homomorphism.
plain_text_def:
Let A be a commutative 𝐤-algebra.

(a) Let H be a 𝐤-module, and let G be an A-module.
For any 𝐤-linear map f:H→ G, we let f^♯ denote
the A-linear map

    A⊗ H→ G,          a⊗ h↦
    af(  h)  .

(It is easy to see that this latter map is indeed well-defined and
A-linear.) For any A-linear map g:A⊗ H→ G,
we let g^♭ denote the 𝐤-linear map

    H→ G,          h↦ g(  1⊗ h)  .



Sometimes we will use the notations f^♯(  A,𝐤)
and g^♭(  A,𝐤) instead of f^♯ and
g^♭ when the A and the 𝐤 are not clear from the context.

It is easy to see that (  f^♯)  ^♭=f for any
𝐤-linear map f:H→ G, and that (  g^♭)  ^♯=g for any A-linear map g:A⊗
H→ G. Thus, the maps

    {𝐤-linear maps H→ G}   →{  A-linear maps A⊗ H→
    G}  ,
    
    f     ↦ f^♯

and

    {  A-linear maps A⊗ H→ G}   →{𝐤-linear maps H→ G}
    ,
    
    g     ↦ g^♭

are mutually inverse.

This is a particular case of an adjunction between functors (namely, the
Hom-tensor adjunction, with a slight simplification, also known as the
induction-restriction adjunction); this is also the reason why we are using
the ♯ and ♭ notations. The maps (<ref>) and
(<ref>) are natural in H and G.

(b) Let H be a 𝐤-coalgebra, and let G be an
A-coalgebra. A 𝐤-linear map f:H→ G is said to be a
(  𝐤,A)-coalgebra homomorphism if
the A-linear map f^♯:A⊗ H→ G is an
A-coalgebra homomorphism.
masked_plain_text_def:

(a) Let H be a 𝐤-module, and let G be an A-module.
For any 𝐤-linear map f:H→ G, we let f^♯ denote
the A-linear map

    A⊗ H→ G,          a⊗ h↦
    af(  h)  .

(It is easy to see that this latter map is indeed well-defined and
A-linear.) For any A-linear map g:A⊗ H→ G,
we let g^♭ denote the 𝐤-linear map

    H→ G,          h↦ g(  1⊗ h)  .

and g^♭(  A,𝐤) instead of f^♯ and
g^♭ when the A and the 𝐤 are not clear from the context.

It is easy to see that (  f^♯)  ^♭=f for any
𝐤-linear map f:H→ G, and that (  g^♭)  ^♯=g for any A-linear map g:A⊗
H→ G. Thus, the maps

    G}  ,
    
    f     ↦ f^♯

and

    {  A-linear maps A⊗ H→ G}   →{𝐤-linear maps H→ G}
    ,
    
    g     ↦ g^♭

are mutually inverse.

This is a particular case of an adjunction between functors (namely, the
Hom-tensor adjunction, with a slight simplification, also known as the
induction-restriction adjunction); this is also the reason why we are using
the ♯ and ♭ notations. The maps (<ref>) and
(<ref>) are natural in H and G.

(b) Let H be a 𝐤-coalgebra, and let G be an
A-coalgebra. A 𝐤-linear map f:H→ G is said to be a
(  𝐤,A)B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM if
the A-linear map f^♯:A⊗ H→ G is an
A-coalgebra homomorphism.

def:
\label{safety2}
Suppose we allow $\sigma^2$ to depend on $n$:
$
\displaystyle\sigma^2 = \frac{c^2}{\log(n)},
$
for some value $c\neq 0$.
For any $ \eta> 0$, we say that a
distance-based tree reconstruction method $M$ has $\eta$-stochastic safety radius
$s = s_n$ if for every binary phylogenetic $X$-tree $T$ on n leaves, with minimum
interior edge length $w_{\min}$, and with the distance matrix $\delta$ on $X$ described by the
random errors model, we have
\[
c < s\cdot w_{\min} \Rightarrow P(M(\delta) = T) \geq 1 - \eta.
\]
plain_text_def:
Suppose we allow σ^2 to depend on n:
σ^2 = c^2/log(n),
for some value c≠ 0.
For any η> 0, we say that a
distance-based tree reconstruction method M has η-stochastic safety radius
s = s_n if for every binary phylogenetic X-tree T on n leaves, with minimum
interior edge length w_min, and with the distance matrix δ on X described by the
random errors model, we have

    c < s· w_min⇒ P(M(δ) = T) ≥ 1 - η.
masked_plain_text_def:
Suppose we allow σ^2 to depend on n:
σ^2 = c^2/log(n),
for some value c≠ 0.
For any η> 0, we say that a
distance-based tree reconstruction method M has η-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM
s = s_n if for every binary phylogenetic X-tree T on n leaves, with minimum
interior edge length w_min, and with the distance matrix δ on X described by the
random errors model, we have

    c < s· w_min⇒ P(M(δ) = T) ≥ 1 - η.

plain_text_def:
Let 𝔠_1,𝔠_2 be two H-chambers adjacent along the wall W_I, with 𝔠_1 being the chamber with x_I=∑_i∈ I x_i<0. Let P_i^λ(x) be the polynomial expressing h_g;x,λ in 𝔠_i. We define the wall-crossing function by

    WC_I^λ(x)=P^λ_2(x)-P^λ_1(x).
masked_plain_text_def:
Let 𝔠_1,𝔠_2 be two H-B_MATH_TERM adjacent along the wall W_I, with 𝔠_1 being the chamber with x_I=∑_i∈ I x_i<0. Let P_i^λ(x) be the polynomial expressing h_g;x,λ in 𝔠_i. We define the wall-crossing function by

    WC_I^λ(x)=P^λ_2(x)-P^λ_1(x).

def:
[Tverberg \cite{T1}]
  For any $d\geq 1$ and $q \geq 2$, any
  set of $(d+1)(q-1)+1$ points in $\mathbb{R}^d$
  can be partitioned into $q$ disjoint subsets
  $F_1, F_2, \ldots F_q$ such that 
  $\textrm{\emph{conv}}(F_1)\cap\cdots \cap \textrm{\emph{conv}}(F_q)
   \neq \emptyset $.
plain_text_def:
[Tverberg <cit.>]
  For any d≥ 1 and q ≥ 2, any
  set of (d+1)(q-1)+1 points in ℝ^d
  can be partitioned into q disjoint subsets
  F_1, F_2, … F_q such that 
  conv(F_1)∩⋯∩conv(F_q)
   ≠∅.
masked_plain_text_def:
[Tverberg <cit.>]
  For any d≥ 1 and q ≥ 2, any
  set of (d+1)(q-1)+1 points in ℝ^d
  can be partitioned into q disjoint subsets
  F_1, F_2, … F_q such that 
  B_MATH_TERM(F_1)∩⋯∩B_MATH_TERM(F_q)
   ≠∅.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
Fix n∈ and ≥0. The -differential privacy polytope, ⊂^n× n, is defined as follows:

    ={A∈^n× n:[    ∑_j a_ij=1,     ∀ 1≤ i≤ n,;       a_ij≥ 0,   ∀ 1≤ i,j≤ n,; a_ij≤ e^ a_kj, ∀ 1≤ i,j,k≤ n. ]}.



The non-negativity and stochastic constraints ensure  is bounded. Therefore it is a polytope.

def: A {\bf $\textit{sub}$}-{\bf $\textit{abacus}$} ${\mathcal S}'$ of an $s$-abacus ${\mathcal S}$ is a set of $s$-abacus positions $(i,j)$ that obey the property that if $(i,j)\in {\mathcal S}'$, then $(i,j)\in {\mathcal S}.$
plain_text_def: A sub-abacus 𝒮' of an s-abacus 𝒮 is a set of s-abacus positions (i,j) that obey the property that if (i,j)∈𝒮', then (i,j)∈𝒮.

def:
Let $X$ be a finite set and let $S$ be a homogeneous collection of ordered 
subsets of $X$ of size $k$. Let $\mu = (\mu_1,\dots,\mu_m)$ and $\nu=(\nu_1,\dots,\nu_m)$ be 
two sequences of measures on $X$. A $(\mu,\nu)$-\emph{basic anti-uniform function}
is a function of the form $\circ_j(g_{i_1}, \dots, g_{i_{j-1}}, f_{i_{j+1}}, 
\dots, f_{i_k})$, where $1\leq j\leq k$, $i_1,\dots,i_k$ are distinct and 
$0\leq g_{i_h}\leq \nu_{i_h}$ and $0\leq f_{i_h}\leq\mu_{i_h}$ for 
every $h$ between $1$ and $k$. Let $\Phi_{\mu, \nu}$ be the set of all 
$(\mu,\nu)$-basic anti-uniform functions 
and define the norm $\|.\|_{\mu,\nu}$ by taking $\|h\|_{\mu,\nu}$ to be 
$\max\{|\sp{h,\phi}|:\phi\in\Phi_{\mu,\nu}\}$.
plain_text_def:
Let X be a finite set and let S be a homogeneous collection of ordered 
subsets of X of size k. Let μ = (μ_1,…,μ_m) and ν=(ν_1,…,ν_m) be 
two sequences of measures on X. A (μ,ν)-basic anti-uniform function
is a function of the form ∘_j(g_i_1, …, g_i_j-1, f_i_j+1, 
…, f_i_k), where 1≤ j≤ k, i_1,…,i_k are distinct and 
0≤ g_i_h≤ν_i_h and 0≤ f_i_h≤μ_i_h for 
every h between 1 and k. Let Φ_μ, ν be the set of all 
(μ,ν)-basic anti-uniform functions 
and define the norm ._μ,ν by taking h_μ,ν to be 
max{|h,ϕ|:ϕ∈Φ_μ,ν}.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let X be a finite set and let S be a homogeneous collection of ordered 
subsets of X of size k. Let μ = (μ_1,…,μ_m) and ν=(ν_1,…,ν_m) be 
two sequences of measures on X. A (μ,ν)-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM
is a function of the form ∘_j(g_i_1, …, g_i_j-1, f_i_j+1, 
…, f_i_k), where 1≤ j≤ k, i_1,…,i_k are distinct and 
0≤ g_i_h≤ν_i_h and 0≤ f_i_h≤μ_i_h for 
every h between 1 and k. Let Φ_μ, ν be the set of all 
(μ,ν)-basic anti-uniform functions 
and define the norm ._μ,ν by taking h_μ,ν to be 
max{|h,ϕ|:ϕ∈Φ_μ,ν}.

def:
\label{def:almostpack}
Let $\mathcal F=\{F_i\}_{i\in[k]}$ be a family of graphs. 
For a graph~$G$, a family of sets $\{R_i\}_{i\in[k]}$ with $R_i\subset V(F_i)$ and a family of maps
$\{h_i\}_{i\in[k]}$ with $h_i:V(F_i)\setminus R_i\rightarrow V(G)$ we say that
$\{h_i,R_i\}_{i\in[k]}$ is an \DEF{$\ell$-almost packing} of $\mathcal F$ into~$G$ if
\begin{enumerate}[label=\abc]
\item $\{h_i\}_{i\in[k]}$ is a packing of the family $\{F_i-R_i\}_{i\in[k]}$ into the graph $G$,
\item\label{def:almostpack:R} we have $|R_i|\le \ell$ for each $i\in [k]$, and
\item\label{def:almostpack:RN} for each $v\in V(G)$, \  
$\sum_{j\in[k]} |\big\{x\in h^{-1}_{j}(v)\colon\, \exists xy\in E(F_{j})
\text{ such that $y\in R_j$}\big\}| \le \ell$.
%$\sum_{j\in[k]}|h_j^{-1}(v)\cap \neighbor_{F_j}(R_j)|\le \ell$.
\end{enumerate}

We say that $\mathcal F$ \DEF{$\ell$-almost packs} into a graph $G$ if there exist $\{R_i\}_{i\in[k]}$ and $\{h_i\}_{i\in[k]}$ such that $\{h_i,R_i\}_{i\in[k]}$ is an $\ell$-almost packing of $\mathcal F$ into~$G$.
plain_text_def:
Let ℱ={F_i}_i∈[k] be a family of graphs. 
For a graph G, a family of sets {R_i}_i∈[k] with R_i⊂ V(F_i) and a family of maps
{h_i}_i∈[k] with h_i:V(F_i)∖ R_i→ V(G) we say that
{h_i,R_i}_i∈[k] is an ℓ-almost packing of ℱ into G if


  * {h_i}_i∈[k] is a packing of the family {F_i-R_i}_i∈[k] into the graph G,

  *  we have |R_i|≤ℓ for each i∈ [k], and

  *  for each v∈ V(G),   
∑_j∈[k] |{x∈ h^-1_j(v) ∃ xy∈ E(F_j)
 such that y∈ R_j}| ≤ℓ.



We say that ℱ ℓ-almost packs into a graph G if there exist {R_i}_i∈[k] and {h_i}_i∈[k] such that {h_i,R_i}_i∈[k] is an ℓ-almost packing of ℱ into G.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let ℱ={F_i}_i∈[k] be a family of graphs. 
For a graph G, a family of sets {R_i}_i∈[k] with R_i⊂ V(F_i) and a family of maps
{h_i}_i∈[k] with h_i:V(F_i)∖ R_i→ V(G) we say that
{h_i,R_i}_i∈[k] is an ℓ-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM of ℱ into G if


  * {h_i}_i∈[k] is a packing of the family {F_i-R_i}_i∈[k] into the graph G,

  *  we have |R_i|≤ℓ for each i∈ [k], and

  *  for each v∈ V(G),   
∑_j∈[k] |{x∈ h^-1_j(v) ∃ xy∈ E(F_j)
 such that y∈ R_j}| ≤ℓ.



We say that ℱ ℓ-almost packs into a graph G if there exist {R_i}_i∈[k] and {h_i}_i∈[k] such that {h_i,R_i}_i∈[k] is an ℓ-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM of ℱ into G.

def:
\label{def:typical}
Let $i\in [c]$.
A pair $uv\in \binom{V}{2}$ is called \DEF{$i$-typical} if $(\load(u,v,\cU_i)-\mu(\cU_i))^2\le\sqrt{\alpha}n^2$, and \DEF{$i$-atypical}, otherwise.
%
An edge $uv\in E$ is called \DEF{typical}, if it is $i$-typical for each $i\in [c]$, and \DEF{atypical} otherwise.
plain_text_def:
Let i∈ [c].
A pair uv∈V2 is called i-typical if ((u,v,_i)-μ(_i))^2≤√(α)n^2, and i-atypical, otherwise.

An edge uv∈ E is called typical, if it is i-typical for each i∈ [c], and atypical otherwise.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let i∈ [c].
A pair uv∈V2 is called i-B_MATH_TERM if ((u,v,_i)-μ(_i))^2≤√(α)n^2, and i-aB_MATH_TERM, otherwise.

An edge uv∈ E is called B_MATH_TERM, if it is i-B_MATH_TERM for each i∈ [c], and aB_MATH_TERM otherwise.

plain_text_def:
The generating function sw_k(x) for the number of smooth words of length n over the alphabet [k] is given by

    sw_k(x)=1+x(k-(3k+2)x)/(1-3x)^2+2x^2/(1-3x)^21+U_k-1(1-x/2x)/U_k(1-x/2x).

The generating function B_MATH_TERM_k(x) for the number of smooth words of length n over the alphabet [k] is given by

    B_MATH_TERM_k(x)=1+x(k-(3k+2)x)/(1-3x)^2+2x^2/(1-3x)^21+U_k-1(1-x/2x)/U_k(1-x/2x).
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
The number of smooth words of length n over the alphabet [k] is given by

    sw_n,k=1/k+1∑_j=1^k(1+(-1)^j+1)^2jπ/2(k+1)(1+2cosjπ/k+1)^n-1,

or alternatively as

    sw_n,k=2/k+1∑_0≤ j≤k-1/2^2(2j+1)π/2(k+1)(1+2cos(2j+1)π/k+1)^n-1.

    B_MATH_TERM_n,k=1/k+1∑_j=1^k(1+(-1)^j+1)^2jπ/2(k+1)(1+2cosjπ/k+1)^n-1,

or alternatively as

    B_MATH_TERM_n,k=2/k+1∑_0≤ j≤k-1/2^2(2j+1)π/2(k+1)(1+2cos(2j+1)π/k+1)^n-1.

def:
\label{th2}
The generating function for the number of smooth cyclic words of length $n$ over an alphabet of $k$ letters
is given by
$$\textit{scw}_k(x)=1+\frac{kx(1+3x)}{(1+x)(1-3x)}-\frac{2(k+1)x}{(1+x)(1-3x)}\frac{U_{k-1}\left(\frac{1-x}{2x}\right)}{U_k\left(\frac{1-x}{2x}\right)}.$$
plain_text_def:
The generating function for the number of smooth cyclic words of length n over an alphabet of k letters
is given by

    scw_k(x)=1+kx(1+3x)/(1+x)(1-3x)-2(k+1)x/(1+x)(1-3x)U_k-1(1-x/2x)/U_k(1-x/2x).
masked_plain_text_def:
The generating function for the number of smooth cyclic words of length n over an alphabet of k letters
is given by

    B_MATH_TERM_k(x)=1+kx(1+3x)/(1+x)(1-3x)-2(k+1)x/(1+x)(1-3x)U_k-1(1-x/2x)/U_k(1-x/2x).
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
Let n≥1. The number sn_n,k of smooth necklaces of length n over an alphabet of k letters is given by

    sn_n,k=1/n∑_i=1^k∑_j| nϕ(j)[1+2cos(iπ/k+1)]^n/j

where ϕ is Euler's totient function (ϕ(n) is the number of positive integers ≤ n that are relatively prime to n), and we write j| n if j divides n.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let n≥1. The number B_MATH_TERM_n,k of smooth necklaces of length n over an alphabet of k letters is given by

    B_MATH_TERM_n,k=1/n∑_i=1^k∑_j| nϕ(j)[1+2cos(iπ/k+1)]^n/j

where ϕ is Euler's totient function (ϕ(n) is the number of positive integers ≤ n that are relatively prime to n), and we write j| n if j divides n.

def: Let $\sigma \in \mathfrak{S}_n$. We say that $\sigma$ is \emph{alternating} if $D(\sigma) = \{1,3,\ldots,2\left\lfloor{n}/{2}\right\rfloor-1\}$, \emph{i.e.} $\sigma_1~>~\sigma_2~<~\sigma_3~>~\cdots$. We denote by $\textit{Alt}_n$ the set of alternating permutations of $\mathfrak{S}_n$. Similarly, $\sigma$ is \emph{reverse alternating} if $D(\sigma) = \{2,4,\ldots,2\left\lceil{n}/{2}\right\rceil - 2\}$, \emph{i.e.} $\sigma_1~<~\sigma_2~>~\sigma_3~<~\cdots$. We denote by $\textit{RevAlt}_n$ the set of reverse alternating permutations of $\mathfrak{S}_n$.
plain_text_def: Let σ∈𝔖_n. We say that σ is alternating if D(σ) = {1,3,…,2⌊n/2⌋-1}, i.e. σ_1 > σ_2 < σ_3 > ⋯. We denote by Alt_n the set of alternating permutations of 𝔖_n. Similarly, σ is reverse alternating if D(σ) = {2,4,…,2⌈n/2⌉ - 2}, i.e. σ_1 < σ_2 > σ_3 < ⋯. We denote by RevAlt_n the set of reverse alternating permutations of 𝔖_n.
masked_plain_text_def: Let σ∈𝔖_n. We say that σ is alternating if D(σ) = {1,3,…,2⌊n/2⌋-1}, i.e. σ_1 > σ_2 < σ_3 > ⋯. We denote by B_MATH_TERM_n the set of alternating permutations of 𝔖_n. Similarly, σ is reverse alternating if D(σ) = {2,4,…,2⌈n/2⌉ - 2}, i.e. σ_1 < σ_2 > σ_3 < ⋯. We denote by B_MATH_TERM_n the set of reverse alternating permutations of 𝔖_n.

def:
\label{def1.2}Suppose that $A$ and $B$ are two sets in some ambient group,
and that $K \geq 1$ is a parameter. We say that $A$ is $K$-controlled by $B$, or that $B$ $K$-
controls $A$, if $|B| \leq K|A|$ and there is some set $X$ in the ambient group with $|X | \leq K$
and such that $A \subseteq (X \cdot B) \cap (B \cdot X)$.
plain_text_def:
Suppose that A and B are two sets in some ambient group,
and that K ≥ 1 is a parameter. We say that A is K-controlled by B, or that B K-
controls A, if |B| ≤ K|A| and there is some set X in the ambient group with |X | ≤ K
and such that A ⊆ (X · B) ∩ (B · X).
masked_plain_text_def:
Suppose that A and B are two sets in some ambient group,
and that K ≥ 1 is a parameter. We say that A is K-B_MATH_TERMled by B, or that B K-
B_MATH_TERMs A, if |B| ≤ K|A| and there is some set X in the ambient group with |X | ≤ K
and such that A ⊆ (X · B) ∩ (B · X).

def:
The prescribed sequences in the J-fraction expansions defined by 
\eqref{eqn_CF_exp_general_form} in the previous section, corresponding to 
( \emph{i} ) the 
Pochhammer symbol, $\Pochhammer{x}{n}$, and 
( \emph{ii} ) the 
convergent functions enumerating the generalized products, 
$\pn{n}{\alpha}{R}$, or equivalently, the 
Pochhammer $k$-symbols, $\Pochhammer{R}{n,\alpha}$, 
over any fixed $\alpha \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$ and 
indeterminate, $R$, are defined as follows: 
\begin{align*} 
\tagtext{Pochhammer Symbol} 
\{\as_k(x), \bs_k(x), \cs_k(x)\} & 
     \quad\overset{\text{ (i)}}{\defequals}\quad 
     \left\{ x+k, k, x+2k \right\} \\ 
\tagtext{Generalized Products} 
\{\af_k(\alpha, R), \bfcf_k(\alpha, R), \cfcf_k(\alpha, R)\} & 
     \quad\overset{\text{ (ii)}}{\defequals}\quad 
     \left\{ 
     R+k\alpha, k, \alpha \cdot (R+2k \alpha) 
     \right\}.  
\end{align*} 
\textbf{\textit{Claim}:} 
We claim that the modified J-fractions, $R_0(R / \alpha, \alpha z)$, 
that generate the corresponding series expansions in 
\eqref{eqn_PochhammerSymbol_InfCFrac_series_Rep_example-v1} 
enumerate the analogous terms of the generalized 
symbolic product sequences, $\pn{n}{\alpha}{R}$, 
defined by \eqref{eqn_GenFact_product_form}.
plain_text_def:
The prescribed sequences in the J-fraction expansions defined by 
(<ref>) in the previous section, corresponding to 
( i ) the 
Pochhammer symbol, xn, and 
( ii ) the 
convergent functions enumerating the generalized products, 
nαR, or equivalently, the 
Pochhammer k-symbols, Rn,α, 
over any fixed α∈ℤ^+ and 
indeterminate, R, are defined as follows: 

    Pochhammer Symbol{_k(x), _k(x), _k(x)}      (i)  { x+k, k, x+2k }
    Generalized Products{_k(α, R), _k(α, R), _k(α, R)}      (ii)  { 
         R+kα, k, α· (R+2k α) 
         }.
 
Claim: 
We claim that the modified J-fractions, R_0(R / α, α z), 
that generate the corresponding series expansions in 
(<ref>) 
enumerate the analogous terms of the generalized 
symbolic product sequences, nαR, 
defined by (<ref>).

def:
The $q$-TKR polynomial is denoted $T_\Delta^q(x,y)$ and is defined as follows.
$$T_\Delta^q(x,y)=\sum_{X\subseteq F} t_q(X) (x-1)^{\beta_{d-1}(X)-\beta_{d-1}(\Delta)}(y-1)^{\beta_d(X)}.$$
Where $t_q(X) = |\text{\emph{Tor}}(H_{d-1}(X),\mathbb{Z}_q)|$.
plain_text_def:
The q-TKR polynomial is denoted T_Δ^q(x,y) and is defined as follows.

    T_Δ^q(x,y)=∑_X⊆ F t_q(X) (x-1)^β_d-1(X)-β_d-1(Δ)(y-1)^β_d(X).

Where t_q(X) = |Tor(H_d-1(X),ℤ_q)|.
masked_plain_text_def:
The q-TKR polynomial is denoted T_Δ^q(x,y) and is defined as follows.

    T_Δ^q(x,y)=∑_X⊆ F t_q(X) (x-1)^β_d-1(X)-β_d-1(Δ)(y-1)^β_d(X).

Where t_q(X) = |B_MATH_TERM(H_d-1(X),ℤ_q)|.

plain_text_def:
Let 𝐤 be a field or the ring of integers, and let Δ be a d-dimensional simplicial complex.  We say that Δ is a 𝐤-homology manifold if 

H_i(_Δ(F);𝐤) ≅
𝐤      if i = d-|F|, 

0     otherwise,


for all nonempty faces F ∈Δ.  If, in addition, ||Δ|| has the homology of 𝕊^d over 𝐤, we say that Δ is a 𝐤-homology sphere .

def:
An $\ell$\emph{-arrangement of hyperplanes} is a pair $\AnV{A}{V}$, where $\A$ is a finite collection of hyperplanes
(codimension $1$ subspaces) in $V = \mathbb{K}^\ell$, a finite dimensional vector space over a fixed field $\mathbb{K}$.
For $\AnV{A}{V}$ we simply write $\A$ if the vector space $V$ is unambiguous.

We denote the empty $\ell$-arrangement by $\emptA{\ell}$.
plain_text_def:
An ℓ-arrangement of hyperplanes is a pair AV, where  is a finite collection of hyperplanes
(codimension 1 subspaces) in V = 𝕂^ℓ, a finite dimensional vector space over a fixed field 𝕂.
For AV we simply write  if the vector space V is unambiguous.

We denote the empty ℓ-arrangement by ℓ.

def:
\label{D:configuration}
A \emph{configuration} $W$ is a subspace of a based vector space\footnote{A \emph{generalized configuration} is a linear map $\varphi$ from a vector space $W$ to a based vector space.
In particular, for every generalized configuration $\varphi$, the image $\varphi(W)$ is a (nongeneralized) configuration in
the based vector space.
The results in this paper extend to generalized configurations.
We do not need this generality, so we refer the interested reader to~\cite{MyThesis}}. 
%A configuration has no preferred basis in general.

The results in this paper extend to generalized configurations.
We do not need this generality, so we refer the interested reader to <cit.>].

def:
\label{def:restrict} 
 Let $\eps,d>0$, $p \in [0,1]$, and let $R$ be a graph on $r$ vertices. Furthermore, let $G$ be a (not necessarily spanning) subgraph of $\Gamma = G(n,p)$ and let $H$ be a graph given with vertex partitions $\cV= \{V_i\}_{i\in[r]}$ and $\cW = \{W_i\}_{i\in[r]}$, respectively, such that $(G,\cV)$ and $(H,\cW)$ are size-compatible $R$-partitions.
  Let $\cI=\{I_x\}_{x\in V(H)}$ be a collection of subsets of $V(G)$, called
  \emph{image restrictions} , and $\cJ=\{J_x\}_{x\in V(H)}$ be a collection of
  subsets of $V(\Gamma)\setminus V(G)$, called \emph{restricting vertices} .
   For each $i\in [r]$ we define $R_i\subseteq W_i$ to be the set of all vertices $x \in W_i$ for which $I_x \neq V_i$. 
  We say that $\cI$ and $\cJ$ are a
  \emph{$(\rho,\zeta,\Delta,\Delta_J)$-restriction pair} if the
  following properties hold for each $i\in[r]$ and $x\in W_i$.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\itmarab{RP}]
    \item\label{itm:restrict:numres} We have $|R_i|\leq\rho|W_i|$.
    \item\label{itm:restrict:sizeIx} If $x\in R_i$, then $I_x\subseteq
    \bigcap_{u\in J_x} N_\Gamma(u, V_i)$ is of size at least $\zeta(dp)^{|J_x|}|V_i|$.
    \item\label{itm:restrict:Jx} If $x\in R_i$, then $|J_x|+\deg_H(x)\leq\Delta$ and 
    if $x\in W_i\setminus R_i$, then $J_x=\varnothing$.
    \item\label{itm:restrict:DJ} Each vertex in $V(G)$ appears in at most $\Delta_J$ of the sets of $\cJ$.
    \item\label{itm:restrict:sizeGa} We have
    $\big|\bigcap_{u\in J_x} N_\Gamma(u, V_i)\big| = (p\pm\eps p)^{|J_x|}|V_i|$.
    \item\label{itm:restrict:Ireg} If $x\in R_i$, for each $xy\in E(H)$ with $y\in W_j$, 
    \[\text{the pair }\quad\Big( V_i \cap \bigcap_{u\in J_x}N_\Gamma(u), V_j \cap \bigcap_{v\in J_y}N_\Gamma(v)\Big)\quad\text{ is
    $(\eps,d,p)_G$-regular.}\] 
  \end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
Let ,d>0, p ∈ [0,1], and let R be a graph on r vertices. Furthermore, let G be a (not necessarily spanning) subgraph of Γ = G(n,p) and let H be a graph given with vertex partitions = {V_i}_i∈[r] and = {W_i}_i∈[r], respectively, such that (G,) and (H,) are size-compatible R-partitions.

  subsets of V(Γ)∖ V(G), called restricting vertices .
   For each i∈ [r] we define R_i⊆ W_i to be the set of all vertices x ∈ W_i for which I_x ≠ V_i. 
  We say that  and  are a
  (ρ,ζ,Δ,Δ_J)-restriction pair if the
  following properties hold for each i∈[r] and x∈ W_i.
  
    
  *  We have |R_i|≤ρ|W_i|.
    
  *  If x∈ R_i, then I_x⊆⋂_u∈ J_x N_Γ(u, V_i) is of size at least ζ(dp)^|J_x||V_i|.

    if x∈ W_i∖ R_i, then J_x=∅.

  *  We have
    |⋂_u∈ J_x N_Γ(u, V_i)| = (p± p)^|J_x||V_i|.
    
  *  If x∈ R_i, for each xy∈ E(H) with y∈ W_j, 
    
    the pair   ( V_i ∩⋂_u∈ J_xN_Γ(u), V_j ∩⋂_v∈ J_yN_Γ(v))   is
        (,d,p)_G-regular.

term: fold GCD closed set;fold GCD closed set
def:
\cite[Definition 2.1]{Hong06}\label{def:r-fold}
Let $T$ be a set of $n$ distinct positive integers and $r\in [1,n-1]$ be an integer. We say that $T$ is a $0$-\emph{fold GCD closed set} if $T$ is GCD closed. We say that $T$ is an $r$-\emph{fold GCD closed set} if there is a divisor chain $R\subseteq T$ with $|R|=r$ such that $\max(R)\,|\,\min(T\setminus R)$ and the set $T\setminus R$ is GCD closed.
plain_text_def:
<cit.>
Let T be a set of n distinct positive integers and r∈ [1,n-1] be an integer. We say that T is a 0-fold GCD closed set if T is GCD closed. We say that T is an r-fold GCD closed set if there is a divisor chain R⊆ T with |R|=r such that max(R) | min(T∖ R) and the set T∖ R is GCD closed.
plain_text_term: fold GCD closed set;fold GCD closed set

We say that T is an r-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM if there is a divisor chain R⊆ T with |R|=r such that max(R) | min(T∖ R) and the set T∖ R is GCD closed.

plain_text_def:
In the context of Definition <ref>, we call a sequence of points (z_1, …, z_m) with z_i = (x_i, y_i) a b-increasing sequence if the following two conditions are satisfied.


  (a) (z_1, …, z_m) is an increasing sequence, that is x_i < x_i+1 and y_i < y_i+1 for all i ∈ [m-1].

  (b) Every point in the sequence is contained in some rectangle R_j with j∈[K]. In other words, (j-1)Δ x < x_i ≤ j Δ x implies b_j-1Δ y < y_i ≤ (b_j +1) Δ y.

Given a collection of points z = {z_i}_i ∈ [n], let _b(z) denote the length of the longest b-increasing subsequence of z. That is

    _b(z) max{m: ∃ (i_1, i_2, …, i_m)
                   such that  (z_i_1, z_i_2, …, z_i_m)  is a b-increasing sequence}.

Here we do not require i_j < i_j+1.

def:
Let~$G$ be a graph and
  let~${\ell},m,r>0$. The~$({\ell},m,r)$-\emph{splitter game} on~$G$
  is played by two players, ``Connector'' and ``Splitter'', as
  follows. We let~$G_0:=G$. In round~$i+1$ of the game, Connector
  chooses a vertex~$v_{i+1}\in V(G_i)$. Then Splitter picks a
  subset~$W_{i+1}\subseteq N_r^{G_i}(v_{i+1})$ of size at most~$m$. We
  let~$G_{i+1}:=G_i[N_r^{G_i}(v_{i+1})\setminus W_{i+1}]$. Splitter
  wins if~$G_{i+1}=\emptyset$. Otherwise the game continues
  at~$G_{i+1}$. If Splitter has not won after~${\ell}$ rounds, then
  Connector wins.

  A \emph{strategy} for Splitter is a function~$f$ that associates
  to every partial play $(v_1, W_1, \dots,$ $v_s, W_s)$ with
  associated sequence~$G_0, \dots, G_s$ of graphs and move~$v_{s+1}\in
  V(G_s)$ by Connector a set~$W_{s+1}\subseteq N_r^{G_s}(v_{s+1})$ of
  size at most~$m$.  A strategy~$f$ is a \emph{winning strategy} for
  Splitter in the~$({\ell},m,r)$-splitter game on~$G$ if Splitter wins
  every play in which he follows the strategy~$f$. If Splitter has a
  winning strategy, we say that he \emph{wins}
  the~$({\ell},m,r)$-splitter game on~$G$.
plain_text_def:
Let G be a graph and
  let ℓ,m,r>0. The (ℓ,m,r)-splitter game on G
  is played by two players, “Connector” and “Splitter”, as
  follows. We let G_0:=G. In round i+1 of the game, Connector
  chooses a vertex v_i+1∈ V(G_i). Then Splitter picks a
  subset W_i+1⊆ N_r^G_i(v_i+1) of size at most m. We
  let G_i+1:=G_i[N_r^G_i(v_i+1)∖ W_i+1]. Splitter
  wins if G_i+1=∅. Otherwise the game continues
  at G_i+1. If Splitter has not won after ℓ rounds, then
  Connector wins.

  A strategy for Splitter is a function f that associates
  to every partial play (v_1, W_1, …, v_s, W_s) with
  associated sequence G_0, …, G_s of graphs and move v_s+1∈
  V(G_s) by Connector a set W_s+1⊆ N_r^G_s(v_s+1) of
  size at most m.  A strategy f is a winning strategy for
  Splitter in the (ℓ,m,r)-splitter game on G if Splitter wins
  every play in which he follows the strategy f. If Splitter has a
  winning strategy, we say that he wins
  the (ℓ,m,r)-splitter game on G.

def:
\label{def.K-free}Let $E$ be a set. Let $\mathfrak{K}$ be a subset of the
powerset of $E$ (that is, a set of subsets of $E$). A subset $F$ of $E$ is
said to be $\mathfrak{K}$\textit{-free} if $F$ contains no $K\in\mathfrak{K}$
as a subset. (For instance, if $\mathfrak{K}=\varnothing$, then every subset
$F$ of $E$ is $\mathfrak{K}$-free.)
plain_text_def:
Let E be a set. Let 𝔎 be a subset of the
powerset of E (that is, a set of subsets of E). A subset F of E is
said to be 𝔎-free if F contains no K∈𝔎
as a subset. (For instance, if 𝔎=∅, then every subset
F of E is 𝔎-free.)
masked_plain_text_def:
Let E be a set. Let 𝔎 be a subset of the
powerset of E (that is, a set of subsets of E). A subset F of E is
said to be 𝔎B_MATH_TERM if F contains no K∈𝔎
as a subset. (For instance, if 𝔎=∅, then every subset
F of E is 𝔎-free.)

def:
Let $G$ be a group of order $v$ 
and let $D$ be a subset of $G$ with $k$ elements. Then $D$ is a $(v,k,\lambda,n)$-\emph{difference set in $G$} if the multiset $\{d_1 d_2^{-1}: d_1, d_2 \in D \text{ and } d_1 \ne d_2 \}$ contains every non-identity element of $G$ exactly $\lambda$ times and, by convention, $n=k- \lambda$.

def:
\label{definition-ultrafilter-limit}
Let $p\in \bN$ be an ultrafilter on the natural numbers and let $f:\N\to Y$ be a sequence of elements in a \emph{compact} topological space $Y$. Then, we define the \emph{limit of the sequence $f(n)$ along the ultrafilter}\index{limit along an ultrafilter|see{ultrafilter limit}}\index{ultrafilter limit} $p$ to be the unique point
\[  y =: \lim_{n\to p} f(n)  \in Y\]
which fulfills the condition
\[  \text{For every open neighborhood } U\owns y, \text{ we have } \inverse{f}(U)\in p  .\]
In other words, the sets of indices $\inverse f(U) = \{n\in\N : f(n) \in U\}$ of sequence elements that are mapped into the open neighborhood $U$ are required to be members of the ultrafilter $p$.
plain_text_def:
Let p∈ be an ultrafilter on the natural numbers and let f:→ Y be a sequence of elements in a compact topological space Y. Then, we define the limit of the sequence f(n) along the ultrafilterlimit along an ultrafilter|seeultrafilter limitultrafilter limit p to be the unique point

    y =: lim_n→ p f(n)  ∈ Y

which fulfills the condition

    For every open neighborhood  U y,  we have f(U)∈ p  .

In other words, the sets of indices f(U) = {n∈ : f(n) ∈ U} of sequence elements that are mapped into the open neighborhood U are required to be members of the ultrafilter p.

    y =: lim_n→ p f(n)  ∈ Y

which fulfills the condition

In other words, the sets of indices f(U) = {n∈ : f(n) ∈ U} of sequence elements that are mapped into the open neighborhood U are required to be members of the ultrafilter p.

def:
\label{definition-shift}
Let $A\subseteq\N$ be a set of natural numbers. For a number $n\in\N$, the \emph{shift}\index{shift of a set} $A-n$ is defined as the set $A-n := \{ k\in\N : k+n\in A\}$, or more suggestively
\[ k\in A-n \defineiff (k+n) \in A.\]
In other words, subtract $n$ from the numbers in the set $A$ and keep the nonnegative results.

Let A⊆ be a set of natural numbers. For a number n∈, the shiftshift of a set A-n is defined as the set A-n := { k∈ : k+n∈ A}, or more suggestively

    k∈ A-n  (k+n) ∈ A.

In other words, subtract n from the numbers in the set A and keep the nonnegative results.

    k∈ A-n  (k+n) ∈ A.

def:
[Addition of ultrafilters, limit version]
The \emph{sum}\index{ultrafilter sum}\index{ultrafilter addition|see{ultrafilter sum}} of two ultrafilters $p,q\in\bN$ is defined as the double limit
\[  q + p := \left(\lim_{m\to q}\ \lim_{n\to p}\ (m + n)\right)  \in\bN ,\]
of the ordinary sum $m+n$ of natural numbers $m,n\in\N$.
This limit is well-defined because the topological space $\bN$ is compact.

[Addition of ultrafilters, limit version]
The sumultrafilter sumultrafilter addition|seeultrafilter sum of two ultrafilters p,q∈ is defined as the double limit

    q + p := (lim_m→ q lim_n→ p (m + n))  ∈ ,

of the ordinary sum m+n of natural numbers m,n∈.
This limit is well-defined because the topological space  is compact.

def:
\label{witness}
A 1-\emph{witness} for a monotone function $f:\{0,1\}^\Lambda\to\{0,1\}$ is a minimal subset $W\subset \Lambda$ such that $\omega_W\equiv 1$ implies $f(\omega)=1$.
plain_text_def: A 1-witness for a monotone function f:{0,1}^Λ→{0,1} is a minimal subset W⊂Λ such that ω_W≡ 1 implies f(ω)=1.

def:
Let $u$ and $v$ be two vertices in an edge-labelled, directed graph $D$, $c$ a label, and $S$ a set of labels. We say that $c$ is $(\lam,  S)$-\emph{amidst} $u$ and $v$ if $c\not\in S$ and there is a length $\leq 2d_\lam$ switching path $P=(u,p_1,\dots, p_{d}, v)$ avoiding $S$ from $u$ to $v$ such that the following hold.
\begin{enumerate}[(i)]
\item There are no edges of $P$ labelled by $c$.
\item If $c$ is a vertex of $D$ then  $c$ is in $\{p_1, \dots, p_d, v\}$.
\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
Let u and v be two vertices in an edge-labelled, directed graph D, c a label, and S a set of labels. We say that c is (,  S)-amidst u and v if c∉S and there is a length ≤ 2d_ switching path P=(u,p_1,…, p_d, v) avoiding S from u to v such that the following hold.


  * There are no edges of P labelled by c.

  * If c is a vertex of D then  c is in {p_1, …, p_d, v}.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let u and v be two vertices in an edge-labelled, directed graph D, c a label, and S a set of labels. We say that c is (,  S)-B_MATH_TERM u and v if c∉S and there is a length ≤ 2d_ switching path P=(u,p_1,…, p_d, v) avoiding S from u to v such that the following hold.


  * There are no edges of P labelled by c.

  * If c is a vertex of D then  c is in {p_1, …, p_d, v}.

def:
\label{def:rep}
An $X$-\emph{arrangement} is a CW complex $Y$ and a finite set $\mathbf{A}$ of subcomplexes of $Y$ such that:
\begin{itemize}
\item[1.] The complex $Y$ is homotopy equivalent to $X^{\ast d}$ for some $d$, and $\dim (Y) = \dim (X^{\ast d})$.
\item[2.] Each complex $A$ in $\mathbf{A}$ is homotopy equivalent to $X^{\ast (d-1)}$ and $\dim (A) = \dim (X^{\ast (d-1)})$.
\item[3.] Each intersection $B$ of complexes in $\mathbf{A}$ is homotopy equivalent to some  $X^{\ast e}$, and $\dim (B) = \dim (X^{\ast e})$.
\item[4.] If there is a free group action of $\Gamma$ on $X$, then it induces a free $\Gamma$-action on $Y$ and every intersection of complexes in $\mathbf{A}$.
\item[5.] If $B\simeq X^{\ast e}$ is an intersection of complexes in $\mathbf{A}$, the complex $A$ is in $\mathbf{A}$, and 
%
% TYPO CHANGED AFTER SUBMISSION
%
%$A \not \subseteq B$, then
%
$A \not \supseteq B$, then
%
%
%
$A\cap B \simeq X^{\ast (e-1)}$.
\end{itemize}
plain_text_def:
An X-arrangement is a CW complex Y and a finite set 𝐀 of subcomplexes of Y such that:


  1. The complex Y is homotopy equivalent to X^∗ d for some d, and (Y) =  (X^∗ d).

  2. Each complex A in 𝐀 is homotopy equivalent to X^∗ (d-1) and (A) =  (X^∗ (d-1)).

  3. Each intersection B of complexes in 𝐀 is homotopy equivalent to some  X^∗ e, and (B) =  (X^∗ e).

def:
\label{def:szonyi}
	Let $\mcl A$ denote the ring $\mcl A:=\field[y]$. 
	Given $U\subseteq\plane$ nonempty and $n\in\N$ with $\# U\leq np$ we define $S_{U,n}(x,y),T_{U,n}(x,y)\in\field[x,y]$ be respectively the quotient and the remainder of the univariate polynomial long division in $\mcl A[x]$ of $(x^p-x)^n$ by $R_U$:
	\[
	(x^p-x)^n = R_U(x,y) S_{U,n}(x,y) + T_{U,n}(x,y).
	\]
	We call $S_{U,n}(x,y)$ the ($n$th generalized) \emph{Sz\H{o}nyi complement} of $U$.
plain_text_def:
Let A denote the ring A:=[y]. 
	Given U⊆ nonempty and n∈ with # U≤ np we define S_U,n(x,y),T_U,n(x,y)∈[x,y] be respectively the quotient and the remainder of the univariate polynomial long division in A[x] of (x^p-x)^n by R_U:
	
    (x^p-x)^n = R_U(x,y) S_U,n(x,y) + T_U,n(x,y).

	We call S_U,n(x,y) the (nth generalized) Szőnyi complement of U.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let A denote the ring A:=[y]. 
	Given U⊆ nonempty and n∈ with # U≤ np we define S_U,n(x,y),T_U,n(x,y)∈[x,y] be respectively the quotient and the remainder of the univariate polynomial long division in A[x] of (x^p-x)^n by R_U:
	
    (x^p-x)^n = R_U(x,y) S_U,n(x,y) + T_U,n(x,y).

	We call S_U,n(x,y) the (nth generalized) B_MATH_TERMnyi complement of U.

def:
[Moments of height]\label{thm:moments}
Let~$r\ge1$. The $r$\emph{th} moment of the height~$H_n$ satisfies
\[
\E{H_n}\sim \frac 2 \lambda \sqrt{\pi n}
\qquad\mbox{and}\qquad
\mathbb{E}[H_n^r]\sim r(r-1)\zeta(r) \Gamma(r/2) \left(\frac{2}{\lambda}\right)^r n^{r/2},\quad r\ge 2
.\]
plain_text_def:
[Moments of height]
Let r≥1. The rth moment of the height H_n satisfies

    H_n∼2/λ√(π n)        𝔼[H_n^r]∼ r(r-1)ζ(r) Γ(r/2) (2/λ)^r n^r/2,   r≥ 2
    .
masked_plain_text_def:
[Moments of height]
Let r≥1. The rB_MATH_TERM moment of the height H_n satisfies

    H_n∼2/λ√(π n)        𝔼[H_n^r]∼ r(r-1)ζ(r) Γ(r/2) (2/λ)^r n^r/2,   r≥ 2
    .

[(n,d)-expander]

Let n∈ℕ, let d∈ℝ^+, and let m:=m(n,d). A graph G is an (n,d)-expander if |V(G)|=n and G satisfies the following two conditions:


  (): |N_G(X)|≥ d|X| for all X⊆ V(G) with 1≤ |X|< m.

  (): e_G(X,Y)>0 for all disjoint X,Y⊆ V(G) with |X|=|Y|=m.

def:
Let $G$ be a rank $k$ hypergraph.
$G$ is $(\Delta, \omega_2,\dots,\omega_k)$\emph{-sparse} if 
$G$ has maximum $k$-degree at most $\Delta$, and for all
$1 \leq l < j \leq k$, $G$ has maximum $(j,l)$-degree at most $\Delta^{\frac{j-l}{k-1}}\omega_j$.
plain_text_def:
Let G be a rank k hypergraph.
G is (Δ, ω_2,…,ω_k)-sparse if 
G has maximum k-degree at most Δ, and for all
1 ≤ l < j ≤ k, G has maximum (j,l)-degree at most Δ^j-l/k-1ω_j.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let G be a rank k hypergraph.
G is (Δ, ω_2,…,ω_k)B_MATH_TERM if 
G has maximum k-degree at most Δ, and for all
1 ≤ l < j ≤ k, G has maximum (j,l)-degree at most Δ^j-l/k-1ω_j.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
Let X,Y ⊆ G_k be fixed.
Suppose that H ∈(n,k) such that every entry of H is contained in X,
and that M ∈(m,ℓ) such that every eigenvalue of √(m)^-1M is contained in Y.

Then the pair (H, M) is (X,Y)-sound if


  * For each ζ_k^i∈ X, we have √(m)^1-i M^i∈(m, ℓ).

  * For each ζ_k^j∈ Y, we have H^(j)∈(n,k).

We will often say that (H,M) is a sound pair if there exist sets X and Y for which (H, M) is (X, Y)-sound.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let X,Y ⊆ G_k be fixed.
Suppose that H ∈(n,k) such that every entry of H is contained in X,
and that M ∈(m,ℓ) such that every eigenvalue of √(m)^-1M is contained in Y.

Then the pair (H, M) is (X,Y)-B_MATH_TERM if


  * For each ζ_k^i∈ X, we have √(m)^1-i M^i∈(m, ℓ).

  * For each ζ_k^j∈ Y, we have H^(j)∈(n,k).

We will often say that (H,M) is a sound pair if there exist sets X and Y for which (H, M) is (X, Y)-sound.

def: Let $\lambda$ be a partition of $n$, and let $T$ be a filling of the Young diagram of shape $\lambda$ with linearly independent elements of $\mathbb{F}_q^n$. We call $T$ an $\mathbb{F}_q^n$\emph{-tableau} .
plain_text_def: Let λ be a partition of n, and let T be a filling of the Young diagram of shape λ with linearly independent elements of 𝔽_q^n. We call T an 𝔽_q^n-tableau .
masked_plain_text_def: Let λ be a partition of n, and let T be a filling of the Young diagram of shape λ with linearly independent elements of 𝔽_q^n. We call T an 𝔽_q^nB_MATH_TERM .

def:
Let $N_1$,~$N_2 \leq n$.  An \emph{$i$-intersecting (order-preserving) embedding} of~$(G_{N_1}, G_{N_2})$ into $G_n$ is a function $\phi: \ V(G_{N_1})\sqcup V(G_{N_2})\rightarrow V(G_n)$ such that:
\begin{enumerate}[(i)]
	\item the restriction of $\phi$ to either of $V(G_{N_1})$ or $V(G_{N_2})$ is an order-preserving embedding;
	\item $\vert \phi(E(G_{N_1}))\cap \phi(E(G_{N_2}))\vert=i$.
\end{enumerate}
We denote by $I_i( (G_{N_1}, G_{N_2}), G_n)$ the number of $i$-intersecting embeddings of of $(G_{N_1}, G_{N_2})$ into $G_n$, and set
\[I(N, n):=\sum_{1<i<e(G_N)} I_i\bigl( (G_{N}, G_{N}), G_n\bigr).\]
plain_text_def:
Let N_1, N_2 ≤ n.  An i-intersecting (order-preserving) embedding of (G_N_1, G_N_2) into G_n is a function ϕ:  V(G_N_1)⊔ V(G_N_2)→ V(G_n) such that:

	
  * the restriction of ϕ to either of V(G_N_1) or V(G_N_2) is an order-preserving embedding;
	
  * |ϕ(E(G_N_1))∩ϕ(E(G_N_2))|=i.

We denote by I_i( (G_N_1, G_N_2), G_n) the number of i-intersecting embeddings of of (G_N_1, G_N_2) into G_n, and set

    I(N, n):=∑_1<i<e(G_N) I_i( (G_N, G_N), G_n).
masked_plain_text_def:
Let N_1, N_2 ≤ n.  An i-intersecting (order-preserving) embedding of (G_N_1, G_N_2) into G_n is a function ϕ:  V(G_N_1)⊔ V(G_N_2)→ V(G_n) such that:

	
  * the restriction of ϕ to either of V(G_N_1) or V(G_N_2) is an order-preserving embedding;
	
  * |ϕ(E(G_N_1))∩ϕ(E(G_N_2))|=i.

We denote by I_i( (G_N_1, G_N_2), G_n) the number of i-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERMs of of (G_N_1, G_N_2) into G_n, and set

    I(N, n):=∑_1<i<e(G_N) I_i( (G_N, G_N), G_n).
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{def:ijchange}
       The\, transform\, from\, the\, sequence\, $ \vec{C}=\{c_1,\dots,c_{i-1},c_i,c_{i+1},\dots,c_{j-1},c_j,c_{j+1},\dots,c_n\} $ \, to\,  $\vec{C}^{\prime}=\{c_1,\dots,c_{i-1},c_j,c_{i+1},\dots,c_{j-1},c_i,c_{j+1},\dots,c_n\} $  by interchanging the $i$th element and the $j$th element is called an\,  $(i,j)$\textit{-interchange}\, of \,$ \vec{C} $.
plain_text_def: The  transform  from  the  sequence  C⃗={c_1,…,c_i-1,c_i,c_i+1,…,c_j-1,c_j,c_j+1,…,c_n}   to   C⃗^'={c_1,…,c_i-1,c_j,c_i+1,…,c_j-1,c_i,c_j+1,…,c_n}  by interchanging the ith element and the jth element is called an   (i,j)-interchange  of  C⃗.
masked_plain_text_def: The  transform  from  the  sequence  C⃗={c_1,…,c_i-1,c_i,c_i+1,…,c_j-1,c_j,c_j+1,…,c_n}   to   C⃗^'={c_1,…,c_i-1,c_j,c_i+1,…,c_j-1,c_i,c_j+1,…,c_n}  by interchanging the ith element and the jth element is called an   (i,j)B_MATH_TERM  of  C⃗.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{def:dual}
      For a sequence $\vec{C}=\{c_k,1\le k\le n\}$, do $(k,n+2-k)$\textit{-interchange} for all $2\le k\le u$, and we can obtain the \,\begin{it}dual sequence\end{it} \,$\vec{C}^d$\, of\, $\vec{C}$, where $u=\bigl\lceil{n/2}\bigr\rceil$,  \,$\lceil\,\rceil$ denotes the ceiling function.
plain_text_def: For a sequence C⃗={c_k,1≤ k≤ n}, do (k,n+2-k)-interchange for all 2≤ k≤ u, and we can obtain the  dual sequence  C⃗^d  of  C⃗, where u=⌈n/2⌉,   ⌈ ⌉ denotes the ceiling function.
masked_plain_text_def: For a sequence C⃗={c_k,1≤ k≤ n}, do (k,n+2-k)B_MATH_TERM for all 2≤ k≤ u, and we can obtain the  dual sequence  C⃗^d  of  C⃗, where u=⌈n/2⌉,   ⌈ ⌉ denotes the ceiling function.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
Let $\theta\in(0,1)$. A vertex $x$ of a graph~$H$ $\theta$-sees a set $U\subseteq V(H)$ if it has at least $\theta |U|$ neighbours in~$U$.\\
		Furthermore,  if $ C$ is a component of some reduced graph of $H-x$, we say that $x$ $\theta$-sees $ C$ if $x$ has at least $\theta|\bigcup V(C)|$ neighbours in $\bigcup V(C)$.
plain_text_def:
Let θ∈(0,1). A vertex x of a graph H θ-sees a set U⊆ V(H) if it has at least θ |U| neighbours in U.

		Furthermore,  if C is a component of some reduced graph of H-x, we say that x θ-sees C if x has at least θ|⋃ V(C)| neighbours in ⋃ V(C).
masked_plain_text_def:
Let θ∈(0,1). A vertex x of a graph H B_MATH_TERMs a set U⊆ V(H) if it has at least θ |U| neighbours in U.

		Furthermore,  if C is a component of some reduced graph of H-x, we say that x B_MATH_TERMs C if x has at least θ|⋃ V(C)| neighbours in ⋃ V(C).
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{thm:ham} $[Ham ~ Sandwich]$
Let $X$ and $Y$ be two sets of red and blue points, respectively, in general position in the plane. There exists a line $l$ such that $|X \cap{\emph{r}(l)}|=|X \cap{\emph{l}(l)}|$ and $|Y \cap{\emph{r}(l)}|=|Y \cap{\emph{l}(l)}|$. Moreover, if either $|X|$ or $|Y|$ is even, we may also assume that $l$ is not parallel to any segment which connects two points in the union of $X$ and $Y$.
plain_text_def:
[Ham   Sandwich]
Let X and Y be two sets of red and blue points, respectively, in general position in the plane. There exists a line l such that |X ∩r(l)|=|X ∩l(l)| and |Y ∩r(l)|=|Y ∩l(l)|. Moreover, if either |X| or |Y| is even, we may also assume that l is not parallel to any segment which connects two points in the union of X and Y.
masked_plain_text_def:
[Ham   Sandwich]
Let X and Y be two sets of red and blue points, respectively, in general position in the plane. There exists a line l such that |X ∩B_MATH_TERM(l)|=|X ∩B_MATH_TERM(l)| and |Y ∩B_MATH_TERM(l)|=|Y ∩B_MATH_TERM(l)|. Moreover, if either |X| or |Y| is even, we may also assume that l is not parallel to any segment which connects two points in the union of X and Y.

def:
\label{def:realizable}
A divisor $\calD$ in $|\self|$  is $C$-\emph{realizable} (or just realizable when there is no cause for confusion) if there is a curve $C'$ such that $\trop(C')=\Gamma$ and $\calD=\trop(C\cap C')$.
plain_text_def: A divisor  in ||  is C-realizable (or just realizable when there is no cause for confusion) if there is a curve C' such that (C')=Γ and =(C∩ C').
masked_plain_text_def: A divisor  in ||  is C-B_MATH_TERM (or just realizable when there is no cause for confusion) if there is a curve C' such that (C')=Γ and =(C∩ C').
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
[\textbf{Chernoff Bound}]\label{ChernofBoundTh}
For any $0\leq t\leq np$:
$${\rm \emph{\textbf{Pr}}}(|{\rm BIN}(n,p)-np|>t)<2e^{-\frac{t^2}{3np}},$$
where ${\rm BIN}(n,p)$ is the sum of $n$ independent variables, each equal to $1$ with probability $p$ and $0$ otherwise.
plain_text_def:
[Chernoff Bound]
For any 0≤ t≤ np:

    Pr(| BIN(n,p)-np|>t)<2e^-t^2/3np,

where BIN(n,p) is the sum of n independent variables, each equal to 1 with probability p and 0 otherwise.
masked_plain_text_def:
[Chernoff Bound]
For any 0≤ t≤ np:

    B_MATH_TERM(| BIN(n,p)-np|>t)<2e^-t^2/3np,

where BIN(n,p) is the sum of n independent variables, each equal to 1 with probability p and 0 otherwise.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
A metric graph $G$ is $k$-\emph{chordal} if for any cycle $C$ in $G$ with $L(C)\geq k$ there exists a
shortcut $\sigma$ of $C$.
plain_text_def:
A metric graph G is k-chordal if for any cycle C in G with L(C)≥ k there exists a
shortcut σ of C.
masked_plain_text_def:
A metric graph G is k-B_MATH_TERM if for any cycle C in G with L(C)≥ k there exists a
shortcut σ of C.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
A metric graph $G$ is $(k,m)$-\emph{chordal} if for any cycle $C$ in $G$ with $L(C)\geq k$ there exists a
shortcut $\sigma$ of $C$ such that $L(\sigma)\leq m$. Notice that being chordal is equivalent to being $(4,1)$-chordal.
plain_text_def:
A metric graph G is (k,m)-chordal if for any cycle C in G with L(C)≥ k there exists a
shortcut σ of C such that L(σ)≤ m. Notice that being chordal is equivalent to being (4,1)-chordal.
masked_plain_text_def:
A metric graph G is (k,m)-B_MATH_TERM if for any cycle C in G with L(C)≥ k there exists a
shortcut σ of C such that L(σ)≤ m. Notice that being chordal is equivalent to being (4,1)-chordal.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def: Given two vertices $a,b$ in a graph $G=(V,E)$  and some $r\in \mathbb{N}$, a set $S\subset V$  is an $ab$-$N_r$-\emph{separator}  if $a$ and $b$ are in different components of $G\setminus N_r(S)$. $S$ is an $ab$-\emph{neighbor separator} if it is an $ab$-$N_r$-separator for some $r$.%If $r=1$, let us denote simply $ab$-$N$-disconnecting.
plain_text_def: Given two vertices a,b in a graph G=(V,E)  and some r∈ℕ, a set S⊂ V  is an ab-N_r-separator  if a and b are in different components of G∖ N_r(S). S is an ab-neighbor separator if it is an ab-N_r-separator for some r.
masked_plain_text_def: Given two vertices a,b in a graph G=(V,E)  and some r∈ℕ, a set S⊂ V  is an ab-N_r-B_MATH_TERM  if a and b are in different components of G∖ N_r(S). S is an ab-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM if it is an ab-N_r-separator for some r.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{def:Gerstenhaber-Voronov} (see \cite{Gerstenhaber-Voronov})
{\rm A {\it brace} algebra is a vector space $B$ equipped with $n+1$-ary operations $M_{1n}:B\ot B^{\ot n}\longrightarrow B$, for $n\geq 0$, which satisfy the following conditions:
\begin{enumerate} \item $M_{10}= Id_B$,
\item $M_{1m}(M_{1n}(x;y_1,\dots ,y_n);z_1,\dots ,z_m)=$
$$\sum_{0\leq i_1\leq j_1\leq \dots \leq j_n\leq m} M_{1r}(x;z_1,\dots ,z_{i_1},M_{1l_1}(y_1;\dots ,z_{j_1}),\dots ,M_{1l_n}(y_n;\dots , z_{j_n}),\dots ,z_m),$$
for $x,y_1,\dots ,y_n,z_1,\dots ,z_m\in B$, where $l_k=j_k-i_k$, for $1\leq k\leq n$, and $r=\sum _{k=1}^ni_k+m-j_n+n$.\end{enumerate}
\medskip 

A $q$-\emph{Gerstenhaber-Voronov} algebra, ${\mbox {GV}_q}$ algebra for short, is 
a vector space $B$ endowed with a brace structure given by operations $M_{1n}$ and an associative product $\cdot$, 
satisfying the distributive relation:
$$\displaylines {
M_{1n}(x\cdot y;z_1,\dots ,z_n)=\hfill\cr
\hfill\sum _{0\leq i\leq j\leq n} q^{j-i}M_{1i}(x;z_1,\dots ,z_i)\cdot
z_{i+1}\cdot \ldots \cdot z_j\cdot M_{1(n-j)}(y;z_{j+1},\dots ,z_n),\cr }$$
for $x,y,z_1,\dots ,z_n\in B$, where for $q =0$ we fix that $q^j = 0$ if $j\geq 1$ and $q^0 = 1$.
}
plain_text_def:
(see <cit.>)
A brace algebra is a vector space B equipped with n+1-ary operations M_1n:B B^ n⟶ B, for n≥ 0, which satisfy the following conditions:
 
  * M_10= Id_B,

  * M_1m(M_1n(x;y_1,… ,y_n);z_1,… ,z_m)=

    ∑_0≤ i_1≤ j_1≤…≤ j_n≤ m M_1r(x;z_1,… ,z_i_1,M_1l_1(y_1;… ,z_j_1),… ,M_1l_n(y_n;… , z_j_n),… ,z_m),

for x,y_1,… ,y_n,z_1,… ,z_m∈ B, where l_k=j_k-i_k, for 1≤ k≤ n, and r=∑ _k=1^ni_k+m-j_n+n.


A q-Gerstenhaber-Voronov algebra, _q algebra for short, is 
a vector space B endowed with a brace structure given by operations M_1n and an associative product ·, 
satisfying the distributive relation:

    M_1n(x· y;z_1,… ,z_n)=∑ _0≤ i≤ j≤ n q^j-iM_1i(x;z_1,… ,z_i)·
    z_i+1·…· z_j· M_1(n-j)(y;z_j+1,… ,z_n),

for x,y,z_1,… ,z_n∈ B, where for q =0 we fix that q^j = 0 if j≥ 1 and q^0 = 1.
masked_plain_text_def:
(see <cit.>)
A brace algebra is a vector space B equipped with n+1-ary operations M_1n:B B^ n⟶ B, for n≥ 0, which satisfy the following conditions:
 
  * M_10= Id_B,

  * M_1m(M_1n(x;y_1,… ,y_n);z_1,… ,z_m)=

    ∑_0≤ i_1≤ j_1≤…≤ j_n≤ m M_1r(x;z_1,… ,z_i_1,M_1l_1(y_1;… ,z_j_1),… ,M_1l_n(y_n;… , z_j_n),… ,z_m),

for x,y_1,… ,y_n,z_1,… ,z_m∈ B, where l_k=j_k-i_k, for 1≤ k≤ n, and r=∑ _k=1^ni_k+m-j_n+n.


A q-B_MATH_TERM algebra, _q algebra for short, is 
a vector space B endowed with a brace structure given by operations M_1n and an associative product ·, 
satisfying the distributive relation:

    M_1n(x· y;z_1,… ,z_n)=∑ _0≤ i≤ j≤ n q^j-iM_1i(x;z_1,… ,z_i)·
    z_i+1·…· z_j· M_1(n-j)(y;z_j+1,… ,z_n),

for x,y,z_1,… ,z_n∈ B, where for q =0 we fix that q^j = 0 if j≥ 1 and q^0 = 1.

def:
\label{d:balanced}
Let $C \in \mathbb{N}$. 
A~pair of words $u, v \in \mathcal{A}^*$ with $|u| = |v|$ is \emph{$C$-balanced} if 
$$
-C \le |u|_j - |v|_j \le C \quad \mbox{for all}\ j \in \mathcal{A}\,.
$$
A~word $\omega \in \mathcal{A}^\mathbb{N}$ is \emph{$C$-balanced} if all pairs of factors $u, v$ of $\omega$ with $|u| = |v|$ are $C$-balanced.
A~word $\omega \in \mathcal{A}^\mathbb{N}$ is said to be \emph{finitely balanced} if there exists $C \in \mathbb{N}$ such that it is $C$-balanced.
plain_text_def:
Let C ∈ℕ. 
A pair of words u, v ∈𝒜^* with |u| = |v| is C-balanced if 

    -C ≤ |u|_j - |v|_j ≤ C    j ∈𝒜 .

A word ω∈𝒜^ℕ is C-balanced if all pairs of factors u, v of ω with |u| = |v| are C-balanced.
A word ω∈𝒜^ℕ is said to be finitely balanced if there exists C ∈ℕ such that it is C-balanced.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let C ∈ℕ. 
A pair of words u, v ∈𝒜^* with |u| = |v| is B_MATH_TERMd if 

    -C ≤ |u|_j - |v|_j ≤ C    j ∈𝒜 .

A word ω∈𝒜^ℕ is B_MATH_TERMd if all pairs of factors u, v of ω with |u| = |v| are B_MATH_TERMd.
A word ω∈𝒜^ℕ is said to be finitely balanced if there exists C ∈ℕ such that it is B_MATH_TERMd.
